39246178.review: Firstly, as a disclaimer, I haven't yet played the DLC. Now to get on with the actual game. I adore the Shantae series and if I had to pick, this would be my favourite one. I will start with the soundtrack as, like in the past, this game has a beautiful soundtrack. I have never been more pumped by a first level song like Dancing Through the Danger. Now in comparison, this game for sure embraces a more techno aspect to the music, however it does not lose the thematic aspects of the songs. On top of the fact that it feels really fitting. The all new shining graphics with clean cut character appearance just benefits the new type of music and I felt just made it all the better. The game looks gorgeous, the sprites are more animated than ever and still look clean cut. This game was definitely the easiest of them, but I wouldn't call that a bad thing, especially when they offer a more difficult way to play the game. It takes pieces of the previous games, weeding out the more disappointing factors and keeping the good. I prefered the level based gameplay from Pirate's Curse, which makes a return in this game, however there wasn't any level that I necessarily disliked. There were portions of levels I could care less for, one which I hated, but besides that they were all amazing, and I only disliked returning to them after like the fifth time I had to hunting for all the items. The story is as cute as ever, except it does feel a bit disconnected from the events of Pirate's Curse, I think mostly because it wanted to bring back transformations over the items in that game. With the bosses, it was a give or take. The final boss was mostly split into three back to back portions, I liked the first, but the second two were incredibly disappointing. I wish there was more to this game than there was really. 9.2/10

39229679.review:
Having played all the other Shantae... I can say this one is completely forgettable. It's a fun game in itself, but it suffers from a lot of issues. 

The levels are short, and the game encourages you to replay them to get things you missed. It wouldn't be so bad if they weren't all linear. 

Music and graphics are the main selling point of this title, the gameplay and story is nothing special. 

Shantae: Pirate's Curse made the gameplay way better, and the whole story is largely forgettable: everything returns just like everything were in the end. No character development, and even then, the character development from Risky Boots from the last game is completely forgotten. 

If they make a new Shantae, this one would probably not be relevant to the whole plot of the series. The universe the past Shantae games made, this one adds nothing; or like one detail about the Genie world and that's it. 

As for the difficulty, they could have made it better. The game is frustratingly hard in the beginning, and near the end, it's ridiculously easy. Bosses in the last couple of levels are real damage sponges. Especially Risky Boots. She takes so much hits, even with everything maxed.

I really, really like the Shantae series, and honestly, I wouldn't recommend this game.

39032631.review:
Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is the 4th game in the Shantae series and it's a game any Shantae fan, or any platformer fan will enjoy.

***NOTE: I HAVE ONLY PLAYED THE BASE GAME AND NOT DLC***

The series is known for its Metroidvania gameplay, however this game in particular feels more MegaMan-like than its previous titles. After getting a power-up you'll find yourself re-treading old ground and exploring new pathways and passages in search of goodies multiple times, but stages are selected via a menu this time around and it feels a lot less like exploring a world in comparison to the other worlds. Backtracking is common here and some people may find it tedious, but that just comes with the territory of playing a Metroidvania/MegaMan-style game, it's enjoyable to those who play these games and it is definitely fun in this game as well. Even if it lost a bit of its Metroidvania touch, it is still very rewarding and satisfying to play.

The controls are extremely responsive and fluid, the characters are cute and wholesome and the OST is absolutely stellar and is a blast to listen to. The whole game is a bundle of joy and it's impossible not to smile when you play this game.

The story in this game is nothing to write home about, however if you haven't played the previous titles you'll miss out on some of the emotional attachment and love from the recurring cast as their stories have already been explained previously, but it's not enough to detract from the experience. If this is your first Shantae game then you'll be fine. Although, I do wish that the story was more in-depth and involved. Previous titles had a surprising level of ambience and mystery revolving around Shantae and her world and there was far more involvement the Shantae cast had to do with the main storyline. There is a DLC that revolves around her friends, but I haven't played that yet so I can't comment on it.

Regardless, I enjoyed every second of this game and I believe anyone will if they give this a shot. For fans of the previous entries, this game is a must-buy. It's not as good as Pirate's Curse, but it's still great.

Overall, Half-Genie Hero is a much worse version of Pirate's Curse, and although I wouldn't say it's a bad game, it certainly isn't a great one either.

38967292.review:
TLDR: the game is too short, only buy when 50% off

Is it a bad game? No. Is it an enjoyable game? Certainly. Would I recommend it? I don't know, but steam doesn't have a neutral option, so whenever I'm neural I don't recommend a game since I feel like there are other games which I would rather play and recommend. The fundamental issue is that this game has a lot of back tracking. This is not a problem, I'm a metroidvenia fanboy, but contrary to a metroidvenia, this game has multiple individual levels which are linear. This makes it feel like it has a bit of an identity crises. This doesn't kill the game by itself, but in combination with the lacklustre length when compared to its price, 10 hours to 100% the normal campaign, it feels quite short. Other games, such as momodora, had the same price and length relatively speaking, yet I felt inclined to replay it because it was a lot more fun. The one thing that really definitively killed this game for me is that they released a 10 euro dlc with roughly 3 hours of playtime. It just feels like a ripoff. If you wanted to buy this game, buy shantae pirate curse instead. If you already owned that I would recommend shovel knight or hollow knight.

38918192.review:
Picked up Shantae: Half-Genie Hero as part of the winter sale at $12.99 and I feel like it was worth the price.  I'm not familiar with other titles in the series and it did feel like there was a decent amount of back tracking, especially if you wished to get the 100% completion, but part of my problem with that was I totally forgot about the whistle to summon Wrench.  The first item you get in game...  After that, using Warp and Wrench, made the collecting far easier.

What I did like:
+Art is absolutely beautiful
+Music was engaging, didn't feel out of place or repetative
+Fluid feeling controls and intuitive behavior
+Bosses felt challenging
+The hand holding (IE, the bath house lady) was helpful from time to time
+The different forms (monkey, elephant, harpy, etc) each felt useful
+It filled my pot breaking fetish nicely
+Art gallery featured both developer and fan art (kudos!)
+Enemies at later stages weren't just pallet swaps

What bugged me a little:
-Towards the end some of the final stage felt like Flappy Bird
-Even in the 'Flappy Bird' stage, I could dodge 50% of the puzzle by just flying very high
-It wasn't longer
-No way to get soundtrack (am I wrong here?)
-Enemy pool wasn't as large as I was hoping for (but at least they felt unique)

Overall, it was a bit shorter than I had hoped, but what I did get was super fun and engaging.  The characters were enjoyable, the stages fun (for the most part, see the Flappy Bird comment) and I was sad when it was over.  I haven't tried any of the DLC yet, but I hope to.  For the price at which I got this game, I highly recommend adding it to your library.  I played it with both the XBox Windows controller and the Steam controller, and didn't have any issues and didn't have to map anything out.  It worked 'out the box' so to speak.  Just sit down and enjoy slapping a variety of enemies about with your hair as you turn into a spider and later set fire to gators to turn them into delicious steaks.

38840155.review:
Despite the massive graphical face-lift, the level design, mechanics, and climax they build to are underwhelming as a follow-up to The Pirate's Curse.  The mermaid factory and its boss grabbed everyone's attention, but following it, things become far slower and more repetitive.  It's not a bad game, but I'm really hoping its assets become a springboard something better later on.  I'd be regretting it if I hadn't grabbed it on sale.

The backtracking in this installment feels excessive.  There are now 8 different forms that each have their own upgrade ability, which sounds great on paper.  But in practice, since none are great against the game's damage sponge enemies and many move slow, all but the monkey form see seldom use beyond getting through their obligatory required spots.  Re-entering the same 6 areas to slowly sift for the one new ability that lets you repeat the process somewhere else.  It becomes soul-crushingly dull when you have to comb the underwater depths as the crab, slowly entering each new body of water to find out there's nothing there, even more slowly jumping your way out, and repeating with the next of 4 neighboring lakes, trying to remember which pool needed which of three upgrades to get past.  I'm thankful they list all the items you haven't grabbed for each level to prevent it from being too confusing, but there are other issues with flow here.

Shantae is one of those side-scrollers that did away with one-hit death pits and spikes, instead just taking some of your health and moving you back.  I think they got carried away with that penalty in Half-Genie Hero, because some of the one-shot lasers and spikes are excessive, moving you all the way back to the entrance of an area.  This can mean walking through long, empty stretches that you depopulated of your enemies to try the one spot again.  While the penalty is technically lenient, the long walk still wrecks whatever sense of flow you had and retrying feels like a chore.   For areas that call for the harpy form, it's mainly difficult because you probably have no experience navigating obstacles with that form, so it's just a very annoying learning process.  Once you beat those spots, you're not going to use that form again, so it's not like you mastered anything.  I feel like these spots miss the point of what makes platforming rewarding.  It's neither snappy, nor makes you feel triumph for overcoming stuff.

Writing-wise, it's... actually kind of weird this would come off as a disappointment, given it's a comedic series that brushes off all sense of consequence.

===================================================
 SPOILERS FOR STUFF THE GAME NEVER REALLY CARES ABOUT, I GUESS
===================================================


No matter what Risky does, she gets thwarted, curses Shantae, and goes back to plotting something evil.  She usually takes and destroys something of Shantae or her uncle's in the process, but whatever, it's not permanent.  In Half-Genie Hero, she corrupts an entire world, and to prevent further damage (depending on the ending), Shantae has to blow it all up including her own mother.  Which is a little dark, but nobody really reacts to Risky herself over it.  The last time the series had an especially evil megalomaniac, it ended with satisfyingly pulling no punches, working in the previous installmetns' plot thread, and blwoing him up.  I'm not saying Shantae has to murder Risky in cold blood for my amusement, but it's a little hard to write off what just happened with "Oh, that darn Risky, up to no good with her slavery and genocide!"  After the last game implied there was more to the villain than one-dimensional evil, it's such an awkward regression.

If anything, I just think the game is tackling dramatic subjects it doesn't know what to do with.  Partway through, Shantae gets corrupted herself, but shakes it off thanks to all her friends cheering her on and thanking her for all she's done.  Even if you've played the previous games, it feels unearned and out of nowhere, since the surrounding story doesn't build up to it.  That and the titular heroine's already fought and beaten her own corrupted genie side before, so it's redundant and has no bite.  She still drones about feeling inadequate as only half gnie when she's had her best written and playable adventure as 0% genie, and something something proof she was all hero all along.  You're left with a long, drawn out dialogue sequence that ultimately adds nothing.  If the game is going to force drama and raise stakes, it really should have let its characters develop and try something new.  Otherwise, I think all the side villains work better as antagonists and rivals, since their plots end in far more satisfying punchlines, schadenfreude, and fourth wall breaking that fit the games' tone.

I'm still giving the game a thumbs up because all the work that went into the animation and music shows, and monkey Shantae is adorable.  I can only be so disappointed while doing Dennis Hopper impressions.

38788260.review:
Half Genie Hero makes me kind of sad because it goes a step back from Pirate's Curse. It is no longer a metroidvania. Instead, levels are super linear and most understandably require you to backtrack to them once you gain new transformations. The problem with this is the transformations take a lot from the pacing of the game, like in Risky's Revenge or the original. In Pirate's Curse, the items you found were designed to keep the flow of the game going. They could be combined to get to new areas or to gain speed. This made getting those items rewarding.
In Half Genie Hero, you cannot combine transformations very easily, as you could only transform on the ground and not in mid air or underwater, making super-quick transformations or ability combinations an impossibility. And even if you COULD transform in mid air, selecting a transformation takes ages in 1/2 Genie Hero, playing a little animation every time you transform instead of just transforming right away, which negatively impacts the pacing of the game. There's also something else to note: not every transformation has an ability anyway. These abilities need to be found in the game world, and they require a lot of backtracking, which is not very fun here. Not to say that it's HARD, it's just very unrewarding in my opinion.
That being said, I still think there is a lot to like about the base game. The bosses are all pretty fun to fight, the artstyle is great (though i personally prefer Pirate's Curse's artstyle a lot more), and the music is fucking banging. Unfortunately, however, the game is very short and can be beaten in just one sitting. Thankfully there IS a hero mode just like in Pirate's Curse, which ramps up the difficulty a bit. 
I don't know, man. Overall this game left a slightly sour taste in my mouth. This is one of those instances where a "Mixed" option would be useful, but I know Valve will probably never add it. So I'll give it a positive review just because I like the series.

I recommend getting Shantae: Half-Genie Hero while it's on sale.

38671324.review:
So I played the whole game, and to be honest I mostly regret it.

I went in thinking this game had a lot of cool ideas. Its a metroidvania style game that has more distinct levels, as opposed to an open world, which is something different. Plus the transformations seemed like a nice twist on the standard powerups you'd find in metroidvania style games. In practice though, both these just ended up being annoying. The more traditional style platformer levels didn't lend themselves to being fun to explore, and the way in which you explored the world was so methodical that it felt more like a chore. Futhermore, the transformations ended up being rather annoying as they really slowed down game play. Getting to the bottom of a water section as a crab, only to realize that you had to go all the way back to transform because you need the mermaid for this section was not fun in the least. 

Furthermore, combat is rather clunky. They're a bunch of broken power ups, and you can sort of just smash you way through the game if you choose. However, if you choose to disable the power ups, the enemies don't really feel designed in a way that rewards tight play. 

Overall, it was meh.

38493297.review:
Short Answer:
Good assets 10/10
would play again

Long Answer:
Let me get something out of the way. This game is NOT for everyone. If you are into Metroidvania, collecting items, fighting minibosses at the end of levels, and enjoy humor and a great soundtrack, this is a well spent $20. However, this game has great (( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)), they require a lot of work and dedication. Take "Old School, Baby!" To earn this achievement, you must complete Hardcore Mode. Read the name. Hardcore mode is NOT for everyone, since everything is buffed to give you a harder experience, that comes with an achievement worth bragging rights if achieved. There is another challenge, where the game must be completed within 2 hours to get the reason why I put "Best Assets 10/10" in the short answer. Chances are you may have heard of this reward, but I won't spoil it for you. In conclusion, if you tend to get upset about "I TOTALLY HUNG ONTO THAT LEDGE! THERE WAS NO REASON I DIED!" You shouldn't really buy this game. If you do buy this game, I wish you the best of luck. I had a LOT of fun with this game, and hopefully you do too!

Wrap up Rating: 9.8/10

38332214.review:
This game was decent. Good, not great though. I think a lot of the great things about the game are kinda surface-level. The game looks beautiful, the script is funny and the music is fantastic, but once you get past that, you just have a servicable platformer that doesn't seem to want to be anything besides a cute little game with a couple of metroidvania type elements thrown in. The game isn't long. I think I beat it in about 8 hours, and that was a lot of time spent backtracking through levels. Don't expect a Hollow Knight experience when it comes to exploration. Collectibles are few, and made simple by a very small, linear map. 

Bosses are pretty standard here. There are some weapons which interact with some of the things bosses do. For example, some of their projectiles can be reflected if you purchase the mirror upgrade. But none of this really matters, since bosses that can be hit by Shantae's hair can easily be face-tanked, thanks to an extremely forgiving health pool, an armor upgrade and an over-abundance of restorative items. 

I am just barely recommending it because it's a fun game. But with the caveat that it's not anything besides a basic platformer with cute graphics.

38123713.review:
[h1] Half-Genie Half-Sandiwich	[/h1]

After about 3 play throughs, here are my thoughts on the game.
[strike] I'm Dean Takahashi	[/strike]


[h1] The Plot	[/h1]

The plot of this game was alright for $20.00 but could have been written much better, it felt short but I can give it a pass, due to the budget. The story was kind of a let down, it felt like Shantae was going to be a hero for hire; going places and doing odd jobs, all while she has this new "Rival" (Holly Lingerbean) that constantly jeers at her, I thought she was going to the final boss or be near the climax. NOPE! Not even close, Holly never really appears in the story outside of the  3 cutscenes that she's in. Holly makes no impact at all in the plot just another thrown in villain, you could've just made the Sandworm the cause of everyone their losing memories and it still would have made more sense. 
Another thing was Risky, I know she's the series, main villain, but I feel she could have taken a back seat for a fresh face to be the new villain, if you wanted to have a Risky [strike] Boobs	[/strike] Boots final battle it could an endgame optional story (which this game doesn't have.)


[h1] Gamplay	[/h1]

I've Really had no problems here other than that some of the transformations being useless or having boring Mechanics.
The Spider is an example, I really wanted this to be my favorite form but it had no use outside of the puzzle rooms and the 2 achievements, (you could have added a poison effect to the Venom attack and added more ceilings to climb.) The elephant was a double edge sword, you deal 10 damage but end up taking damage if you don't finish them off. The Mouse maze mechanic was meh... It had potential but, ends up falling flat.
Other then that the game is pretty solid it just needs some polishing on some of the enemies and their cheap hits.

[h1] Animation/Graphics	[/h1]

The look of this game is great, the beginning of this game and the use of colors makes the tone of the game mysterious and spiritual. the animation is smooth for the most part, it has some hiccups with some choppy animations, bad motion tweens, and reuse of the Wrench level select sprite in the escape cutscene.


[h1] Overall	[/h1]

The game is Great, it's a lot of small things that hold it back. ( Ex. Transformations being underused, not enough areas to play in), I would recommend this game, but when it's on sale, to save yourself a few dollars.
if WayForward, you do release another Shantae game, add some more original villians and enemies, place in a few more enemies, and flesh out your Transfomations (more gameplay mechcanics, and interactions with the townsfolk and the transformations.)

37912383.review:
In some ways, Shantae reminds me of the Kirby series, even though they are quite different in style. It is kind of funny to think about it, but there are similarities here.

Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is a cartoon platformer that has a main world map where you run between a handful of levels, and each level has a few stages inside of them; but you can return to any of the levels or stages throughout the entire game (as you unlock them). The reason you return to them is to find new items to progress in the main story, because the items are usually hidden behind new passages that are inaccessible until Shantae (the main character) unlocks new powers.

I think Shantae's powers made me think of Kirby, even though the mechanic is not the same. Essentially, Shantae either gains new powers in the storyline at certain cutscenes, or finds them in chests hidden through stages. These powers allow Shantae to transform into specific types of creatures to navigate things like windy hallways, swimming underwater, flying in the air, and so on. On the other hand, Kirby is a pretty old platformer series where the main character was able to eat enemies and mimic their bodies to gain their abilities, which could also be used to get around. Different mechanics, but Shantae went along with a similar idea. [i](Note: I am sure that there are many other games in the past with transformations and navigation, but Kirby came to mind first!)[/i]

In any case, I enjoyed the main storyline of Shantae because the characters you encounter are all very funny in a tongue-in-cheek style. There's definitely some low-bar jokes in here, but I still laughed most of the time.

The visual style is a mix of 2D and 2.5D between the characters/enemies and the level design. The music of the game is quite catchy and I enjoyed listening to the majority of the songs along the journey. I really liked the art overall.

For the gameplay described above, it actually works for this game, even though you backtrack to certain levels many times. There are a few places where I got stuck and a little confused on what to do. I can understand that some people might get bored if they are unable to progress easily, because the backtracking then becomes painful. Thus, I would highly suggest to pull up a guide if you get stuck for a considerable amount of time.

I would say that a big improvement to the game would have been to add more levels overall and to lessen the number of times you had to revisit certain stages. Similarly, some of the transformation powers only get used a couple of times, and some of them are quite annoying. For instance, [spoiler]I really did not enjoy the Mouse power, as navigating the mazes was not fun nor did it require any thought. It simply wasted a bunch of time.[/spoiler]

Overall, though, I had some fun with the game here and would recommend the main storyline.

36814839.review:
Where to begin?

I have known about the Shantae franchise for a while now. I never got to play the physical copy of the original, but I have played it on my 3DS. Since then I have enjoyed the Shantae games from the original to Pirates Curse.

When I heard that Wayforward announced HGH via Kickstarter, I was hyped and managed to contribute to help make the game a reality a few years ago. Now I am aware Kickstarter has a bad rep. Many products there have been mediocre at best and a disaster at worst. However I am safe to say that despite waiting years for this game, I can announce that this game has not dissapointed me.

First off, the leap from the pixel style to the cartoon-ish look was a great choice in the art direction. I know that some games tend to stick with the classic look like Sonic Mania. But this is a beautiful game. The animation is smooth and appealing to those who can appreciate 2d animation in games.

The soundtrack is on-point. Jake Kaufman has once again done a tremendous job with the music for the game. From the upbeat updated version of Scuttle Town to the catchy electro sound of Riskys Hideout, it definately gave me various earworms. Dance through the Danger by Cristina Vee is a great theme for the game and she did a great job at it.

Now for the gameplay. HGH both feels like a Shantae game but at the same time doesn't. It has all the classic mechanics: upgrading hairwhip from the shop, unlocking dances that give you access to other areas, backtracking to get the items needed to progress. At the same time though, it feels a bit more streamlined than the other 3, they had the focus of exploring dungeons to progress the story. Here it goes for a more simpler approach, having a level select screen (taking a page from Pirate Curse) and getting from point A to B to beat the level. I personally don't take issue with this, but I know some who'd prefer the original style and might find it too easy.

Fortunately, Wayforward included a free update including Hardcore mode, I'm still having trouble getting through it as it makes you more cautious due to bein able to die much sooner so players wanting a challenge will likely enjoy that.

Speaking of additional content, with Pirate Queen Quest being the only one available at the moment with Friends till the End coming up, I really like this style of DLC, actually adding to the game rather than just giving a new weapon or a skin. It's an interesting concept, taking place at certain points in the original game and expanding on it. It takes all of the Shantae levels and flips them around with how each character (Risky only for the time being) gets around the level differently compared to Shantae. Though perhaps a bit too pricy.

Overall, I really enjoyed HGH, Wayforward is a really hard working company, and Matt Bozon should feel proud that not only did his game make it through Kickstarter, but one of the few that didn't backfire and worth the wait as they wanted the game to be the best it could be.

8.5/10

36561037.review:
You know that one game in a classic franchise that plays nothing like all the others? That's how I feel about Half Genie Hero. Half Genie Hero doesn't stick to the classic formula of traversing through one open world, going through dungeons, and collecting the main mcguffins before the villain can get ahold of them. At first, this really made me skeptical of the game. I bought this game about a month ago, and I did get a lot of enjoyment out of it, for the first couple of playthroughs anyways. It was fun the first time because you don't really know where all the collectibles are, unless you're following a guide of some sort. Then by the time you replay the game, you really start to notice how tedious getting 100% completion is, how the majority of the side plots go absolutely nowhere, and ultimatly how simplistic the gameplay and story is, (providing you're not going after all the achievements of course). I don't think the main campaign is bad pre se, but it does make me miss how the original Shantae, Risky's Revenge, and Pirate's Curse was structured. It was a formula that worked, and with WayForward getting rid of that structure, this just left me wishing there was more to Shantae's campaign. I can only recommend this campaign for those who don't really care about getting all the achievements and beating all the modes because this game really drains you around the third or fourth playthrough.

Pirate Queen's Quest, on the other hand, is structured better and really gives you more of a sense of non-linear progression. I love how this mode automatically lets you choose which level you want to play, and I wish Shantae's campaign would've been structured similar to this. True, you can't get any of the pirate equipment in any order, but being able to choose the levels in any order really adds a depth of strategy similar to how the robot masters are handled in classic Mega Man games. Plus the Dark Magic skill tree is genius as well, letting you develop Risky as you see fit. Of course, part of the reason I like this mode is because you get to play as Risky, and Risky Boots is probably one of the most over-the-top villains in any video game franchise, hence why I love being able to play as her and see things through her perspective. 

Friends to the End, oh where to begin...
For starters, let me say what I think Wayforward did right. First and most importantly, they got rid of the hubworlds and world select. This is how I perfer Shantae; an open world with all the different areas connected together that contain plenty of secrets that can be found once you get the right tools and explore everything. Wayforward also made this mode linear, which works out with Bolo's, Sky's and Rottytop's gameplay. Each character has unique abilities at hand as well, which can make for some interesting puzzles. This is extremely noticable in the last world, where you play as each character seperate, with each character having their own set of challenges. Rottytops is extremely broken as well, since using her decapitation powers gives her brief invulnerability, (which is a Godsend for the Nega-Shantae battle). Now for the negative aspects. This mode is difficult for ALL the wrong reasons. All the characters share a health bar, which wouldn't necessarily be a bad thing, EXCEPT Wayforward wants you to do a 3 heart run of the mode. In other words, your limited to 3 hearts, period. No heart holders to be found, no heart squids, just 3 hearts. Albiet Rottytop's can restore your health to full providing you have enough magic, but even then, if you don't have enough magic, then you have to be even more careful. It doesn't matter who you play as; none of these characters are built for combat.  This is especially noticable in boss fights such as the Giga Mermaid. I do like the Level Up system, but the least Wayforward could've done was made it to where all 3 members max health increases once someone levels up. Combine the poorly executed combat and the 3 heart run dibacle, and this mode will hand your butt to you on a silver platter on many occasions, especially when fighting the Giga Mermaid. As long as we're talking about rehashed assets, did Wayforward REALLY need to bring these bosses back? I don't look forward to Cape Crustacean or Hypno Baron's Castle because I can only imagine how much harder these bosses are going to be in this mode. I know people were complaining that both Shantae's and Risky's campaigns were relatively easy for a Shantae game, but this is how you make a game that's hard for all the wrong reasons. I want to praise this mode for the puzzle-platform aspects, but the combat could've used a lot more work. 

Overall, I don't think Half Genie Hero is a bad game. The main campaign and Friends to the End could've used a lot more work, as they are easily the most poorly executed parts of this game. And you know, it's sad that the only mode of this game that I really enjoy is Risky's campaign. I can see potential in Friends to the End, but the issues I've mentioned really makes me loath it more than I like it. This was an ambitious attempt Wayforward, but next time, go back to your roots...

36416377.review:
Ich bin ein großer Fan der Shantae Reihe und habe jedes dieser Spiele gespielt. Shantae: Half-Genie Hero ist der vierte Teil der ebends genannten Shantae Reihe und es hat mir wirklich Spaß gemacht.

Das Gameplay setzt zwar keine neuen Maßstäbe, ist aber trotzdem verdammt gut. Es geht gut von der Hand und macht Spaß. Das Platforming ist hervorragend. Nur wie sich Shantae an Harken fest hält, ist etwas fummelig.

Die Story ist diesmal etwas anders, als in den vorherigen Teilen. Hier werden eine Reihe an Mini Episoden erzählt, die nur von einem kaum bis garnicht vorhandenen roten Faden zusammengehalten werden. Ähnlich vergleichbar mit dem Storytelling aus dem Anime "Devil May Cry". Jede Episode ist eine Stage, die man alle nach und nach freischaltet und nach Abschluss nochmal besuchen kann, um die restlichen Secrets zu finden, sofern man die richtigen Fähigkeiten dazu besitzt.

Beim Look war ich anfangs etwas skeptisch. Ich bin allgemein kein großer Fan von Chibi (kleiner Körper, großer Kopf), jedoch sieht es im fertigen Spiel wesentlich besser aus, als erwartet. Ich mags.

Die Musik hat mich leider etwas entäuscht. Versteht mich nicht falsch. Sie ist wirklich gut, nur leider nicht ganz so gut, wie es im vorherigen Titel war.

Im Großen und Ganzen ist das Spiel abgesehen von ein paar Macken hier und da wirklich gut und definitiv empfehlenswert. Wenn ihr auf der Suche nach einem einfachen, guten und spaßigen Platformer seid, ist dieses Spiel absolut keine schlechte Wahl für euch.

I had tons of fun playing, replaying, beating the game on hard mode again and getting all the achievements.
It is pretty much all you want from a metroidvania and more.
Revisiting areas with newly acquired power ups again while having a decent gameplay challenge, responsive movement and combat with good quick animations that don't freeze up your character for to long.
The platforming feels good and is not to much of a challenge but hard enough that it feels nice when you beat it and goes nice with the awesome soundtrack.
The music is awesome.
The quality of the sprites and the artwork of the game overall is great and better than older shantae games.
I have to admit that I was a little sceptical from the still standing screenshots but it looks a lot better when its moving.
There was a very impressive amount of work put into the game and the humor is great if you like it but not annoying if you don't like it.
I'm just sad that the crowdfunding goals for the bonus chapters wasn't met because I am really looking forward for another shantae game of this caliber.
If you liked other games of the series you can expect to like this one as well.


Overall a great game and lots of fun to be had but in my opinion not as good as pirate's curse for a few little reasons in no particular order:

- Many Transformations with mediocre to little purpose.
For me constantly transforming into something because the edge of the wall is a little bit to high up or there is a boulder that has to be taken care off or there is a space in the wall that is only 1 tile wide is not that great.
Many of the transformations were also kinda useless except for that metaphorically x shaped hole it was designed to fit through (I'm talking about the first left and bottom, second left and right transformations here).
I would have loved better combat with the transformations but the attacks and slow and all in all they suck for normal combat.
I loved pirate's curse powerups because it would just let me use them in many situations without interrupting the flow or it would at least let me puzzle a little with the boots which in my opinion is a better solution then standing still for a few seconds to climb a wall even if the transformations are super cute.


- Wall and ceilingspikes are not as forgiving.
When you barely touch them (at corners not touching them at all) and its back to the beginning for you which is just not as fun as pirate's curse spikes that you have to get more than 1 pixel of your sprite into to actually be resetted to the start of the screen.
At least spikes are very rare except in the last level which is hard but in no way as hard as pirate's curse last level but pushed my annoyence level 300 times harder anyways because I DIDN'T TOUCH THESE SPIKES MAN!
I stood on top of a platform once that had spikes on the wall BELOW and transformed into something wider and I immediately counted as impaled even though there should be no way I was in, on or touching a spike in any way which only happened once but left me questioning the game obviously.


- More farming.
When I did the speed archivements I had to farm so god damn much even with smashing all pots in all levels when clearing them for the first time and on all revisits because there are now dances you can buy, the spells got more expensive and the upgrades increased in price too which left me with a boring ass farm session of farming a whooping 2000 rupees.
This is not to much of a problem on a normal playthrough.


- First and second fire spells are still very situational and got nerfed together with pikeball for some reason (I didn't use cloudpuff because it's to much of a bother for me to use). 
The only point in the game where I would ever use it for normal combat is in the earlier levels on hard mode which is very hard to solve without using some sort of ranged attack in the first level because enemies are so tanky and deal very high damage and you don't have healing items at that point.
I just don't get why we can't have a fire ball that deals 5 or even 6 damage with a faster fire rate because I need to invest magic and money after all.


- Bosses are meh gameplaywise.
They are fun to beat on the first playthrough because they look and feel amazing but they are just repeating their phases so fast.
Second boss was the most creative but the chasing attacks are a little annoying to deal with or you just ignore it and chugg healing items.
I don't want to say to much about the bosses because I don't want spoil them because they are good enough and still enjoyable.


- Lacking options.
Could use seperate sliders for sound and music, windowed options and more.
More options are always good.


- Pirate's queen's quest feels weird.
Levels got redesigned to be beatable without the transformations or any of the pirate items because you can choose the order you go through them.
At the beginning they are quite difficult but extremely easy once you acquire a certain amount of upgrade points and Items because your movement options increase but the levels stay the same.

35887881.review:
从“复仇”到本作，一路下来通关了移植到PC上的三作，（之前也曾尝试过GB的初代）感慨良多。
与前几作掌机的规格相比，本作各方面都进步很大，变成了一款主机规格的游戏，是一款超进化式的作品。
其实本系列一直在提高，只是本作确实有些麻雀变凤凰，画面大幅提高了，音乐更嗨了，内容更丰富了。
然而在进化的背后，系列前作一些特点也消失了，大概所谓成长了，但也失去了一些东西吧。
比如说原本颇为复古的像素风格被手绘动画风格取代了，游戏也变成了2D结合3D。即使颇为精美、效果不错，也更符合时代潮流，毕竟还是两个路数。对于像素风爱好者来说，是一种遗憾。
如果说画面风格算是萝卜白菜，各有所爱，游戏的玩法上变化就显得有些混乱
前两作都是类银河战士类，有着这类游戏独有的探索乐趣和重解谜的特质
本作关卡则改成了单程式，动作性更高，而解谜要素大幅降低。
而本作系统又偏偏是回归了一、二代，利用变身系统解谜是一大核心。
但虽然本作的变身系统更为丰富，但很多时候变身只是沦为开路的工具，或是收集道具的开门砖。
更不用说过多的变身，实际并不精炼。许多变身的进化技能更是敷衍，许多仅仅是可以攻击
这就导致前几作那些比较精妙的解谜不再。
当然，我说那么多，也只是一些个人想法，并不是否认本作的游戏质量。本作还是无愧于一个值得推荐的好游戏。
DLC还没买，等打折吧，不过那是DLC的事情了（听说有点坑爹）。
期待续作。

35503406.review:
Another great entry for the Shantae series, and just like the previous entries before it, it changes things up a bit from game to game.  The formula is different this time around, but the same Shantae feel is there more than ever.

[b]The Good:[/b]
As always, the music is fantastic.  In fact, I would go as far to say that this is the best soundtrack in the series.  Absolutely phenomenal.  And of course, it wouldn't be Shantae without the humor as I've found myself laughing at it's silliness.  Although I'm a sucker for pixel graphics, the change to a semi 3D/2D cel shaded graphic art style was very pleasing to the eye.  Its colorful, and alot of detail was put into character, level design, and animation.  Everything felt smooth.  

This is where WayForward changes things up a bit with the formula, Half-Genie Hero insteads goes the route of something akin to Mega Man, where this time you play through a level and less of the Metroidvania layout.  Now, I will always prefer the Metroidvania approach for this series, however despite the change to it's structure, it's still very much a solid platformer and I did not mind the change at all. 

One gripe I've always had with the Shantae series was it's difficulty, in that every game was on the Easy side.  The initial reviews for this game all seem to point towards the same issue at release.  I firmly believe the best way to play this game is on Hard mode.  Yes, it was frustrating at first, and yes I died a lot.  But it was incredibly challenging when it came to platforming and bosses.  Magic and the animal transformations where crucial for me to survive.   However, the more upgrades you get/find, it does mitigate the difficulty later on so Hard mode doesn't stay frustrating for long.  

[b]The Not So Good:[/b]
The manner you acquired new dances felt rushed.  Whereas the other games you happened on some fountain/genie/whatever that teaches you a dance, it was absent here.  Is it minor?  Yeah, probably, but I very much missed stumbling on some set piece to get a new dance.  

You will revisit the same areas again and again to progress the storyline.  For me, this wasn't a huge deal, as I loved going back to listen to the music and appreciate level design.  But for others, I can see this as getting tedious.  There where a couple of quests where I had to farm an item from a certain enemy, and again to me, felt rushed and unimaginative.  

There are no dungeons/labrynths in this one,  and I very much wished they included them.  Yeah, each level is great and well done, but it doesn't beat stumbling on a labyrnth in the open world.

Hard mode, although great, sometimes felt cheap.  Very early on in the game, enemies will one shot you and the enemy placement can be incredibly aggravating.  Sometimes, in order for me to survive through a level, I had to farm for items/hearts/magic jars.  Again, to me, not a big deal but a deal breaker for others.

[b]Overall:[/b]
What a fantastic game, truly a great platformer.  Despite it's flaws, I was willing to overlook them because of the carefully crafted game WayForward put together.  If you are a fan of  sidescroller/platformer/Metroidvania/whatever genre, pick this one up.  I think you'll enjoy it.

After playing all of Shantae games, this is how I would rate each series:

1) The Pirate's Curse
2) Shantae (GBC)
3) Half-Genie Hero
4) Risky's Revenge

35235636.review:
[i][u][b]Risky Discovery[/b][/u][i]

Shante Half-Genie Hero is the avant-garde of the magically charming, thrill-seeking, belly dancing, platforming franchise by WayForward Technologies. From the onset of the Kickstarter campaign, it was evident that the direction would not adhere to past titles. The newly cell-shaded rendition of Shantae by way of Inti Creates, to the level structure mirroring Mario land, to seeing my favorite character Rotty make it as a playable DLC long after the initial campaign had ended, WayForward had planted the seal of innovation into our expectations well before the conception of stage 2. It was a risk Wayforward took, as if in search of a breakout. I do think it will pan wonders, because features like expansion packs, variable art styles and level progression, and fan-selected palettes, can become mainstay ingredients for creating newer, fresher titles set in the diverse land of Sequin. 

[b]Plot[/b]

Simplicity is an effective staple of Shantae’s romp through Sequin. Deeply asleep, a voice calls out to Shantae, sending her underground of Scuttle Town where a mysterious apparition further lends to the confusion. Shantae is a confident half-genie, but at times most confusing, family have often been her crutch. Believing that her uncle could elucidate the oddity, she visits him which serves as the tipping point for the entire journey. This begins with witnessing a tinkerbat and Risky herself stealing Uncle’s newest blueprint: the Dynamo.

Uncle later tells her that the Dynamo [i]parts[/i] mustn’t fall within evil’s grasp. Fueled by her recent firing for failed safekeeping of Scuttle Town, she embarks on a transformative quest, most introspective, and every bit set on proving the mayor wrong, to regain her uncle’s lifework and in the process, possibly learn of that nighttime apparition. 

[b]Gameplay/Performance[/b]

The game ran smoothly for the entirety of my 100% run which lasted just shy of ten hours. Parallax scrolling in the new cell-shaded, 2.5-D render style forced me to gawk from time-to-time and take a few harpy arrows while screenshotting the scenery. The diversity in monster design was on par with what we’ve come to expect. The team went all out with transformations in terms of capacity and aesthetics. Please don’t tell me the siren isn’t cute. Swoons.

Boss fights were a mixed-bag. Most of them fell in one try from my platforming awareness, but I can see newer Half-Genies and those playing the genre for the first time stumbling across a hitch or two as they try to analyze patterns and gimmicks to defeat these two—three phase giants. As I mentioned earlier, the levels now have a beginning and an end and are selected via a world map. Thank you Sky! This is a huge divergence from the open world style of past titles, but in all honesty, it did not make the game feel any less ‘Shantae.’

This game also felt more fetch-quest driven than prior titles, especially when compared to the fast-moving Pirate’s Curse, though most of Pirate’s speed was derivative of the sword dash exploit and hover+cannon runs. Regardless, this game is slower in movement relative to Pirate’s Curse, however, much faster than the first two games. This speed difference thus necessitates the constant use of transformations ie monkey, harpy, etc. A veteran would implement these in a heartbeat for speed runs and be left with the envious quandary of choosing which to use for optimization.

Some screen tears were also present depending on the graphics card used, particularly Nvidia GTX 1050/1080, however, scouring the forums helped me in addressing most level 1 issues I encountered. Integrated graphics worked extremely well at 60 fps, granted needing the newer generation, higher end varieties. Vertical Synching is available and window adjustments are plentiful.

I was also pleased to see fan-selected palettes and the gallery selections. Moments like those is why we back games despite not knowing what awaits us. Good, bad, sometimes trust is necessary to gain something. 

[b]Tunes[/b]

There was not a track I found mundane or jarring. The overall selection was more bass heavy this time around, if not more electric. Christina Vee’s vocals starts the game right and the final boss’ theme was comparable to Pirate’s Curse true-final boss’ theme. Unfortunately, I cannot state my favorites given the nature of how stages are unlocked, but trust me when I say it’s upbeat fun. 

[b]Magical[/b]

Looking back, Shantae Half-Genie Hero was as much a game about Shantae seeking answers on her own as it was WayForward discovering a new direction. Maybe I’m reading too much between everything—too symbolically even—but I feel that there is a lesson to be had on aggregate: the Kickstarter campaign, the continued donations post-campaign via PayPal, the initial reception, to everything new about the game, along with the slew of Sequin-bound expansion packs. None of it would have been possible without effort, and adversity had served the catalyst for Shantae—both in-game and the developed product, which resembles most development cycles of fan-funded titles. Needless to say, something beautiful and worthy of a genie’s wish was in fact discovered when WayForward decided to take the risk in making Half-Genie Hero. 

Thank you WayForward~

35124045.review:
Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is a fantastic game, very fun and enjoyable. The platforming is great and the gameplay is well designed. The artsyle took some getting used to, but it quickly grew on me. And as it is in every Shantae game, the story is simple but still fun, and the soundtrack is awesome.

However, even if I think the game's great, I feel some of its potential is wasted, mainly when it comes to the transformations. There's a lot of different dances, but there's no balance whatsoever between how often you use them. Some are overused, and some others are used so rarely it's easy to forget they are there. The Spider Dance, for example, which I think is great in concept, is only required once in the entire game, and that's if you're going for 100%. The levels just aren't designed to fit its gameplay, and that's a real shame.
Also, I don't know who thought it would be a good idea to make the last stage a Flappy Bird minigame, but it was frustrating and I hated it.
All of that might be nitpicking, but I feel like giving some more thought to the level and puzzle design so they fit better would have made this the best Shantae game by far.

So, is this game worth it? Yes, it is. It has flaws and I still think Pirate's Curse is the best one in the series, but that doesn't mean the game itself is bad at all. If you're looking for a fun and light-hearted platformer, get this one.

Outside of Hard Core Mode, the game isn't espescially hard but you'll have fun while you're playing it. If you've not played any of these games yet, this is a good starting point.

“萌え”とはただの立ち絵や、ましてはキャラ設定テキストから読み取るものではない。見いだせる要素は無数にあるものの、ことゲームにおいては「動き」が重要な位置を締めているように思える。プレイヤーがインタラクティブに画面に干渉するコンテンツゆえに、連動して動かされるキャラクターらの挙動は、ヒトの心を揺さぶってやまない。最高にカッコよかったり、クールだったり、そして萌えたりするのだ。
一言で総括するとシャンティまじ可愛い。ほんと可愛い。無駄に体力全快のニュートラルポーズで放置しちゃう。ベリーダンスえろい。可愛いんだけどエロい。腰とかおっぱいが。登場キャラもみんなエロ可愛い。素晴らしいアニメーションだよ！

和訳がかなり怪しいが、いい感じの味になっている。時々メタ発言があるのもご愛嬌。こういう適当さがまかり通る世界観なのだろう。一方で中東風のデザインワークは本当に素晴らしい。

アクションゲームとしては、SFC時代の2Ｄアクションを思い起こさせる超正統派の懐古アクションゲーム。ていうかロックマンだよねコレ…。この頃の単純なゲーム性は、たぶん100年後にやっても一定の面白さを感じることができる。
変身能力を駆使してクリア済のマップを探索するのもそこそこ楽しいだが、ハーピーを手に入れるまではやや面倒に感じることもあった。

ギガマーメイドかわいい。タコかわいい。ゾンビ娘可愛い。敵も憎めない。町娘可愛い／食べ物を食べる時のシャンティの声がエロい／メインテーマがイカす／MP無限のアクセサリがチートすぎる／人魚の缶詰って…食用で出荷されてたんだよね…？人間の偽装人魚も肉缶詰になって出荷されてたわけで…グロいぜ…

是非続編をやってみたいね。

34771476.review:
I backed this game on Kickstarter, and I have to say that the direction they took here was incredible. The music is brilliant,  the art is amazing, the gameplay remains reminiscent of earlier titles in the series, and it's a great game for all ages to enjoy. Shantae has always been a bit of a Metroidvania with its vast levels and open exploration possibilities that encourage you to come back when you've picked up some powerups in order to unlock more of an area, and this game does not detract from that feature, giving much more to work with on the PC platform. 

Personally, I recommend this game, but the reason I gave this a thumbs-down is because WayForward also stole all the money that I invested into this game through Kickstarter without giving me any rewards other than the lowest tiers of pledge prizes. They were also not interested in fixing their error despite my reaching out to them on the issue, and I have to say that as someone who enjoys this series, I feel violated and betrayed for handing this company cash, and will never play their games or buy any of their products again.

Play the game. Enjoy the game. But don't trust this company.

34766082.review:
While I really loved the visuals and I'm addicted to the soundtrack - they're awesome as it's always expected for Shantae games - and I enjoyed a few smiles with the humorous dialogue and some happy parts of the game, this one has some flaws that ruin the experience. I'm going to borrow from one of the other reviewers and call this game a "tech demo". If you played Shantae and the Pirate's Curse you'll understand what I mean in this review.

Most of the game is too easy and even the tricky parts are not a problem because the game gives you too many items and purchasable upgrades to prevent damage, restore heath/magic, and even if you manage to die there are dozens of save checkpoints everywhere now (and they're annoying full screen save dialogs between areas).

The lack of an open world that forces you to revisit the levels wouldn't be a problem if some of them weren't uninspired and puzzle-free levels you just run around to collect objects while replaying them several times when you unlock a new power-up that lets you access an area you couldn't before. The fact this will give you more gems to buy the shop upgrades that make the game even easier makes matters worse and later it becomes pointless with a new travel feature.

It feels weird getting transformation dances and magic powers from chests, it kinda breaks the immersion or sense of belief and for the devs to not think about it is lazy and unexpected because in the first Shantae game a genie would appear and teach you magic stuff with some special effects as far as I can remember.

The story is an excuse to get you around collecting "nonsensical" items for random NPCs instead of things that have a connection of sorts with events. There's a funny item I won't spoil but that's it basically. Compare that with Pirate's Curse events where every thing you collect is related to the story and you have to think which character you need to give the item to and the obvious difference of experience shows.

I was disappointed to not having seen a magic carpet race minigame or something like Run Rottytops Run from the previous game. The mouse mechanics would do a great puzzle element but there's only a simple one thorough the game. Lots of lost opportunity. :(
I recommend the other games in the series instead.

Smooth art & animation with limited but perfect voice acting. Bouncy music that'll keep you amped throughout the game. The Pirate's Queen Quest DLC was pretty fantastic too although I would say $10 is asking a bit much for a DLC I beat in 3 hours.

I can find nothing negative about this game except maybe....it's not a metroidvania like the previous Shantae games, this one is trying to be different. But since this game is so well done I wouldn't necessarily say that's a bad thing in context of the game.

More like Half a game
There are a lot of transformations that are well thought and are pretty fun.
The game is really beautiful and the musics are great... that's it

Therefore the game relies heavily on back tracking to make the game last longer: you need to come back to every level at least once to get some random items and finish the game. It looks good, but it just has too many problems for me to like it.

-The story is terrible. Hardly exists at all. If you want anything that resembles a story, don't play this game. There's no funny moments either.
-The levels aren't designed around your abilities. It feels more like you're breaking the game with your abilities. Which is a big problem that makes the gameplay much less satisfying. It's incredibly easy because of this as well.
-The portraits in conversations look a lot worse than in previous games. Stuff like that bothers me a lot actually. Especially in a game that focuses so much on having superior graphics compared to the rest of the series.
-Less fan service than in Pirate's Curse. Another small problem but it still bothered me.

I'm bad at writing long reviews, so I hope this is good enough.

Although not as enjoyable as "The Pirate's Curse", still an enjoyable metroidvania that I recommend to any platformer fans.

[h1] ~What I liked about the game~ [/h1]
[list]
[*]The new art-style
[*]Some of the Bosses
[*]The Humor (Don't call it Poop Toot.)
[*]The characters as always
[*]Some of the buyable magic are fun to mess around with
[*]The Music
[*]Some of the transformations can make for good puzzles
[/list]

[h1] ~What I disliked about the game~ [/h1]
[list]
[*]The final boss extremely confused me in the first playthrough
[*]Transformations slow down the gameplay
[*]While the Magic is fun, it felt gimmick-y
[*]A bit too easy (but hardcore fixes this issue)
[*]The invinciblility bubble is way too Overpowered
[/list]

[h1] ~Conclusion~ [/h1]
Dispite the issues, this is a fun game to go through with good humor, a nice artstyle, a [i] wonderful [/i] soundtrack, and cute characters I want to hug and be friends with.

Rating:
[b] 7.7 [/b]

Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is a Realitively short game and 100% a run isn't too difficult either.
While the stages may feel short, the game has had a massive Graphical and Sound upgrade to it's previous sequels.
The songs in the game are quite rememberable and so are the characters.

The boss stages in 1/2 Hero are that they really aren't like the previous Sequels, there's no thinking of how to get the opportunity, no use for the Transformations to take it down, it pretty much doesn't let you take on what you've been using to get through the stage, and use it against a Boss fight, It's more of a "Bash em till they are done" stratergy.

The voice acting and overall quality of the game is outstanding, the Sound is crisp, the Music is amazing and the little bit of detail in characters are honestly amazing. This is one thing which alot of games fail to do and is have a sort of Mood scene music, which 1/2 hero does extremely well.

+Excellent Music which is rememberable
+Upgrades from the sequels are Impressive

-Stages fall a bit too short
-Bosses aren't very well thought

It is also worth noting that it is fairly easy to obtain every item in the shop by grinding the same level over and over and some of the hidden items and magic abilities are very overpowered making the game way too easy in some cases. 34169891.review:
目前除了DLC的成就，其他成就都完成了，shantae在steam三作当中个人最喜欢的一作。
没有汉化补丁，英文基本能看得懂，不知道往哪里走的时候去跟浴室人物对话就能获得提示。
游戏确实有虎头蛇尾的感觉，最后的一张地图细节好少。
动作方面，手感也是一级棒，同期玩过空洞骑士，手柄延迟以及烦人的跑图让我给了差评，这作当中，每次有新技能重新跑图都会有新的发现，个人觉得做的比空洞骑士好很多。
说几个细节：
1.用火烧鳄鱼，会掉任务道具，同时也是很好的回血药
2.有些成就可以尝试二周目完成，难度与一周目完全不同
3.变身老鼠爬管道是个让人印象深刻的设计
4.基本所有的成就都可以通过再次进图完成，但是有一个，最终BOSS之前，收集risky四样道具，需要四样道具都在身上才能解锁，收集齐之前不要与发明家叔叔对话，不然会把已有的东西给出去，成就就不能完成了，只能重新开始游戏。

目前DLC全成就也已经完成
前四个成就比较简单，搜集所有物品打通关就可以，最后一个成就的要求有些苛刻，条件是：1.物品全搜集 2.一小时30分以内通关；需要同时达成这两个条件才能解锁成就
游戏的DLC素质还是不错的，不过就是价格有些高，个人觉得不值这个价格。
这个DLC的性质，就像是苍月十字架里面，用阿鲁卡多3个人去讨伐苍真一样，地图没有重新设计，也有相对完整的剧情，最终BOSS是主角本人，苍月的十字架这个模式直接就包含在本体里面，这款游戏把他单独做成一个DLC，并且售价超过了游戏本体的一半，我觉得是不合适的DLC不着急玩可以不买，建议等打包优惠再入。

34099929.review:
Dissapointing departure from METROIDVANIA adventure roots of 1st and 2nd game to dumb linear unchallenging platformer with endless hordes of enemies spawing in your face.
Shantae 2 was the game that made me fall in love with metroidvania genre, Shantae 4 aka Half-Genie Hero is the game that ruined almost everything series was loved for. 

I really tried to love this game, but i just cant beat huge dissapointment.

Yeah, art direction is nice, but even it has departure from sexy Shantae of previous game to feminist friend chubby chibby Shantae, and besides new art direction there is nothing interesting.

Also i really hate inconsistence of level design between games, they cant keep main town and Shantae home consistent between games, every time i start new shantae if feel dissonance and keep asking myself "who the **** rebilt the island again?", and there is no in game excuse to that (they could at least add like 2 lines where shantae asking why town needs to be rebuild and always different, and someone tells here that major is weirdo and cant keep things consistent).

And something really fucked up UI designers in a head - instead of showin cutscenes talks at lower part of screen like they used to be in previous games, they are show in upper part... you may think its not a big deal, but thing is that art cut from bellow, there is no smooth fade out to transparency and it feels like amateur work or bug that misaligned conversation UI.

And controls getting worse and worse in every game. Its amazing how they can make controls clunky when they had so many buttons unused.

Everything in this game feels lazy, rushed and half-assed, and while i love WayForward games (especially shantae 2 and duck takes remake) this one feels almost as bad as their Blood Rayne betrayal. I think they are working on way too many projects nowadays and dont put their souls in their games anymore.

The only thing that devs can do now to please betrayed fans of what Shantae supposed to be - make a Shantae Trilogy ramake with assets from this abomination and yet with gameplay of previous game (however 3rd game was not that good as well, but at least it was way better than this one, it kinda was mixed between 2 and 4).

Damn it, i really want huge maze levels like it used to be in Shantae 2, i want backtracking... i want puzzles, i want a lot of conversations with other charactes and i want adventure\quest genre elements that was vital part of Shantae 2 and was dumbed down in 3 and almost completely gone in 4 Half Genie Hero :-(

34071359.review:
Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is a fun and beautiful game, yet when compared to the series' previous titles it falls immensely short.

The levels are very short and the game would be a good 4 hours long if it wasn't for the sheer amount of backtracking that pads the game out for the most part. The gameplay is simple yet enjoyable, and the amount of collectibles to find will make any Banjo-Kazooie fan squeal in delight. Unfortunately, previous Shantae games do what Half-Genie does only better in almost every aspect.

I will RECOMMEND this game, but ONLY TO DIEHARD FANS of the series.

34064735.review:
Finalmente un nuovo gioco di Shantae, questa volta un gioco nativo su PC e le console casalinghe: dunque addio alla vecchia grafica pixellosa e via con una nuova bellissima veste grafica che ricorda molto "Ducktales remastered", un'altro bellissimo gioco della Wayforward. Tuttavia Shantae Half Genie Hero fallisce ad impressionare i giocatori, specialmente i più appassionati della serie, consegnando un gioco dall'identità confusa e evidenti carenze nel gameplay e nel rinomato backtracking, componente fondamentale dei giochi di questo tipo, i metroidvania.

Il più grande cambiamento di questo capitolo è senza dubbio la nuova predisposizione stage by stage in opposizione al mondo aperto dei metroidvania che facilita il backtracking e permette un esplorazione più profonda e soddisfacente. Ovviamente questo non sarebbe un problema se il gioco, essendo strutturato livello per livello, cominciasse e finisse pezzo per pezzo senza dover tornare nei livelli passati. Shantae Half Genie Hero sbaglia nel porsi a metà fra uno stage by stage e un metroidvania nel senso che: i livelli iniziano e finiscono ma bisogna tornare più volte in questi per prendere oggetti e ulteriori abilità necessari per tornare nei livelli passati e scoprire delle sezioni nascoste. Essendo dunque uno stage by stage la mappa è sparita e questo è decisamente un grosso difetto per un gioco che si dovrebbe basare sul backtracking e l'esplorazione in generale. Per sicurezza, per chi ha intenzione di ispezionare ogni cm del livello (come questo tipo di giochi richiede), i giocatori, a meno che non abbiano una memoria di ferro, sono costretti a ripetere più e più volte intere sezioni dei livelli passati con le nuove abilità, sempre se queste siano quelle adatte per scoprire le parti nascoste del livello; spesso e volentieri il  backtracking può risultare inutile e spesso si finisce per lasciare un livello già esplorato senza aver concluso niente. Parlando di queste sezioni nascoste, queste sono minuscole e non danno alcuna soddisfazione tipica dei metroidvania, appunto lo scoprire un intero "livello nel livello", cosa che i precedenti giochi consegnavano perfettamente. Il level design è ok ma per la sua non linearità, sempre per via dell'assenza della mappa, sarà sempre arduo capire dove si è stati e dove serve andare sopratutto durante le fasi di backtracking. Sarebbero dei buoni livelli se questi fossero esplorati una sola volta, invece bisogna tornare troppe volte e, spesso e volentieri, anche odiare certe sezioni. Se gli sviluppatori avessero seguito solamente il sistema stage by stage avremmo avuto sicuramente più livelli con gimmick diverse e probabilmente una longevità generale maggiore, ma invece ci troviamo solamente con pochi stage che siamo costretti a rigocare più e più volte e che restringono la durata del gioco. A tal prosito il gioco produce un ritmo veramente poco originale e tedioso: completa il livello, ottieni una nuova trasformazione, recupera un oggetto e/o abilità e/o trasformazione dal livello passato, ottieni una mappa per un nuovo livello  (mappa che serve solo a Sky per volare fin lì, voi, ovviamente, non potrete consultarla!), completa un nuovo livello, ottieni la nuova trasformazione, torna nei livelli passati a cercare nuovi oggetti/abilità/trasformazione, ottieni la mappa, vai in un nuovo livello e così via... Sempre per via di tutti questi backtracking Shantae sarà piena di trasformazioni poco diverse fra loro rendendo molte di queste veramente poco originali e superflue; ad esempio la trasformazione in arpia e quella di pipistrello che fondamentalmente fanno la stessa identica cosa ma da pipistrello puoi volare solo a destra e sinistra con precisione, da arpia puoi volare in ogni direzione ma in maniera disordinata e poco adatta nelle situazioni che richiedono precisione. Insomma, tante trasformazioni per gimmick nei livelli poco originali e che ci costano solo tempo e pazienza per rivisitarle.

Il gioco impressiona tantissimo invece sotto la veste grafica, curatissimi gli sprites senza la minima visibilità dei pixels, animati perfettamente senza la minima sbavatura e bellissime le ambientazioni 3D che danno sfondo alle avventura della nostra cara mezzo-genio. La musica non è niente male, molto upbeat, ci sono molti vecchi temi tanti quanti nuovi temi anche se a volte questi ultimi contengono molto spesso il tema principale. La storia è graziosa ma è molto simile ai più belli Shantae e Shantae: Risky's revenge. Dopo Shantae and the Pirate Curse mi aspettavo un qualcosa tanto quanto originale se non di più e invece qui, in termini di storia così come in termini di gameplay, si fa un passo indietro e si semplifica il tutto senza riuscirci. Mantenuto invece lo humor tipico della serie, a tratti demenziale e a tratti persino velatamente sconcio ma a questo punto è veramente una goccia in un oceano.

Un vero peccato per questa serie che negli ultimi anni ci ha stupito con titoli veramente validi in grado di ottenere ottime recensioni e annoverarsi fra i migliori titoli del genere metroidvania. Shantae Half Genie Hero è probabilmente un gioco per i fan della serie e che hanno già giocato a Risky's Revenge e Pirate Curse, giusto per aggiungerlo alla loro collezione e provarlo. Per chi vuole cominciare a cimentarsi con la serie targata Wayforward, Shantae Half Genie hero non è certamente un gioco con la quale iniziare, non ha quelle cose che hanno fatto grandi i titoli precedenti e finirebbero per avere un idea sbagliata di cosa sia questa serie. Magari forse è un po' più adatta ai casual gamers senza aspettative né alte né basse o a un papà che vuole comprare un gioco grazioso per il proprio figlio ma i più appassionati troverebbero questo gioco poco originale e con parecchi difetti. Sarà per la prossima volta!

6.5/10

34014262.review:
After playing Risky's Revenge and Pirate's Curse, I had to pick up Half-Genie Hero and this is possibly my favourite in the series. The controls are simple but refined, the visuals are gorgeous, the music is catchy as all hell and the game knows what it's aiming for - pure, unadulterated fun!

The overall look is vibrant and crisp, the aesthetics are fantastic as always and the character design manage to be fun and sexy without crossing the line into sexualised. Shantae herself of course mostly wears her genie's outfit (a.k.a a bunch of ribbons with delusions of grandeur) and the mermaid's wear little more than seashells, but you're not going to find any panty shots or gratuitous boob close-ups here. 


RR and PC were a little more open-worldy, even metroidvania-esque at times, but while HH has a simpler level structure you're unlikely to ever get lost, with a couple of artifacts available from the get-go that let you duck in an out of levels as needed. The dancing transformations make a return and while they'll never be a seamless as the Pirate's Curse controls they're very well streamlined, especially the dancing.

Story-wise it's an odd mix, being something of a soft reboot. Basically they've kept all the stuff that's useful (Shantae good, Risky bad, Rotty misunderstood and her brothers aren't trying to kill you)  but there's sadly no trace of the surprising depth given to Risky or her relationship with Shantae in Pirate's Curse. Maybe these things will be re-explored in a sequel but for now it's a little more black-and-white.

In any case, great fun, highly recommended and bonus points for bringing in Christina Vee on the vocals.

33946044.review:
This is Risky's Revenge: Definitive Version.
No, i am 100% serious.
This is exactly what Risky's Revenge was supposed to be, but couldn't achieve due to limitations of DSiWare.
It has same mechanics as Risky's Revenge, with all the magic stuff and use of transformations.
Plot is almost exactly like Risky's Revenge.
Hell, first and final levels are both almost exact as Risky's Revenge first and final levels.
The feeling of Deja Vu was with me the whole time through my playthrough.
...It's not bad, though.
I am glad i finally saw Risky's Revenge as it was intentended to be.
It looks great, it sounds great, feels... pretty good, plays... pretty good.
But...
I wasn't expecting another Risky's Revenge.
I've been waiting for a new game in the series, with new mechanics, new things overall, like...
Well, like "and the Pirate's Curse".
I still think that Shantae and the Pirate's Curse is the best in the series.
It has best length, best story, best gameplay, best feel and pretty good, colourfull, cartoony pixelart graphics with great soundtrack.
It was new for the series, really new, and it's still one of my favourite metroidvanias of all time.
But, most importantly, it was the best in gameplay department, i need to reassure this.
1/2 Genie Hero was... a step backwards.
It was still fun, but... It wasn't as good as the Pirate's Curse AND it had too much infuriating moments sprinkled throughout the game, ESPECIALLY FINAL LEVEL.
GOD I HATE FINAL LEVEL.
I HATE IT AS MUCH AS I HATE RISKY'S REVENGE FINAL LEVEL.
sigh.
Half-Genie Hero is still a great game, i had a lot of fun, i like it very much.
But it wasn't as good, as The Pirate's Curse. A little but of a letdown.
Still, i will recommend it to... well, pretty much everyone. Especially considering the fact that it has not much connections with previous titles, it can be you first or your latest Shantae title and it won't matter at all, unlike "The Pirate's Curse", which was heavily connected to Risky's Revenge, and vice versa.
Buy it, you PROBABLY won't regret it.
WayForward deserve our money.

33911825.review:
Нет, извините.
Какое-то невероятное количество сюжетно требуемого бектрекинга и пиксель-хантинга.
Структура уровневая, хотя в прежних частях мир был открытый, и эти уровни надо просто вылизывать неоднократно.
После миссий с летающими кораблями меня отправили искать кристал света на одном из двух открытых уровней, причем одни кивали на один, а вторые на второй. Вылизав уже вылизанный уровень я нашел-таки масюсенькие дырочки, в которые надо залезать мышкой, пробегав по ним, нашел волшебника, который за помощь потребовал конфету. Где искать конфету - не имею ни малейшего понятия, подозреваю что надо ползти в город и обтыкивать всех, чтобы получить какой-нибудь туманный намек на ещё один из уровней.
Плюс когда пробегаешь уровни, невероятно раздражает огромное количество мест, куда пока ты попасть не можешь, потому что нет абилок. Особенно когда перед тем, как понять что дальше ты не пройдешь, надо проплыть пару комнат.
Я смотрю на людей, у которых 14 часов в профиле и понимаю, что все эти 14 часов надо вылизывать уровни в поисках абилок, которые нужны, чтобы вылизывать уровни в поисках абилок.
Зачем разработчики выбрали такой дурацкий метод увеличения хронометража - не понимаю и понимать не хочу. Раньше все собирательства ограничивались бонусными хитпойнтами. Раньше было лучше. Начинайте знакомство с серией со старых игр.

33564762.review:
Shortly:
4th Shantae game that continues the story further., however Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is quite different from its predecessors.

First recognisable difference is how the game looks. Unlike the pixxelated art style in the previous Shantae games, this time the game has this more cartoonish art style which isn't half bad. The character movements and the world feels more alive.

That leads to the 2nd noticable difference, which is the world itself. In the previous games, you had this semi-open world that you could explore once you obtained powers to do so. There's no such thing in the Half-Genie Hero, but instead the world is diveded into stages/worlds. Each stage/world has several areas lined after each other that you can explore and at the end of each world there's a boss waiting for you. Once you defeat that, the world is cleared and you can move on to next one. Its kinda similar to how the islands worked in the Pirate's Curse, but this time they have this "super mario" feeling in them. It's just not the same as it was in the previous Shantae games, which is kinda disappointing for me. I would have preferred the semi-open world like the Risky's Revenge had.

Unlike in the previous Shantae games, the Half-Genie Hero doesn't have any dungeons either, which is mostly because of how those stages/worlds wokr that I mentioned earlier.

Other than that, the game is pretty much the same old Shantae games that we're used to.

Pros:
+ Improved art style
+ Familiar gameplay mechanics with few additions mixed in
+ Entertaining 2D platformer
+ Bigger variety of different abilities

Cons:
- Semi-open world replaced with stages/worlds
- No dungeons
- Save points way too often, which means that dying is no longer punishing as the game asks you every 2-3 minutes if you want to save your progress  (why couldn't they just implement auto save instead if they didn't want people to feel punished for dying, though personally I hate auto saves if they save your progress like that )
- The Soundtrack isn't as good as it is in the previous titles - The OST is similar but too...modern.. if you could call it that. Didn't enjoy it personally

Do I recommend?
Yes. Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is entertaining 2D platformer and it continues the story where the Pirate's Curse left on. I have to warn you though, the game is not as good as its predecessors are, because of the stage/world system.

Verdict:  6.5 / 10 - Good game  (though not as good as its predecessors are because of the stage system)

33525641.review:
Como um jogo em que me diverti tanto (Pirate's Curse) pode ter tido uma continuação TÃO RUIM?

Parece que o jogo foi feito por outra pessoa, o level design é horrivel, simplistico e sem graça, as transformações são inuteis, os mapas são feitos para você usar o macaco e nada mais (e de vez em quando colocar uma pedra na frente pra te forçar a usar outra transformação e falar "Olha! Estamos usando outras transformações! Olha como nosso mapa é bem feito")

Você acha que o jogo vai ser como o Pirate Curse: Terminar um mapa, pegar um item e continuar o proximo (ou raramente ter que fazer alguma coisinha em um mapa anterior para então ir pro proximo mapa, mas não, o jogo te força a refazer TODOS OS MAPAS com sua "nova transformação" para pegar 1000 coletaveis para ai sim ir pro proximo mapa

Nem cheguei no quinto mapa e estou enjoado do jogo, rejoguei TODOS OS MAPAS mais de 10 vezes

O jogo é assim:
-Terminou o mapa e conseguiu poder novo
-VOLTE EM TODOS OS MAPAS e pegue coletaveis para então pegar o mapa da proxima fase e poder ir nela
-Repita

Faça o teste você mesmo, vá na segunda fase e veja quantos caminhos você não pode fazer porque "Você não pegou esse poder ainda" e pense que quando você pegar esse poder você terá que voltar TODAS AS VEZES nesse mesmo mapa, e no proximo, e no proximo, e no proximo

Pior sistema de backtrack que ja vi na vida

Sem falar que o jogo não é intuitivo, tem momentos que você chega em uma parte e fica preso, então você fica "O que eu faço?" e então você descobre que um tipo de chão é "atravessavel" se voce se abaixar e pular, você pensa "Legal! Então todos os outros chãos iguais a esse também são assim". Mas quando você volta na fase (DE NOVO) testar isso essa regra não existe mais! Nenhum chão igual a aquele é atravessavel. Esse é só um dos exemplos de "não intuitivo" que esse jogo é, ele muda as regras quando ele bem entende

O jogo também não é recompensador, você descobre maneiras mirabolantes para acessar certas areas dificeis para chegar em uma parte do mapa meio secreta para sua recompensa ser NADA ou na maximo 1 vaso com algumas gemas (dinheiro do jogo)

Jogo horrivel

Queria reembolsar essa droga, nem na promoção valeu a pena (20 reais)

Quer um Shantae daorinha? Jogue o Pirate's Curse
