29252060.review:
[b]Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is a simple yet very enjoyable action plate-former in a gorgeous and loveable universe.[/b]

It's relatively short with only 6 levels, but those levels can be replayed and explored further to find bonuses that will widen your exploration possibilities by giving you secondary transformations, more mobility options, etc, so that completionnists will still have a fair amount of time to devote to hunting collectibles.

Despite this fair amount of replayability, Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is a very easy game, made all the easier by how broken some bonuses are (like, say, [spoiler]using the Invincibility relic alongside the Magical Tiarat that makes all your relics cost NOTHING, meaning you're invicible against everything but spikes and bottomless pits so as long as you don't transform[/spoiler]), but thanks to its incredible backgrounds and overall art direction, and an upbeat soundtrack by Jake Kauffman, playing and replaying each and every of those levels is a pure blast. 

Except [spoiler]the final level, which relies on aforementioned spikes EVERYWHERE to create a sense of difficulty while you must traverse them using the Harpy form, which controls kinda awkwardly, making your deaths seem somewhat bullspit and unfair.[/spoiler]

EDIT: [spoiler]I also regret how the character of Risky Boots evolved from being somewhat respectful and appreciative of Shantae at the end of Pirate's Curse only for her plot in the game to the most evil one yet. Bad Risky! :([/spoiler]

Other than that, everything's fantastic. The visuals are wonderfully polished, the humour and wit of the series is present, there are collectibles everywhere for you to hunt, and more content including another campaign mode is coming soon! [b]8/10[/b]

29230047.review:
Eu tive o prazer de começar a jogar a série Shantae em 2015, com o Jogo Shantae: Risky's Revenge, desde então joguei na sequência Pirate's Curse  e eu também adorei. Não tive dúvidas: comprei este jogo logo que lançou, e foi uma ótima aquisição.
O jogo, além dos jogos anteriores da série, consegue manter uma jogabilidade fluída e divertida, a personagem principal é cativante. Nota-se o trabalho bem feito na produção do jogo, com uma história simples, porém muito interessante. O jogo não busca ter algo muito sério em sua trama, preferindo manter algo mais engraçado e descontraído, e é isso que torna Shantae muito legal.

Os puzzles não foram feitos para serem difíceis, focando mais para diversão do que uma plena realização de ter conseguido uma façanha difícil. Mas isso não tira nenhum mérito do game.

A jogabilidade é muito agradável, e os desenvolvedores sabem muito bem como fazer um jogo de plataforma de qualidade.

29228042.review:
Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is in no way a bad game. It has much of what made the previous Shantae games great, like its fluid animations, great visuals, silly story and amazing music. The gameplay feels fantastic and responsive aswell. But despite the game's numerous positives, one can't help but feel a little disappointed. 

The metroidvania style world building and levels in the previous titles have been cut for "chapters". A chapter consists of several linear stages (go right. for the most part) and side scrollers. There are secrets spread throughout each chapter. Some you can get right away, while others you'll need a certain skill to get to. This forces you to backtrack and revisit chapters, and is a small substitution for the metroidvania styled secrets. This however doesn't make the exploration that enjoyable, as you're forced to run through the stages quite a few times to get everything. There is a dance you can get in the game called "Warp Dance", that lets you skip a previously completed stage. This helps getting to a correct stage faster, if you know there is an unacquired secret there. But you will still always start at the very beginning of a stage, so you'll always have to run through the beginning each time you want to visit the area.

Another minor disappointment is the absence of a few animations that exists in the game's previous titles. Some examples are the various dance animations, a proper dodge animation, and an idle "hurt" animation. Even though they seem minor, and not too important. It all adds up, and more fluid animations helps the atmosphere of the game greatly. However, this doesn't change the fact that the game has quite a few animations already, and of very great quality.

One can't help but feel that the game is missing something when coming from Shantae and the Pirate's Curse. There are many small things that if added, would add that little extra bit of polish and quality, and it would help out the game immensely. There are even concept art within the game that shows that there was so much more planned for the game, but for whatever reason was scrapped. If it is because of the lack of money or time isn't easy to tell, but it could also be because of the promises they have to deliver because of the kickstarter.

These are however minor flaws. Half-Genie hero is very enjoyable for what it offers. The game oozes "Shantae" from the very beginning, and is a treat for every fan of the series. If there is one thing WayForward doesn't get (too) wrong, it's the Shantae titles. And one can tell that they really care about this series.

Here's to a successful Risky dlc campaign, and future Shantae titles, because this series is absolutely splendid.

29214087.review:
This game is an example of how crowd-funded projects can turn out spectacularly well.  If you've played any of the Shantae games before, you already know what to expect.  If you haven't, you've clearly had a deprived, borderline abusive childhood, and I'm sorry for that.

Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is a 2D platformer that, despite the HD graphics, retains its indie-esque feel.  Mechanics of the game are simple enough to pick up quickly, yet with enough depth that the game remains enjoyable many hours later (I pause to note that Steam vastly underestimates how many hours I've put into this game.  At time of writing, it's close to 20 hours).

Having mentioned it earlier, I should mention that the graphics of this game are simply gorgeous.  It's an upgrade from the classic style without disrespecting its roots.

Soundtrack is absolutely amazing.  Plenty of allusions to previous Shantae games that carry over with distinctive sequencing, and virtually guaranteed to be stuck in your head for hours to come.  Not that I'm complaining.

With regards to the plot/story, Shantae isn't known for its compelling storytelling.  The plot is best described as 'cute' or 'quirky' and mostly serves as a vehicle by which the gameplay is delivered.  The dialogue is snappy and self-aware enough to be entertaining to read, carried by characters that are caricatures of stereotypes, but are entertaining rather than annoying.

The achievement list is very reasonable with only a single 'joke' achievement, and one harder achievement for completing a 100% speedrun.  That being said, I 100%'d the game in about 10 hours in-game (which involved two full playthroughs).  If you can't be bothered to route the speedrun yourself, there are plenty of guides for it hanging around.

Overall thoughts:  This game is absolutely amazing and everybody should be playing it.

29210172.review:
I've got a lot to say about this game, but not all of it positive. TLDR; Good game, Wait for sale.

---

Pros:[list]
    [*]Character Design, Visuals, and Animations: Gone are the days of the retro low-res character sprites and pixelart tiled level design. Each character has high resolution character sprites that are fluidly animated, and the traversable environments are all rendered in cell-shaded 2.5D.
    [*]Music: Anybody that has played a Shantae game will tell you that it has some of the best music of the platforming genre. A lot of the more memorable leitmotifs from the series, such as the Burning Town and the main theme, return in a number of ways. This include such tracks as Neo-Burning Town, which retains its middle-eastern flair while also taking on a club-music feel, and Dance Through the Danger, which I'm admittedly biased about because Cristina Valenzuela (the voice actress for Shantae's spoken lines) provided A++ vocals for the song. Never get tired of hearing that woman sing. Like all Shantae Games, you'll be hard pressed not to find a track from its soundtrack that hooks you.
    [*]Puzzles: The game loves to make you look for the solution to finding that one collectable you can see but not get to. At the same time though, they are never too difficult; it's usually just a matter of backtracking, and if you keep up with chatting with the NPCs, you'll never be short on hints. Just keep on exploring. Just be aware that some transformations completely kill puzzles, and some puzzles you can technically complete before you get the ability or power-up required to do them.
    [*]Boss Battles: One thing I've always liked about the boss battles in the Shantae games is that they are almost always unique, and in Half-Genie Hero, it was no exception. One battle has you relying on bits of the environment introduced in a mission, while another has you running yourself in literal circles as you try to figure out how to actually damage the boss.[/list]
    [*]Transformations: Lots of them. I won't spoil all of them, but a number of the classics from both the gameboy color Shantae title, as well as the returning forms and abilities from Risky Revenge make their return in Half-Genie Hero, in addition to a number of new ones to play with.

---

Cons:[list]
    [*]Performance: For a modern game with such modest specs, Half-Genie Hero has its share. For one, the game has Vertical Sync permanently enabled and expects your monitor to have the exact refresh rate of 60Hz, meaning that if you're running on a 120Hz monitor, or you're playing on a TV at a non-60Hz refresh rate, such as one running at 1080i, you're going to have a bad time. It spazzes out on higher refresh rates, and on lower rates, sprites flicker, FPS caps at 30, and within the first minute of the game the camera goes epileptic before shooting off into the void. Even if you're running it at a 60Hz refresh rate on a progressive resolution—say 720p—and your system meets and exceeds the reccomended system specsthere's no guarantee you're going to get that smooth 60FPS the game expects to run at without a bit of fiddling. Case in point, I had to tell Radeon Settings to use the Frame Rate Target Control at 60 just to get that smooth 60 at 720p.
    [*]Level Design: To put it bluntly, the levels are incredibly short. Most of the dungeons consist of medium or large 'rooms' that require you to navigate back and forth through on the x and y axes, taking into account the elements and obstacles of that particular level. You might be required to hop across a series of platforms that fall if you stand on them for too long, or scale a tall room hopping from moving ring to moving ring. For the most part, it's a far cry from the Shantae standard of dungeons being a series of small interconnected rooms. Heck, it's so simplified that you don't even get a map this time around. This brings me to...
    [*]World: In the previous Instalment, Shantae and the Pirate's Curse, you access to Scuttle Town as your 'hub', from which you had access to a boat which would take you to the world you would then need to navigate and explore, just to get to the dungeon. In Half-Genie Hero, the devs took the 'boat' and decided, "How about we just drop you right in the 'dungeon' and cut out the middle man." You just go to Skye's place, hop on her mode of transportation, and off you go to the dungeon select screen. Don't even get me started on Pirate's Curse vs. its predecessor. Of course, to account for the smaller world and bigger, they had to put in a lot of...
    [*]Padding: With only a series of short dungeons, the devs definitely seemed hard pressed to make sure the game lasted. To account for this, they utilized a number of things to pad out the game. Backtracking was always a big thing in previous Shantae Games, but a lot of it could usually be mitigated by knowing where something was ahead of time. There wasn't TOO much that hinged on you having a specific transformation, or a particular ability for said transformations. I'm not talking about little mini-puzzles that force you to use specific transformations and problem solving, I'm talking about the things that draw things out such as [spoiler]the mouse form mazes[/spoiler], or one-off abilities such as [spoiler]sonar for the bat transformation, which is used for all of one puzzle that can technically be solved without it[/spoiler]. You see that collectable on display right out in the open where you can't get it because you don't have a specific ability? You're going to be tormented by those a lot for three quarters of the game until you get that power you don't have. Then of course you have things like rings that disappear from the foreground or the infamous disappearing platforms. If you've played the classic Megaman games, you know exactly what I'm talking about. They're just a right pain to get the timing down on, which just creates...
    [*]Artificial Difficulty: I just want to say that Half-Genie Hero is not a hard game. That said, it does have segments that will make you want to tear your hair out. For example, in the very final dungeon, you are required to use your [spoiler]Harpy[/spoiler] transformation to [spoiler]navigate a series of spiked walls, some of which were moving[/spoiler]. This might not have been so bad if the game actually gave you reason to use said transformation [which was only just acquired AFTER the second to last dungeon] and some practice, but you're basically thrown into the deep end of the pool with cement sneakers on, and you've been missing leg day lately. It is basically [spoiler]Flappy Bird[/spoiler] in that section. You have an early segment where you're in a restricted movement auto-scroller, and you need to rely on reflexes and skill to not miss a jump or hit something that will inevitably damage you. [spoiler]This kind of segment returns after the final boss and is cranked up to 11, with shorter platforms, the rings where if you're not placed just right, you will miss and go back to the start, and wall of death that continues to take up more and more of the screen, making the segment a game of memory and reflex as you end up with less and less space to work with. It was, apparently, difficult enough that the devs removed your life bar for this segment. I can only imagine how bad it would have been otherwise.[/spoiler]
    [*]Stretch Goals: In case it wasn't readily apparent, Half Genie Hero is a kickstarter game, and budget can be blamed for some of the shortness. Two of the levels in this really short game were in fact stretch goals. Yep, the game would be shorter if those goals hadn't been met. Iterestingly enough, the very first stretch goal, a mode where you play as Risky Boots, is not present as of this review, and is slated as Coming Soon. So in a way, the launch exclusion of Risky Mode, coupled with the performance issues kinda gives the game an Early Access feel rather than a full launch.[/list]

29198733.review:
[h1]10/10[/h1]

2017 is off to a great start [i](even though it released in very late 2016 shhh)[/i] with the release of [b]Shantae: Half-Genie Hero[/b], and let me tell you, it was worth the wait.  I was so excited for this game, I had to buy the steam version even though I already backed the game, because I just couldn't wait for my copy to arrive. 

Being in development for for nearly four years after a sucessful Kickstarter isn't always good, and I think we were all worried about a repeat of a certain blue helmeted robot boy's mistakes. Happily though, Wayforward has delivered in spades. Even though it's only January, I can already tell this is going to be one of my favorites, if not definitive favorite.

Let's go over a few of Shantae's merits, if I may:
[list]
[*]The controls are as tight as you could ever want. Never once did I feel as if I messed up ro died because things were out of my control. 
[*]The music is astounding. Wayforward always does good soundtracks, but they've gone above and beyond for this. It even has it's own single "Dance Through the Danger". The first time a Shantae game has had a voiced song, and it's absolutely wonderful. I've been listening to it all week.
[*]The art design is beautiful.  The colors and lighting will make sweet, tender love to your eyeballs.
[/list]

Demerits? I can't really think of any. There are some things I'd have liked that aren't there, but nothing that takes away from the experience. 
[list]
[*]The first two games, the original and Risky's Revenge, had sprawling overworlds between dungeons, and while I really liked those and kind of miss them, I can see why they were removed from this game. The dungeons here are the focus, and I think they're stronger for getting the full spotlight.
[*]The game is very short. Spent about 8 hours on my first playthrough, but I enjoyed those 8 hours so much, I immediately tried to speedrun the game on 'Hero Mode' right after finishing, so replay value is high.
[*]I thought the dificulty was absolutely perfect. Challenging at the right times, and with simple portions as breathers. Some people may find it a little easy, though.
[/list]

29178472.review:
[h1]My first jump into Shantae: Half-Genie Hero[/h1]

This felt magical again! Like "Risky Boots Revenge" - the first Shantae game I played. Transformations are back, the graphics feel more HD (the previous games were made for the Nintendo DS and thus had a way smaller resolution), and familiar faces in every direction.

Stages are set up "Select Screen" style again. I preferred the way they did it in Risky Boots Revenge - the world map I mean - and thought it was a downgrade to the game world as a whole when it went from that to a simple stage select in The Pirate's Curse - which they kept for this. It's not the worst thing in the world though.

The puzzles weren't hard until the final level. Most of the stages weren't set up with puzzles.  There were some here and there (avoiding laser beams, climbing a maze before time is up, the entire final level) but most levels were based around exploration or simple advancement from point A to B through a horde of enemies.

A lot of the transformations completely outclassed other transformations. I enjoyed using them anyway - and I felt a bit more lenient about there being forms that were less useful when I found out some of them were just tossed in as extra rewards for the players to enjoy.

While the graphics themselves were enhanced the animations for the characters seemed a little less amped than the previous games in the series. I mean I still enjoyed them and they still came to a point I feel keeps WayForward of the "We care about the animation quality" mentality, but they were clearly a little less ambitious than previous games on that specific detail. There's only one dance animation for example when everybody was amazed at her dancing in [i]Risky Boots' Revenge[/i]. I can totally understand [i]why[/i] though: they added several times more transformations so waiting for a cycle of 20 dances to roll through would have been unintuitive and probably aggravating after a bit.

[h1]Pet Peeves[/h1]
[list]
[*]There weren't many levels. At the end I felt like the game could have gone on another few hours. The game length on my first play through - which included a lot of fooling around, some gem grinding, and a decent amount of backtracking for 100% completion - was roughly about 10-11 hours. So the game holds up in length, but the stages don't feel numerous - especially after finding out two of the levels were added as Kickstarter rewards.
[*]The final stage was another spikes-and-pitfall level that made the game hard for the wrong reason. To be fair sometimes the only reason the challenging parts [i]are[/i] challenging is because they can be cheap, but in Shantae's series it's always shooting itself in its own foot since it throws away the point of spending extra hours finding more health. I'd have preferred more numerous enemies and stronger enemies over spikes and pitfalls again; something to give the health bar some stress in [i]combat[/i].
[*]Holly, [spoiler]a character that seemed centered on an  interesting rival-genie arc, is resolved very quickly. She has a decent buildup to what ultimately just concludes and disappears into thin air all of a sudden. I think she would have offered something new to the universe as an rival character even if only for one game before the rivalry were concluded, but it ended so fast it could easily have been skipped entirely.[/spoiler]
 [/list]

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
I played with the transformations like toys. I [u]love[/u] the transformations. I did what I could to try and beat every stage I reasonably could as each transformation (which I'm still in the middle of doing). Ultimately I feel the transformations are what make a Shantae game a Shantae game. 
I feel like the game lost [i]something[/i] about it that was there in the earlier games but I can't put my finger on it. It also added more [i]"something else"[/i]. It still feels like a Shantae game. Just somehow with a little more and a little less "something". I really could have seen it being longer but despite  feeling as though I blazed through it they did pack content into this game. I think it feels slightly unfinished because a lot of this content can't be used effectively.

29152284.review:
This is for me a difficult game to review – this was the first game I ever kickstarted back in the misty past of 2013, and I never believed for a moment that a 2D platformer would take three and a half years to materialise. With such a long time in development, backers’ expectations were high – Wayforward have a pedigree, and I’ve enjoyed every game they’ve ever produced. The Shantae games in particular are blessed with excellent production values, level design and waifus that are frankly off the hook.

It’s clear to me that those years in development were not spent productively. I completed the game with 100% items in under six hours, and I’m fairly certain that it could easily be completed in half that. Of course length is not necessarily an indication of quality, as ur mum will attest – but the levels here are short and linear, so much so that there is no map screen. Some levels don’t even feel finished, and considering the small number of them and the extensive development time that’s pretty piss poor. Most of the levels need to be revisited to find items crucial for advancing the story, which is a transparent way of lengthening the dismal play time. Backtracking is of course a metroidvania staple, but here it feels forced and unnecessary.

In terms of abilities, transformations are back after an absence in Pirate’s Curse. There are certainly a wealth of transformations compared to previous games (each beautifully rendered and animated), but some of them barely have anything to do, and there’s a surprising degree of redundancy. The level design also feels very flabby and under baked – certain abilities borderline break the game at the point they can be acquired, like the bat that allows you to pretty much skip half the desert level.

Outside of the amazing visuals and music (and they really are best in class), Half Genie Hero is entirely inferior to Pirate’s Curse, and if I’m being honest it doesn’t even hold up particularly favourably to Risky’s Revenge. Looking at Half Genie Hero in a vacuum, it’s a fun little platformer, and I can’t deny I enjoyed my (short) time with it - however, compared to both its immediate predecessor and the stiff competition in the metroidvania market on Steam, it just isn’t worth the fifteen quid.

Oh boy. As someone who has an old history with platformers ranging from my first Gameboy Advance SP with Super Mario Advance all the way to obscure cartoon platformers like Fairly Odd Parents Clash with the Anti-World, this game was one blast to the past.

Half-Genie Hero is one of the best 2d platformers in recent history. It requires a lot of backtracking to previous areas, which I personally enjoy, to gain extra abilities and story related items. The great part of this is the areas change visually after the first time you visit it. Sometimes good, sometimes bad(no more counterfeit mermaids). Unfortunately, it's a short game. I managed to finish up the main game within a couple of hours and achievement hunting isn't really hard or too time consuming either.

The visuals and soundtrack are absolutely beautiful. I couldn't help but get immersed into the game whenever I started it up and an hour or 2 would fly by. Whenever I would have to go back to Tuki I would always pick Tassel Tower just for the music.

The gameplay is great. Very smooth handing and fun interactions with enemies and environment. My only complaint would be the handling of switching between dances. I feel it would've been nice to transform in between animal forms instead of going back to Shantae for a QoL improvement. But it is extremely minor anyways.

tl:dr Extremely fun world that is visually and euphonically pleasing. If you're into platformers you'll enjoy this one. If you don't, you ceratinlly will after this one.

29138191.review:
Shantae:  Half-Genie Hero is a competent platformer, but it gets too many things wrong for me to recommend it.  There are 6 stages in all, including the final stage which holds no secrets and another stage that holds only a couple that you'll visit maybe three times.  As you play, you accumulate more abilities and forms for Shantae which enable you to visit previously inaccessible areas and acquire more items and powerups.  But because the final stage has no secrets and another one has only a couple, you'll spend most of the game visiting the same 4 stages repeatedly.  To pad the length of the game and make up for a lack of content, you are occasionally given strange, lengthy fetch quests to complete to advance the story.

I'll be blunt:  Half Genie Hero doesn't feel like a complete game.  It isn't just the lack of stages.  A few of the transformations--like bat and spider--have no real part to play in the game.  You use them a couple of times to collect optional items and nothing else.  Half Genie Hero was funded on Kickstarter and I suspect the developer may have hoped to be funded for more stages that would make use of things like the bat and spider transformations.  And unlike a traditional metroidvania game, there is really no variety or sequence breaking to be had.  You either have the right upgrade or you don't.  And since the game is so small, there really isn't any sense of progression.

The game starts out at an average difficulty, but once you start buying some of the items in the shop and upgrading your life the difficulty soon vanishes.  You'll have so much health and take so little damage from attacks that you can literally just walk through normal enemies.  You can even buy an invincibility spell which further reduces the challenge.  There are a couple of places where the difficult absolutely skyrockets.  One is an area where you must climb quickly to avoid instant death, and another consists of a long path of one-hit kill spikes that you must fly through with extremely awkward controls.  It's like the developers struggled to balance the difficulty and then decided they needed some areas with serious challenge.

I really like the style of the game and its characters, but the game just doesn't live up to its potential and I can't recommend it.  If you want a platformer, grab Shovel Knight or Freedom Planet instead.  If you'd like to play a game specifically like Castlevania, I'd recommend Valdis Story.  If you like games like the classic Metroid (or just good games in general) check out Axiom Verge.  If you're set on playing Shantae because it looks interesting, I'd recommend checking out the previous game in the series instead.

29132964.review:
Kickstarter Backer.

Бэкал эту игру без особых надежд, так как ранее в Shantae не играл. Заинтересовался чем..? Красавицей героиней конечно :) Обнадеживало также то что у WayForward руки растут из нужного места. Бэкнул и забыл. А тут игра вышла.

И это получилась весьма неплохая игра! Я однозначно не чувствую себя обманутым, как это было с Майти9. Всё, что я ожидал, я получил:

* Очень мимимишная рисовка, красиво нарисованные персонажи, все многочисленные девченки в игре радуют глаз. Живенькие анимации, всё прям сочно-отлично
* Хороший саундтрек. Не то чтоб прям шедевр аля Furi, что можно в плейлист без стыда добавлять, но отлично идёт с игрой.
* Сюжет есть. Ничего такого, но юморок присутствует и он приятен.
* Неплохой 2д платформер. Нечего сказать, игра не особо сложная (хотя последний уровень - неприятный неожиданный скачок сложности), управляется хорошо.
* Довольно много серектов, находить которые было правда интересно. Ну и успешное нахождение всего делает героиню настоящим нагибатором, и далее можно по уровням просто гулять сметая все на своём пути

Спорное:
* Чтобы собрать секреты вам придётся неоднократно посещать одни и те же места. Некоторые секреты необходимы для прохождения игры. К счастью чем дальше, тем проще перемещаться по пройденным уровням - у вас появляются все более мобильные формы, да и боссов, мешавших вам при изначальнои прохождении уровня там уже нет.
* Иногда возникает ощущение что левел дизайнеры не предусмотрели то что игрок догадается использовать некоторые формы на некоторых уровнях. По началу кажется что даже первая форма (обезьяна) уже ломает левел дизайн, но потом я умудрился пропустить пару типа сложных платформинговых кусков полностью. Почему это не недостаток? Потому что когда до этого допираешь, чувствуешь себя невероятно умным, и это приятно %)

Из недостатков:
* Плохо продуманная система покупаемых апгрейдов - лучше бы их все запрятали по секретам. Дело в том что поначалу кристаллов ни на что не хватает, а потом внезапно для себя открываешь парочку способов зарабатывать их из воздуха не двигаясь с места и скупаешь все апгрейды, что конечно же снижает сложность игры в некоторых местах
* Из той же оперы - плохо продумана и сбалансирована магия. Её можно покупать, но большинство заклинаний бесполезны, плюс покупаешь кота в мешке. Из самого казалось бы отстойного заклилания вырастает самое полезное, с которым я ходил всю игру, а из самого казалось бы лучшего - полное фуфло.

29130088.review: I am confused as to what went wrong. Looking back at the previous installations of this series, all that needed some refinement was the minimap and maybe enemy combat. However, Way Forward tries to solve the navigation issues by making all levels linear, completely debilitating a lot of the established core design patterns, and we can see the consequences of this: the game has a mere six levels, yet there are eight transformation abilities, each of which can be further upgraded. The game's world is too small to bring all these abilities to life in a meaningful manner. What follows is the tedious kind of backtracking: Revisiting previous levels to find that one block you could not previously break, that one spot you could not previously climb, that one platform you could not previously reach, all while traversing exhausted content that has lost its meaning by the time you come back with your bag full of upgrades that allow you to fly past everything, just so you can get some thing using some other thing you just got, which, afterwards, you won't be using again, except maybe once in some later puzzle, deliberately designed to make you use the thing, all in order to feign the presence of meaningful choice; but there is none. This design decision spawns further problems, but I'll refrain from emphasizing. By reducing the world to linear levels selected from one central screen, Way Forward has placed an obstacle before themselves that they could not deal with.

29100468.review:
I saw the first trailer for this game approximately one year ago, long after the kickstarter campaign had finished.

I deeply regret not having been a part of crowdfunding this amazing game.

As a gamer well into my 30s, I absolutely adore retro-style platformers; they inspire memories of sitting around the couch with friends trying to get past the Gutsman level in Megaman. Truth be told, I hand't been this excited or looking forward to a game like it since the release of Ori and the Blind Forest.

I was blown away by the fluid, gorgeous hand-drawn animation style, the music was upbeat and perky, and the gameplay made for a classic metroidvania approach that never felt repetitive. 

My only quip with the game is I felt it was a little too short (given its approximate 7-hour initial runthrough), feeling it could have expanded so much more, but overall a very fun experience.

If you're having second doubts about buying this game, don't. It's very much worth the price tag, delivering every promise it every made during its funding and then some.

I can only hope there will be more Shantae games in the forseeable future.

Cheers.

29085468.review:
A great addition to the Shantae line of games that have become big favorites of mine. To start off, 2D animation amongst 3D shaded backgrounds looks sharp! I was a little surprised at first, because I had played Shantae so much in it's pixel art form, but this new style WayForward has adopted for the series is fantastic and I got used to it fairly quickly. That also including the control scheme which is very snappy and responsive! Shantae has become a living realtime cartoon and it is a major factor that I'm so glad the series now has.

Major and minor characters are back including Bolo, Uncle Mimic and Rottytops and they all have great dialogue and look great in the new style. The character interactions and text are all very funny, even including some fun unexpected moments where the characters will speak automatically, used a bit more here than in Pirate's Curse. I also really like how townsfolk give you hints and small clues, which comes in handy for dummies like me in those moments where I'm stupid and can't put 2 and 2 together.

Music is great as always, Jake Kaufman bringin' it down with more sick remixes of Scuttle town and Burning Town. The new song sung by Shantae (Cristina Vee) is awesome when you first hear it on Main Street. Absolutely a major factor that makes the game stand out and goes along great with it. Though I will say I take more of a liking to Pirate Curse's tracks, these orchestral songs are great and are very dance worthy.

The transformations are back from Shantae's earlier games, being staple powerups. They are used awesomely in this game! Very quick to transform and each stage uses different transformations for key areas to find secrets and other essestial items for achievement hunters and casuals alike. For Pirate's Curse of course, I did like how snappy and fast it was to use the pirate items for the corresponding buttons, but each key feature of the chosen transformation helps out greatly in areas, not just to get around the level, but also to find secrets. And hey, it's all worth it just to see Shantae dance again!

Oh man, the bosses are pretty good too this time around. They all have some cool attack patterns and look great all while the kickin' battle them is blasting from your headphones. They're all varied and some do bring out great fun. Whoever thought up that rad giant mermaid needs a big ol' smooch.

If I had to bring up any cons at all or stuff that just irked me personally, there's nothing that kept me from enjoying the game majorly. But the story is a biiiiit more straight forward this time around, and each world is sort of broken down into tiny subplots that don't really show up again, such as with Holly Lingerbean, the new kid on the block who's sort of just kicked out in a few minutes. But the small stories are essential for getting items back into the main plot.

Some characters also felt kinda weird in this game, there's not a lot of ongoing character development carried on from past games. Risky in Pirate's Curse was Shantae's arch nemesis doin evil stuff as always,  but when the pair had to work together, she became a sort of hothead with a short temper while she worked with the good guys compared to Shantae's upbeat goofiness. She also came with a backstory where she used to have a powerful master. Here's she's just kind of the generic main baddie. Don't get me wrong, I know they kinda want the games to be accessible in any order, but for me it was just kind of a shame to see characters who have been sorta fleshed out in other games back to their plain old selves. Though it was kinda just a thing for me with Risky upfront.

Something I noticed was that some aspects can make the game feel too easy, flight abilities can have you skip entire sections of levels, you can rack up gems like nobody's business though who's ever complained about free coinage?? And with enough gems, armor and hearts, getting hit every once in a while is really no problem.

But hey, I love Shantae, and overall, this is a dang fun Shantae game with lots of great powerups, funny writing, a sweet new artstyle once again and a great soundtrack. It's just that compared to Pirate's Curse, it felt a bit more compact. While I would rate that game my favorite in the series, trust me, Shantae Half-Genie Hero is definetely my second. A great effort to everyone at WayForward and another definite step in the right direction. Can't wait to see that future character DLC!

29079480.review:
So far, really enjoying the game. It's bright, colorful and is super smooth with it's tweened animations. Really impressive art and animation. 
I'm less into the 3D backgrounds, they contrast too harshly with the character art, they work for the most part. 

Gameplay is nice, it's a mix between Risky's Revenge and Pirate's Curse, you get the transformations of the 2nd game and the faster gameplay of the third game....Buuuut it's levels are not as large or have the depth of the previous games. They feel simple and easy. Maybe this changes a bit more later? I'm not sure yet. One thing that's a bit frustrating so far is there's a lot of weird backtracking. 
Weird as in, you'll beat level, go back to the level with a new power to get some more stuff right? But you won't have the ability to get through a wall...So you can only collect 2/5 items required to progress ...till you go further down the level, talk to an NPC who gives it to you making you walk back what you JUST did....twice. As said earlier, levels aren't massive so it's not a huge deal but it's just weird to make you run back right away. 

Overall, so far I think Pirate's Curse is a better game. But this is a game worth getting all the same. Lot of charm and polish. 
One thing is for sure, despite Mighty No. 09 getting all the hype and all the money this game managed to do more with less. It plays better, looks VASTLY better, is far more optimized and has all the charm and character you'd expect from Way Forward.

29078416.review:
This game is a great step forward for the series, and the previous entry was already pretty good. The new semi-3D graphics look awesome and are put to great use. Shantae gets a lot of forms and they all feel more organic and useful than they did in Risky's Revenge (probably thanks to the level design). Zelda-dungeons have been replaced with more megaman-style linear levels, which you could go either way on; my feeling is that the levels are much more fun and tightly-paced, and they have much better setpieces.

There is a lot of mandatory backtracking, but it's not any worse than the previous games (especially if you get the warp dance). Usually by the time it wants you to return to a level a few new enemies have been added you have new forms to find hidden items in it.

The only criticism I can think of is that the story is kinda all-over-the-place. Instead of pursuing an overarching "gather X plot coupons" goal you jump back and forth between unrelated plotlines that each last one level, while occasionally fetching an item for your uncle's machine from a previous level. But it still has fun characters and cute dialog, so it's ok.

29078149.review:
It's been a while since I played a platformer worth it's salt.  Thankfully, I decided to purchase Shantae: Half-Genie Hero entirely on a whim.  I hadn't heard about the kickstarter otherwise there's a strong chance I would have backed it.  I've since rectified that mistake and bought the game when Steam suggested it to me.

Shantae is a game with great artwork, and incredibly catchy sound track, and a plethora of unlocks to get you through your quest.  The levels are designed incredibly well which is great since you'll be revisting them multiple times to get any new items you can find as the game progresses.  Bosses are humorous, animated well, and sometimes challenging.  

Shantae isn't without it's flaws, though those are incredibly minor.  Really.  While the next bit sounds like a lot, I'm being incredibly nit-picky.  A few animation glitches occur during the opening sequence when Shantae first gets out of bed and in the mid-level save sequence.  Jumping can be a bit stiff but if you've played enough platforming games, you can quickly adapt.  

One of the coolest parts of Shantae is also one of the most disappointing parts.  On your first go around in a level, you'll see many details that bring the stage to life.  These are usually tied to the story of the level and once you clear it, they go away.  Future vists see the level altered slightly to reflect what you've already accomplished.  For example, in the second level, a number of fair maidens are being carted away in a factory.  Once the issue is resolved, the women are obviously gone seeing how you saved them, but it kind of ruins the atmosphere a little.

Again, nitpicking and critiqueing classical art.  Shantae is worth a playthrough.  It's a tad on the short end but don't let that detract from the quality of the game you get.  

TL:DR If you're still pissed at Mighty No. 9 and need a platformer to scratch the itch that disaster promised, then Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is here to fix you right up.

29067109.review:
Were you disapointed by Mighty Number 9?  Well look no further then Shantae: Half-Genie Hero for an example of how both kick starters and platformers can be done well.  I didn't much care for the original Shantae, and thought Risky's Revenge was only just okay.  I did love Pirate's Curse, but when I heard this Shantae was going back more to its roots with the dance transformations I admit to having been concerned.  I was also worried about the art style, which looked much more cartoony then the previous games, as well as all the 3d elements which felt unnecessary in a 2d platformer.

I'm VERY happy to say all my fears were unfounded.  This game is FANTASTIC.  You can really tell these developers are learning from each of their releases, with each one taking the best of the previous games, dropping the bits that no one cared for, and then just further expanding and refining everything people liked.  S:HGH has the speed and creativity of Pirates curse, while making the transformations finally into something fun, something I looked forward to getting.  The music is as fantastic as ever, while the art, while admittedly more cartoony, looks incredible and really feels like it fits.  Even the 3d is used in just the right proportions such that it actually feels like it adds instead of takes away from the experience.

Wayforward has officially gone from a little developer I wanted to see succeed, to one whose legitimately earned my trust and support going forward through top notch quality content that.  If you like platformers at ALL, you owe it to yourself to give this game a chance.  If you didn't like Pirates Curse, I'm not sure this game will change your mind, but if you felt the original and Risky's Revenge were over hyped, I strongly urge you to give this one a chance.

- The dialogue and character interactions are pretty funny.

CONS:

- I missed the dungeons that were in previous Shantae games. The levels in 1/2 Genie Hero are more similar to Megaman stages.

Way Forward should have fixed this bug a while ago, but I guess over half a year just wasn't enough time to fix it.

It's a good game, you should consider getting it. There will also be more characters added that will drastically change (or so we're told) how you play the game (*Edited 8-10-17* The DLC characters are only free if you backed the kickstarter, how disappointing.)

29063106.review:
A few years ago, I was browsing the virtual console games on 3DS and found a game called Shantae, which was originally for Gameboy Color. I played it and found it clunky, but the characters and world were very charming, so I picked up the next game. Risky's Revenge was solid and improved a lot of the gameplay, and I became a bit excited when I heard that Shantae and the Pirate's Curse was coming out. Shantae and the Pirate's Curse was absolutely one of the best games I've ever played, so when I found the option to kickstart a new entry to this series which I've become really fond of, I absolutely did.

And it delivered.

Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is an incredibly solid entry into the Shantae series. While the pixel art of the previous games was amazing, I really do like this new art style, and I'm a sucker for 3D backgrounds with 2D characters. The game is really pretty, keeps up with the silly quirky story and characters I've come to love, has great platforming, and is absolutely a worthwhile sequel.

The game improves upon a few things from previous entries. One of the biggest problems in the first two Shantae games was how long transformations took for the amount of times you needed to use them. Transformation dances took a LONG time, and really took you out of the moment. To be completely honest, the best part of Pirate's Curse was how there were no transformation dances. The Metroid-style pirate items they used as a replacement made the action smoother and more enjoyable. Half-Genie Hero did take a page from this to an extent, and made transforming MUCH easier and quicker, especially with the optional Metronome item that increases the speed further, but the best thing they did was triple the amount of dances Shantae could perform. This gives the player many options on how to tackle a puzzle, and while I think some could have been utilized further than they were, I really appreciate having so many creatures to transform into! I really feel like they hit the sweet spot of Shantae having her signature transformations while keeping the gameplay smooth.

In terms of music, Half-Genie Hero has definitely gone more electronic than its predecessors, but in a good way. It's very lively and really gets your heart pumping. It makes you feel good to play while listening to it. I think good music is a very important component to making a game enjoyable, and the Shantae series has always delivered on this. I love the track for Mermaid Falls especially!

There are a few negatives, of course. I feel that some of the unlockable items are utterly useless except for achievements (a lot are just attacks for your animal forms, which generally are very weak and serve little purpose). There are also times where I would get stuck in an area after a puzzle and need to exit the entire level just to get out of that room, or going into a new room would totally screw up my camera requiring exiting the level as well. I also really miss dungeons, which were a Shantae staple up to this point, but the new level-based design really wouldn't have allowed for them the same way, so I can give them a pass on that.

In terms of gray areas, things that some people might like and some people won't: There is a LOT of backtracking through levels, and its really hard to avoid some enemy attacks. You're going to get hit and need items to restore your health. Both of these are really common in all Shantae games though, so they're just kind of expected at this point. I didn't mind backtracking in this game as much as games like Pirate's Curse or Risky's Revenge, though, where you have to go back through entire dungeons to find stuff you might have missed. I also really don't like the TOTALLY CAPS YELLOW TEXT that appears in a lot of dialogue. I just feel it shows up way too often, but it's really not a dealbreaker to a lot of people.

Overall, I think I would still consider Pirate's Curse to be the better game. I think its puzzles, bosses, and levels were more fun, and it had a really good story as well as some interesting bombshells, whereas Half-Genie Hero's story falls a little flat as far as these games go. That said, Half-Genie Hero is no slouch, and has been an overall great game that I had a really good time playing.

Whether you're a fan of the series or just want to try it out, I recommend Shantae: Half-Genie Hero as a very solid platformer with wonderful visuals and music, and I recommend checking out the other games in the series if you can!

CONS:

The controls, level design and gameplay are all highly polished, ensuring that it isn't too punishing for platformer newbies while there are enough secrets and challenges for more serious players to complete. However, like its previous installments, the game suffers from its short length and limited replay value.

Overall, I rate "Shantae: Half-Genie Hero" as one of the best platformers released in 2016. The game is definitely worth full price on its own, but do note that several DLC are already in development to add additional costumes for Shantae and new campaigns where you can play as Risky, Rottytops, Sky and Bolo. I'd recommend keeping an eye out for new game updates this 2017.

29020432.review:
Shantae: Half-Genie Hero была игрой, выхода которой я ждал с нетерпением, и приобрел немедленно в день релиза. Какая же она? 

Первым делом, стоит отметить визуальную и музыкальную составляющие, к которым сложно придраться: красочная картинка, милые спрайты персонажей, гладкая анимация, одним словом, игра - загляденье. Переход в HD-эпоху явно пошел Шантей на пользу. Музыка же, как и всегда, замечательная, включая заглавную вокальную тему.
В плане геймплея игра не претерпела практически никаких изменений, за тем только исключением, что открытый мир и традиционные для серии подземелья исчезли, уступив место системе уровней, как в обычном платформере. Не считаю это существенным недостатком, даже наоборот, это существенно облегчает бэктрекинг (которым в игре, как и раньше, придется заниматься много). В распоряжении игрока множество облегчающих жизнь магических предметов (порой даже слишком облегчающих, вплоть до откровенного читерства), вследствие чего пройти игру не составляет большого труда.

А вот действительно покритиковать игру хотелось бы за следующие моменты:
1) Игра довольно короткая и оставляет впечатление некой незавершенности. Особенно заметно это на сюжете, который страдает разрозненностью и чрезмерной спешкой событий, а также на персонажах, которые практически никак себя не проявляют и не развиваются. Я очень надеюсь, что дело поправят DLC с играбельными Риски и друзьями Шантей, но пока имеем что имеем.
2) Танцевальные трансформации Шантей вернулись, и на сей раз их больше, чем когда-либо! С одной стороны это прекрасно, но с другой порождает новую проблему: половина из них являются слишком ситуативными и практически бесполезными за пределами их основной функции (что, в основном, является добычей спрятанных предметов). Складывается впечатление, что у разработчиков не хватило идей для грамотного осуществления данного концепта.
3) Моя личная претензия, но черт возьми, WayForward, всего одно танцевальное движение для Шантей? Серьезно? У вас был концепт с разными танцами, неужели сложно было сделать пару лишних анимаций? >_<

Кое-что о багах: случались порой незначительные графические глюки с лицевой анимацией персонажей, а еще пару раз игра спавнила меня после смерти где-то за экраном без возможности выбраться. Ничего смертельного, впрочем, на игре это практически не сказывается.

Несмотря на все это, игрой я остался очень доволен, рекомендую к ознакомлению и с нетерпением жду продолжения банкета.

Do not go into this game expecting a metroidvania - this is not what you will find. However, it's still a fun platformer with some exploration elements. The game is really well polished and loves to show off what it does best.

Pros:
- Excellent graphics/animations, and something I would love to see more of in 2D games
- Amazing soundtrack
- Solid controls
- Interesting levels with some good variety
- Hilarious writing, especially with Hypno Baron and Squid Baron

Cons:
- Linear level design loses some of the good qualities the older games had.
- Not difficult to get through at all. The game hands out too much money, or makes important upgrades to your hair too cheap.
- Forced backtracking doesn't feel natural.
- The story had no real payoff. It was quite generic and wasn't as memorable as The Pirate's Curse.

28990647.review:
It's no secret I love the Shantae series, and I've been waiting for this game to come out since I seen the kickstarter page. Now its out and it time to see if it was worth the wait. 

Story: Shantae Half-Genie Hero take place after the events of Shantae Pirate's Curse but if you haven't played it don't worry. The game stand on it own. 
Shantae is the guardian genie of the town and spend her days solving problems and stopping pirates. After a strange dream followed by a pirate attack, Shantae set off again to save her town.

The story is straight forward. Not as much character development as previous games, but it felt like a good game for new players to jump onto the franchise.

Gameplay: Shantae can jump and hair whip her opponents into submission. As a Genie she can dance and transform into various creatures to gain access to new areas. You can buy upgrades for Shantae hair whip at the item shop and also buy magic spells. The magic spells have always seem to break the game. If you're a completionist  than you're going to upgrade all your magic and with magic that can make you invulnerable, well let just say some bosses become a cake walk. But they give you option in the menu to disable any upgrade if you feel the game is too easy.

Final Comment: Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is a good game for new players to start at, and veterans will be glad to see the return of loved characters. If you like platformers than Shantae: Half-Genie will grant one of your wishes.

Manages to be a great game despite being entirely different from its predecessors. Transformations, while interesting and numerous, are just not as interesting as the gear used in Pirate's Curse, with most ending up very situational (I can count the number of times I used spider shantae on one hand, and I 100%ed the game). Despite this, the game seems to use the premise of dance-transformations the best of all previous titles, and is honestly a lot of fun to play through.

Risky Boots DLC could easily fix these problems, but it's not out yet.

If you're looking to get into the Shantae series, I would still recommend Pirate's Curse, but if you crave more, then this game won't disappoint. The story is well-written and entertaining in each game, but the overarching plot isn't too serious, so playing out of order won't hurt anyone.

PS: This game does not feature the best girl, squidsmith, and thusly is complete garbage. Bring her back right now, wayforward!

28982396.review:
如果你是愛好橫向卷軸動作冒險遊戲的玩家，或多或少應該有聽過《Shantae》吧？該系列最早於 2002 年就在 Gameboy Color 平台發行初代作品《Shantae》，不過因為名氣不如當年依舊人氣很旺的遊戲系列《Rockman》與《Castlevania》而默默無名，直到 2014 年推出第三部作品《Shantae and the Pirate's Curse》才迅速竄紅，成為小有名氣的遊戲系列。這次要介紹的《Shantae: Half-Genie Hero》是系列作第四部作品，製作團隊 WayForward 決定將其 HD 高畫質化，換下懷舊像素畫風，換上動感十足的賽璐璐卡通風格，背景也從 2D 平面改為混合 3D 建模的半立體背景，當筆者進入遊戲挑戰第一關卡時，馬上就被畫面表現上的全面進化給深深吸引，沉溺於中東異國風味濃厚的魔法國度中流連忘返。

鑒於前作《Shantae and the Pirate's Curse》近乎完美的出色表現，本作是否得以保持優良傳統再創佳績呢？答案是肯定的，在這五小時毫無冷場的遊戲過程中，玩家會在六大世界來回穿梭，過關斬將同時破解謎題，取得新能力後回到其他區域尋找重要任務道具，最後挑戰難易拿捏適中的最終頭目，為拯救世界的冒險旅程劃下句點。較為可惜的是，後期關卡設計較為單調，探索區域大幅減少就算了，雖不奢望會有《Rockman》系列經典的八大頭目戰，但最後一關實在是精簡到極致，越過一路上的致命陷阱，耗時不到十分鐘直接進入頭目戰，或許是因為資金燃燒得差不多了，才會在為作品收尾時如此草草了事吧？


隨著故事進行，玩家會有足夠資金購買強化自身傷害的聖物，當然也能在探索期間發現新的舞蹈，我們可以明顯感受到桑塔不斷提升戰鬥能力，關卡難度卻保持在最初水準，除非完全不購買或使用強化道具進行遊戲，本作可以說是不管是誰都能輕易通關的動作遊戲。換句話說，熱愛挑戰自我的硬核玩家可以挑戰在最短時間通關或無傷擊敗頭目，僅想體驗遊戲樂趣的休閒玩家會在強化道具的輔助之下沒有壓力的通關遊戲，同時造福兩大玩家族群，達成一舉數得的結果，同時也是《Shantae: Half-Genie Hero》好評不斷的理由之一。


撇去動作冒險遊戲基本操作【攻擊】和【跳躍】不看，《Shantae: Half-Genie Hero》最具特色的原創系統是女主角〝桑塔〞可以通過舞蹈幻化為猴子、螃蟹、大象、蝙蝠等動物，並且利用動物的特殊能力突破萬難。舉例來說，玩家第一個取得的猴子舞蹈能讓你變成猴子，猴子不僅擁有跳躍能力加成，使你跳得更高更遠之外，還附加爬牆效果，除了長滿尖刺陷阱的牆面，絕大多數的場所都能靠著猴子型態通過；想要潛入藏著重要道具的海洋世界？先決條件是取得螃蟹或美人魚舞蹈，兩者雖然皆是用於海底移動的舞蹈，但美人魚型態擁有較佳的機動性與攻擊力，同時還可以噴出足以擊碎大石的泡沫開闢新的道路。

動物舞蹈通常運用在闖關過程而非攻略頭目，幾乎沒有任何頭目是透過動物能力擊破，製作團隊似乎也沒有打算設計出專為動物舞蹈攻略的頭目，導致此項能力在大多時間淪為趕路工具，然而有些用途較為狹隘的動物舞蹈如老鼠舞蹈、蜘蛛舞蹈、蝙蝠舞蹈，感覺是為了放置相對應謎題才特別加入的舞蹈，破解特定謎題之後，這些舞蹈立馬變為無用武之處的雞肋功能。反觀猴子和人面鳥舞蹈萬用到不行，眼前有麻煩的跳躍平台？沒關係，變成猴子爬牆越過去就好！碰到隨著時間消失的移動平台？超簡單，變成人面鳥飛過去直接到終點！如果平均分配運用各種舞蹈的謎題，絕對可以有效提升它們的價值。


《Shantae: Half-Genie Hero》是款難以找出缺點的作品，如果硬要指出缺點的話，大概就是耐玩度比起前作《Shantae and the Pirate's Curse》遜色不少，關卡豐富性、頭目戰設定、以及劇情深度皆有待加強，但這些都是跟前作相互比較硬擠出來的缺點，並不代表其遊戲內容存在著嚴重影響到體驗的缺陷。總而言之，要稱本作為 2016 年最佳橫向卷軸動作冒險遊戲一點也不為過，比起年初令人失望透頂的半調子情懷鉅作《Mighty No. 9》，同樣的建議售價，更少的募資金額，更棒的遊戲內容，相信大家知道以後要掏錢支持誰了吧？


優點：
+畫面全面 HD 高清化，跟舊時代像素畫風道別，迎接賽璐璐卡通風格。
+千變萬化，以萬變應萬變的動物舞蹈，想順利通關絕對需要此特殊能力。
+全程毫無冷場，探索區域、破解謎題、擊敗強敵，一氣呵成不拖泥帶水。
+募款資金少於某款遊戲三百多萬美金，成品素質卻屌打對方好幾條街。


缺點：
-後勁力道嚴重不足，明顯感受到後期關卡的區域豐富性遠不及前期關卡。


結論：人物設定精美，遊戲整體表現優異，就算透過原價購買也不吃虧。

28976775.review:
This game is worth the 20$ I spent. 

I'm a Huge fan of the new visuals. Shantae's model is adorable...well all the female characters are adorable both their models and illustrations. It's so clean, crisp, and very colorful. With this new style, details like facial expression are very easy to see on these new models. Every character looks amazing. The characters/items really standout from the background. So it doesn't matter if you are playing this on a teeny tiny screen or your 55" screen in the family room, it's going to look great. 

The game ran smoothly.Everything Shantae does looks good. Same goes for enemies. There were some hiccups, not like lag or anything but some blinks of color in spots of the screen. This could be fault with something in the game or something on my end.

The levels were well designed. Many of them seem to be designed for several ways of navigation up until end in the event you miss some transformation or moves hidden along the way. On the topic of transformations. I enjoyed all but one, the one I'd have to say it is nothing more than a joke. 

I found the levels to be moderately difficult and some small spots kind of hard. Part of me wishes most was hard but at the same time given the number of times I treked back and forth in levels, I think perhaps moderate is for the best. If you are into time trials be it just finishing as fast as possible, getting all unlocks, or going for 100%(buying all shop items) There levels are large enough that they take a good amount of memorization and creativity to navigate them as quickly/efficiently as possible.
This game also rewards those have keen eyes for finding things in the levels/taking the time to get them. I found the Mermaid level to be my favorite level. Lots of jumps, its really big. 28962269.review: Absolutely loved this game, the soundtrack is amazing and a fun and sometimes challenging platformer, if you are looking for a good old fashion platformer with a twist then this game is for you, a bunch of new features such as *SPOILERS* transformations and magical abilities that keeps the gameplay feeling fresh, even when previous levels have to be scoured through many times over.

28962226.review:
If you want to play this game because of the Metroidvania style of the previous games in the series, prepare to be disappointed. But not in a bad way, by any means. This game is something else rather, more of a cross between Megaman X  and old-school Castlevania.

Areas are broken up into fairly linear levels that must be re-played when you unlock more abilities in order to explore various branching paths previously unavailable to you on the first run. However, you're never forced to play any stage from beginning to end more than once, as you can get the ability to warp between all 3 parts of level and also drop out of the level at any time, keeping whatever new items you've grabbed. While it sounds a bit tedious to backtrack, the aforementioned warping plus the added mobility of your new transformation abilities really cut down on the time it takes to backtrack.

The story plays out like a day in the life of Shantae, with all the offbeat humor and cute babes intact from the rest of the series. It's nothing revolutionary, but it makes a lot of shout outs for longtime fans of the series, in addition to serving as a great introduction to the world of sequin land for those who haven't played Shantae before.

Overall, it's a fun game with loads of speedrunning potential. It would be apt to compare it to something like a theme park ride. A rather long wait for an ultimately short experience, but with theming and entertainment so good, I can't help but want to go again sometime later. Speaking of which, I'm looking forward to the upcoming DLC for Risky mode + Sky/Bolo/Rotty mode, which should further add replayability to this joyride of a game.

28961143.review:
一応実績全解除するまでやりました（タイムアタックの実績は過去作より少し判定が甘いようです）

まずシャンティと言えば可愛らしいドット絵のイメージだったので、個人的にはドット絵でなくなってしまったことが少し残念です。
代わりに高解像度にも耐えうる美麗なグラフィックになっており、2D横スクロールとして順当な進化をしたともいえますが、
従来のようなレトロゲーライクのドット絵アクションを期待していると肩透かしを食うでしょう。
立ち絵は前作よりもデフォルメが効いており、可愛らしさが増した反面、色っぽさは無くなっています。

ダンスによる変身、ショップでの魔法購入、魔法ゲージでの魔法の使用など、
基本的なシステムは前々作「Risky's Revenge」を踏襲していますが、
それぞれ独立したステージを探索するという点は前作「Pirate's Curse」のシステムと同じです。

難易度は過去作よりも更に控えめで、魔法やアイテムによるゴリ押しをしなくても、終盤までゲームーバーにならず進めるでしょう。
ヒントをくれるモブがいたり、町の人との会話でも次に何をするべきか推測できるので、行き詰まることもありません。
過去作と同様、終盤に1ミスでチェックポイントまで戻される所があるので、そこだけはストレスになるかもしれません。

日本語がおかしい部分が多々ありますが、それで話がわからなくなるような事はなく、ニュアンスの違いと言った程度です。
メタネタを使うキャラもいるぐらいなので些細な事です。

キャラ選択画面に「近日公開」と書かれた、シルエットからリスキーと思われるキャラが選択肢にあるのですが、
終盤ボスとして登場するリスキーが、前作「Pirate's Curse」でシャンティがやっていたアクションを使った攻撃をしてきますので、
もし彼女が操作キャラとして実装されれば前作のような操作感になるのではないかと思います。
そちらも楽しみです。

28960944.review:
To all the backers of Shantae: Half-Genie Hero, thank you for all of your support! I would have happily joined you had I known how awesome the Shantae series was, but I came late into the game, and it was only shortly after the campaign ended did I take the time to enjoy Risky's Revenge and The Pirate Curse. Playing those two games, I've come to expect a lot from this series in terms of its artstyle, soundtrack, and gameplay. Needless to say, this game has exceeded some of my expectations while underwhelming others.

[h1]The Artsyle[/h1]

Right away you can tell this game is beautifully drawn and the characters are well animated. The colours, the movement, and even the backgrounds are vibrant and beaming of life. I don't usually pay attention to backgrounds, but I can see how much time and attention has gone into them along with the smooth character animations.

[h1]The Soundtrack[/h1]

Although most of the music is rearranged and redone, the Shantae soundtrack continues to match the levels and the dialogue moods perfectly. None of the new music really stands out as super catchy and memorable, but when they are used for specific moments and levels, it composed well enough to immerse you into the situation.

[h1]The Gameplay[/h1]

As much as I love the aesthetics for this game, I feel like the gameplay has taken a stepback. A lot of long times fans come to expect a more Metroidvania kind of structure to the levels and worlds, and for me this more level select method is a better for backtracking. There were times in previous games where I just got lost easily and felt like some stages lost their importance after a while.

Thankfully the levels are all simply structured to have three stages each, along with a few obstacles you can't get past until you earn an animal transformation. I can see they wanted to focus on the use of them along with making the game more accessible to newcomers.

So while the puzzles and extra sections are a ton of fun to figure out in terms of using the right transformations and abilities, I feel like the selection of transformations was overwhelming. There were too many transformations that could have been consolidated into less animals with more abilities as opposed to one animal with one unique ability each. I get excited learning a new ability and this game didn't seem to reward my experience as much as I'd like because you barely ever get to use your new abilities that often except for maybe one or two situations that call for them.

[h1]Final Thoughts[/h1]

All in all though, I still had a ton of fun with this beautifully designed platformer. I patiently wait for the DLC that is already available for backers *shakes fist* and look forward to more of what WayForward can come up with in the future. 

I give this game a solid 7/10. The art, music, and levels are well crafted. Learning and using new abilities felt underwhelming when they were horribly underused, but the game makes up for some of these flaws for having a decent level of difficulty in puzzle solving and its exciting boss battles.

On top of all that, I know that Shantae stories are usually meant to be light hearted and on the Saturday Morning cartoon side, I still can't help but feel like there could have been more to it than what was presented. There were moments where the story could have had some strong themes elaborated on. [spoiler]I was severely disappointed that the evil Shantae section was over as soon as it started. Maybe a level being inside Shantae's heart or something would have been nice. Like a good challenge to rid the evil that she's been inflicted with, instead of just having all these characters monologue at her saying how much they care for her. That would have been better if it was a reward to a one time level in the game.[/spoiler]

But I digress. Gameplay is king in Shantae games and having the story skimped out on is not a huge loss since they're not usually known for their stories alone. All in all a fun and exciting game that is good for its length and what it offers. Replayability is debatable and more geared towards a speed run, but we shall see what gets add for DLC later on!

JAKE KAUFMAN'S MUSIC

Shantae's voice

I love Shantae and I love WayForward for making this amazing title happen. An amazing series with an amazing character, Shantae Half Genie Hero is a continuation of some of the best games I have played since the rest of the gaming industry went nuts on us.

9/10

28947131.review:
最早接触这个系列是从DSiWare开始的，基本上可以理解为短小精悍+难度适中的类银河战士/恶魔城游戏。这一作在很多地方做的更靠近普通的横版平台动作游戏，不过需要回到打过的关卡找剧情道具倒是依然保留了传统。游戏提供了哨子（返回大地图）和传送舞蹈（关卡内切换场景），找到需要的可以立马撤，所以收集任务并不算麻烦。
游戏的画面非常的出彩，无论是人物还是场景的描绘都非常细致，保证动作流畅不拖沓的同时还能看到很多有趣的细节，比如女主趴下的时候如果不动会像猫准备扑猎物一样盯住前方扭屁股。
游戏性来说，游戏总体难度不能算高，但确实还是有些挑战性的，比如一些需要速通和解谜的部分，战斗难度倒是出奇的低，一方面敌人确实弱点比较好找，另一方面能补血的东西真是太多了。
音乐非常带感，已经很久没听过这么带感的游戏音乐了，要是出原声就好了……
游戏长度比较短，初见全收集7-8个小时差不多，而且一旦上手了之后搞个速通啥的估计才是这个游戏的正确玩法。
总之，游戏很精致，操作手感保持了WayForward家一如既往的高水准，画风很偏日系的美式（？），玩起来很痛快而且不会纠结，就游戏综合素质和目前的全价来说打分给个9分没问题。

28924329.review:
Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is the fourth Shantae game in the series, and is a pretty good game overall.

The minute I started playing this, I was instantly blown away by the amazing graphics and catchy soundtrack the game had to offer. Unlike previous Shantae games, almost all the songs in the sountrack are not remixed and are completely new (one of them being Burning Town). The characters are humorous and lovable, just as usual.

In terms of gameplay, Half Genie Hero is a very fun and enjoyable experience. The platforming and quests aren't very difficult. The game itself isn't very difficult either; at most, something in a boss battle catches you off guard but when you try again it's simple. The game is very linear, and there are no dungeons or labyrinths unlike previous Shantae games. Despite these differences, the game is still extremely fun to play and I see it as WayForward trying a new, fresh approach to making a Shantae game. Half-Genie Hero still has its fair share of backtracking to collect secret items, though.

The only complaint I have about this game is the amount of content. It feels a bit short. The game also has a weaker plot structure compared to the other games. My first playthrough of the game, collecting everything, took me approximately eight hours. There are always the achievements, though, and you'll probably have to play the game some more if you want them all. The game is good, though, so no trouble. Also, additional downloadable content for Half-Genie Hero is scheduled to come out soon. It looks really interesting and will add more things to do in the game.

Overall, I would definitely recommend Half-Genie Hero to anyone who likes Shantae, platformers, or anyone who just wants to play a well-made game. The game has a bit of an arcade feel to it, kind of like Mega Man, and is very entertaining and simple to just pick up and play. While the game may seem short, extensions will be released in the near future. The game is definitely worth playing (especially multiple times) and I suggest picking it up and experiencing it yourself, too.

edit: a few soundtracks were remixed

28911937.review:
It's a Shantae game, in both the good ways and the bad ways.

The good ways are that Shantae looks and sounds better than ever, and that the characteristic good writing is present, along with all the characters you know and love(or love to hate).

The bad ways are in the sense that every Shantae game is, to some extent, experimental. Some aspects and mechanics recur, but every single game is made up of those "classic" elements mixed evenly with the developers tossing new ideas up into the air and seeing what sticks. But it feels like they rarely test these things(except to avoid bugs), as long as nothing's outright breaking the game, it stays in, and the final test of whether it's actually fun or functional, is left for the game's buyers to figure out.

For instance, we've got the shapeshifting from Risky's Revenge back again, this time with even more forms. But there are a couple of forms that you'll never actually use(outside of their mandated one or two applications for gaining bonus items or quest items), because their uses are either extremely niche(elephant, spider and mouse, looking at you) or heavily overlapped with another form. Some also feel like they weren't tested much, since the Bat allows you to trivialize large parts of some areas(sky bridge in the desert, hello to just flying past all those platforms).

Boss fights also still feel spastic rather than tactical. I'm sure I'm going to get the usual "git gud" comments for this, but in some platformers, I can go into a boss fight, and after screwing up one or two waves, I can go: "Oh, okay, this is what they want me to do." And then sure, I may lack the brains or dexterity to actually do it, but I can always see the IDEA. In HGH, there are some attacks where I just can't see HOW to dodge them, some bosses where I just can't figure out their mechanics(what actually triggers the Tinkerbrain popping up its canisters?) and the game also suffers a bit from some things that look good being a bit counterproductive.

In the case of boss fights, circular boss arenas are VERY neat, since they basically give you "infinite" horizontal space without any screen scroll, but it makes it hell to judge the distances of something rolling towards you, and when there's a LOT of stuff in the middle of the circle, like in the final battle, it can be hard to see projectiles spawned on the other side of the circle before they're all the way past the clutter and way in  your face.

In general, the improved graphics also feel like they make things a bit more vague. It's less "sharp" where spikes end and where they begin, or what parts of a heavily animated flame projectile actually burns you. I mean, it looks GREAT, not denying that, but it feels like if you're gonna do that in a platformer, you should be a bit more forgiving about hit areas. 

It also feels like there's no "good" difficulty in the game. Like, again, I enjoyed it, but I never really felt challenged except by instakill spikes in a couple of areas, and that's not the sort of challenge that appeals to me(seriously, WayForward, the final dungeon of Pirate's Curse was a mistake. PLEASE don't try to recapture any of that. Ever.). But unless you intentionally avoided upgrades and heart holders, it just feels like you can brute force your way through most areas, chugging a few consumables when necessary, and the same for the boss fights. 

On the one hand, a bit more challenge would make it feel a bit more satisfying when beating an area, but on the other hand, I appreciate that if I really get stuck on doing something "right" I can just power through it with potions.

I'm also not sure how I feel about the new approach to travelling, with the world map and warp dances. It makes everything feel easier, backtracking is considerably less of a pain, but it also makes Sequin Land feel less like a world, and more like a series of levels. But that's probably a personal thing.

Finally, there are a few technical issues, mostly related to some animations "chopping" a bit, sometimes characters flicker partway through animations, etc. but it's pretty rare. It's almost completely isolated to the world map screen where Sky, Wrench and Shantae sometimes behave a bit oddly.

So ultimately, the verdict is: It needs polish, and in some cases issues that have been showing up in Shantae games since Risky's Revenge need to be recognized as issues and addressed, but it's got so much heart that I can't pretend I don't love it. This was money well-spent for me, and it will be for anyone else who likes the Shantae games. Because like me, I bet you've spent half an hour listing all the things that could be fixed about Risky's Revenge and Pirate's Curse, but then you finish by going: "I loved the game anyway. How did they manage to make a zombie so cute?"

You know, unless you have no taste and don't agree that Rottytops is best girl.

A very fun game with beautiful art, incredily smooth animation, good music, charming characters and silly sense of humour. Shantae games are always an enjoyable experience, and Half-Genie Hero is no exception. To make things even better, the game will still get more updates, giving us extra characters to play with unique abilities.

My one complaint is that the game is too easy, and it's possible to collect an item that gives you unlimited magic, which downright breaks the game. However, we are given the option of deactivating these items, which is nice, as it helps keeping the game more challenging.

The story is a bit ot a let-down as well in two senses: 1- it doesn't really follow the pllot of Shantae and the Pirate's Curse, and 2- the missions don't feel like part of a bigger adventure, IMO. They feel like episodic quests only slightly connected to each other.

Still, the game is really fun to play and the animation is gorgeous! If you're looking for a light-hearted plataforming adventure with great visuals and delightful characters, this is the game for you!
