28876422.review:
I should probably say that I’m newcomer to the series and Half-Genie Hero is my first game in the franchise.  I liked the game, which seems strange considering my final vote on it – my final feelings lie somewhere in the middle, but Steam doesn’t have neutral score, so I cannot use this.
The game certainly looks polished when you play it – characters look beautiful, music is fantastic and animation fluid. Game plays smoothly and responsively (usually, we will talk later about some forms...). The level design is good and most of the levels are blast to play. Transformation are fun and open a lot of new ways to move though levels, other power-ups and spells make fight interesting and give players a lot of options to dispatch enemies.

So far it seems like very nice platformer, doesn’t it? However, the longer you play, the more cracks start to show. There are only few (hub, five main and final) levels, which wouldn’t be a problem – game doesn’t really have to be very long to be good and leave nice impression, but you can see that creators saw short length of the game as big problem and were afraid that it seemed to short. Most of my problems stems from methods they applied to combat this problem.

- First, that five main levers? They are very interesting first time you play though them and nice second time, with some small changes in monster or trap placement. However, you better hope you will really like them, because you will be playing them over and over trying to find that missing upgrades necessary to progress your story. At this point I just cannot look at beautifully designed and interesting creepy factory level considering how many times I have to beat it. When you have to give players spell to skip parts of the world to get instantly to next level (you get that and this is immensely helpful, but still doesn’t  eliminate main problem) you really should think if amount of backtracking isn’t too big. At some point it just stop being fun (and I’m a completionist type of player) and start to seem like artificially padding the game’s length.

- Instant death traps spanning entire sublevels. Well, they are not exactly instant death (you only lose some energy after failing and are moved to the beginning of challenge), but they are rather long with no checkpoints in the middle. It wouldn’t be that bad, but they are designed for you to fail at least few times before you can play them from memory. Two of them remove most of your special skills and make you fall down slippery slope while jumping over chasm and avoiding barrels (don’t know, maybe it is series tradition? Doesn’t really seem fun), with some jumps timed in the way that you cannot really succeed on them without inhuman reflexes or precise knowledge coming from failing them before – and if you will, you will have to replay entire segment from the beginning.  Another one is “lava rising” type of the level – you need to climb tower while instant kill condition rise from the bottom. This is classic platformer design, however even in Ninja Gaiden series it was clear where you should jump – Shantae sublevel is long and have tons of blind ends, making you constantly fail until you progress to almost the end and can play sublevel from memory where you should move to avoid moving into blind end.

- These instant death trap type of sublevels? One of them comes just after final boss. It’s extremely fun to have do trial and error long gameplay segment when you have just won final fight and want to sit back and relax while story unfolds ;-)

- There is instant death sublevel build entirely on how unwieldy and full of inertia is one of the transformed Shantae’s forms. I know that controls of that form are bad, you don’t have to show me that so much ;-)
 
- Lots of upgrades seem like afterthought – for example, special power of bat transformation is used exactly once and only to get relic that allows another (not really useful for combat) almost optional form to attack.

- There is an upgrade late game (I think you get it for unlocking entire art gallery? Not sure) that gives you unlimited mana allowing for endless casts of spells. Doesn’t seem too bad, strong bonus for completionists, until you realize it means unlimited instant full life heals, unlimited healing items spawn and unlimited invulnerability bubble spell.  Because of that final level consist mainly of instant kill spikes, while final bosses are a joke.

- For the end – characters. They seem fun and interesting. They seem to know Shantae, but I have no idea how and why. If you don’t know them from previous installments, there is pretty much zero explanation who they are, how they know Shantae and why are they friends/enemies.

To sum up -  I enjoyed most of this game, at least until more annoying parts came up, killing my enjoyment each time. It is a very nice game and I hope there will be next game in the series that will polish problems this one is full of – but at this point, my opinion is a little more negative than positive (I would really like to be able to choose neutral opinion in Steam review options).

28867153.review:
I'm not normally one to write reviews, but I really want to write my thoughts on the game somewhere. It's like 4AM though, so I'm not sure how coherent this is going to be, but uh, here we go.

First of all, I love the direction that they've taken the art style. The visuals are absolutely gorgeous. The hand-drawn characters over the 3D backgrounds look very nice. Speaking of the characters, I feel that the more chibi-style is really cute. All in all, it's just a great game to look at.

The soundtrack is fantastic as usual. A couple of tracks really reminded me of Mighty Switch Force!, which y'know, makes sense considering Jake Kaufman composed the soundtrack to that too. I don't think he's ever produced a track I haven't liked.

Now in comparison to the previous titles in the series, I do feel like Half-Genie Hero takes a couple of steps back in places, particularly the level design. I wouldn't really call the game a Metroidvania. The more exploration-based dungeons are gone and have been replaced with much more linear levels divided up into a few sections each followed by a boss. If I had to draw a comparison to something similar, it'd probably be Mega Man. (This certainly doesn't mean I think Mega Man has bad level design or that I think the level design in this game is bad. Really, it's just different.) The scale of the worlds also feels a lot smaller, especially in comparison to Pirate's Curse. I was a little surprised at how short they all felt, even on my first playthrough. I also feel like the game doesn't utilize all of the transformations enough. There are a couple that are really only used once and then never again. There are also a few that don't even really need to be used at all. Most of those are optional though, so it's not a huge deal.

I've got a few small issues with the story, too. I'm sure others have said this before, but the game is sort of a soft reboot. There were some character development moments in Pirate's Curse that I was interested to see possibly get expanded upon, but the game kinda just ignores them. It's not really that big of a deal, though. It was just something I was kinda hoping to see. Something that does bother me though, is how disjointed the story feels at times. The events of the game never really feel all that connected and are more like random tasks that are just there to move the plot along. It doesn't really feel all that much like an adventure. The dialogue is great, though. I did enjoy the references to previous games and I laughed at most of the jokes.

I know it probably sounds like I'm being too critical, but I really enjoyed the game. It just feels a little weaker compared to the rest of the series, in my opinion. On its own, it's a really great game and a hell of a lot of fun. If you've never played a Shantae game before and you're interested, this is a great place to start. I feel the game does a good enough job of introducing the characters and the world to newcomers. If you do pick it up and enjoy it, then I strongly recommend you check out the others as well. It's a great series and it's really a shame that it's still so relatively unknown.

To sum everything up, I feel the game takes some steps forward in certain areas and some steps back in others, but it's still a great experience. Give it a try if you're interested!

There's probably more I would like to say, but it's really late and I'm tired so I think I'm about done here.

28854465.review:
(Edited since the addition of hardcore mode)

TL;DR: Good game, but a step back from the previous title. Initially downvoted because of lack of content, and even now I feel like the base game only barely meets the $20 asking price, especially since there will be paid DLC in the future (unless you were a backer in which case it's all free). If you're looking to get into the franchise, I would VERY strongly recommend Pirate's curse instead, or even Risky's Revenge: Director's Cut since Pirate's Curse is a continuation of that story.

PROS:
-Platforming is fluid and satisfying.
-Absolutely amazing soundtrack. Less tracks here than PC, but what is here is golden. My only critique is that the first run of the first level had vocals which I found distracting, but that same track is also played during the credits which is perfectly fine.
-Transformations are more fluid than previous games, and there are many more of them.
-New art style isn't bad (chibi isn't really my thing personally, I prefer pixel sprites and Inti Creates' art style from Pirate's Curse).
-Humorous dialogue. I laughed out loud on multiple occasions.

CONS:
-Easily my biggest issue is the switch from the metroidvania playstyle. There are no dungeons, no save stations and no open world. HGH plays more like a Megaman game. You have stages divided up into a few areas that give you a save option between them. Stages can be replayed from the beginning to collect upgrades/items previously unattainable, and later on you get the ability to warp ahead to the next area of a stage if what you're looking for is in that area, but there is no backtracking to the previous area in a stage. If you miss something in the previous area you have to restart the entire stage (warp is handy here).
-Overall less content than PC, as stated before.
-Story is severely lacking. Rather than an overarching plot, HGH consists of several mini-plots, none of which are very interesting.

IMO, the game feels like less effort went into building the game and instead that effort went into creating new assets and engine. Probably the reason Pirate's Curse was so awesome was because it reused so many assets from Risky's Revenge, and so much more effort was able to go into the game itself. If so, then I can only hope that the next game turns out to be at least as successful as PC was by reusing assets from HGH.

Also, I would absolutely LOVE to see the return of Inti Creates artwork for the next game.

アクションゲームとしては水準程度の出来で、一日を費やすには悪くないゲームである。ボリュームは比べるべくもないが、風のクロノアをイメージすると近いものがあるだろうか。ただし不要な要素が多く、潔く要素をそぎ落としていれば完璧なゲームとなっていただろう。

[b]ファンサービスでしかないストーリー[/b]
前作「Pirates Curse」でも目立っていたシリーズファン向けストーリーがより先鋭化し、ファンサービス」以外の何物でもない状態になっている。キャラクターにもともとの愛着がなければストーリーは単にテンポを悪化させるに過ぎない。

[b]無駄な非アクション要素[/b]
本作は2Dアクションだが、完成度の低い強制スクロール面とシューティングステージが存在する。これは私見だが、そのゲーム本来の操作系と異なるステージを突然挟むことには大きな不快感を覚える。Gears of Warの乗り物ステージでイライラした覚えはないだろうか？ Call of Duty World at War の戦車ステージはどうだっただろう？　これが本作を推薦しない最大の理由だ。コース料理の合間に、酷く不味い口直しを挟まれてはたまったものではない。

[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
[*] The OST is really fun and varied - there are some funky, catchy songs mixed in here. 
[*] For the most part, the animation is great, especially on Shantae herself. Most of the animations have a certain bounce to them, which compliments the music.
[*] The controls feel tight and responsive. 
[*] Being able to transform into a bunch of 'Shantae-ified' objects and creatures is really cool. It's certainly swooped in and stolen Momodora 4's '2016's Best Game With A Transforming Anime Girl' award. 
[*] The general tone of the game, in terms of presentation and writing, are really light-hearted and upbeat. The game has this sex-positive vibe without taking things too far, and I personally enjoy the sense of humour in the writing (e.g. fourth wall breaking). 
[/list]

[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
[*] The level design isn't very intricate. It's too often just a straight shot from left to right, with a few little extras to find here and there. In comparison, Pirate's Curse's levels felt more Metroidvania-ish in design, looping around or reusing rooms in interesting ways. 
[*] There's a lack of variety. Since transformations are this game's core mechanic, it's basically just a series of platforming challenges with slightly different rules introduced throughout (e.g. 'you can swim now', 'you can climb walls now'). Again, comparing to Pirate's Curse, those out-the-blue levels, where it turns into a runner, stealth or puzzle game, are almost non-existent. 
[*] The game's way too easy, and I'm not a person who usually cares or complains about challenge. There's just such an abundance of healing items, and enemies do so little damage. There came a point where I wasn't really engaging with boss fights, but instead just standing there, whipping constantly, because that's all I had to do to win. Once you have Shantae's hair fully upgraded, bikini armour and a few heart containers, enemies may as well not exist.  
[*] Some of the transformations feel redundent (and I'm not including the ones which are redundant by design, for comedy). For example, (avoiding spoilers) I feel the first two transformations assigned to D-Up could easily have been combined to be one form. Transforming is a cool mechanic, but with so many, it slows the pace of the game down. I feel as though dropping some forms in favour of fleshing out some other's movesets would've helped the pacing of the game. 
[*] The backtracking feels like padding. I don't recall feeling this way about Pirate's Curse, so I'm not sure if there's just more fetch-quests here, or if the level design is part of the reason for this feeling. 
[*] The world-building is weaker than past games. The hub area, Scuttle Town, though more refined in terms of utility, feels more restricted and shallow. 
[*] There aren't any real narrative stakes. The episodic nature does work, but there isn't really anything tying it all together (unlike Pirate's Curse, with both Risky's and the Ammo Baron's plotlines). I was hoping [spoiler]the new town genie[/spoiler] would play a larger role, [spoiler]but that narrative thread ends way too early[/spoiler].  
[/list]

I feel bad for writing so many negative opinions about the game. Again, I think I'm biased towards being critical because I hold Pirate's Curse really highly. I appreciate that Half-Genie Hero tried something a little different, rather than just rehashing the last game. It's obvious that I'd recommend Pirate's Curse above this game, but I honestly think it comes down to preference. Overall, it's still a fun platformer with an upbeat atmosphere and some compelling gameplay mechanics.

28841237.review: Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is a solid platformer with beautiful graphics, tight controls, great music, and genuinely funny dialogue. As a disclaimer, I have not played any other Shantae game so I can't speak to how Half-Genie Hero stacks up to previous entries. The game centers around Scuttle Town (the hub area) where you're able to speak with NPCs, buy items, get hints, and travel to the various levels of the game. The story takes you through each level which are abundant with collectibles, hidden areas, NPCs, and bosses for you to face. I didn't find any of the levels or bosses particularly challenging except one or two times I struggled finding a specific item. The only real issue I have with the game is its length, but that's only because I enjoyed what was there so much! Thankfully, the kickstarter achieved several stretch goals that will add post-release content to increase the length of the game. I very much enjoyed my time with the game and reccomend it to any platformer fans.

28830582.review:
WayForward did a good job working out this game.  In comparison to previous titles in the Shantae series, this one has the least "clunkiness" feel to it.  The game feels better streamlined.

I will also say, the game will feel easy.   Once you are decently equipped with pick-ups and upgrades, the game and boss fights do get easier.  This game is built around the same premises that keeps Super Metroid in the spotlight.  Super Metroid has good replayability and is as challenging as you make it.  Shantae: Half-Genie Hero, all the same.  This game is as challenging as you make it.  If you don't want the last fights too easy, don't collect everything or put everything to full use.  Find your own challenges.

The story is great and worth reading through, even though you can skip through it for a speed run.  I find the story is well balanced and fun.

All being said, previous games had a Metroidvania feel.  This game is more like the Mega Man X series where you replay levels to pick up items hidden in each level.

I fully recommend playing this game and the other 2 Shantae games available on Steam.  The original game is Shantae for the Game Boy Color, and WayForward has not ported or remastered it for a modern console or PC.  And this game is also the 4th game in the series, not a reboot.

28816256.review:
Half Genie Hero plays more like a Mega Man game than a Metroidvania. Mega Man X to be precise. If you're looking to scratch a Metroidvania itch, this game won't do it for you. It's a trend that has been happening with the Shantae games. Risky's Revenge had a large world that was entirely open, but Pirate's Curse broke the world into islands containing a dungeon. Half Genie Hero only has pure levels.

The levels are mostly linear, with a few side areas you can explore if you have the right transformation. The transformations while fun, are too abundant and have the obvious consequence of having their roles overlap. Their usefulness depends on the player. If you care about optimizing your movents, all the transformations can help you blaze through levels and collect items. For regular and casual players, half of them will probably never see any use.

Other than that, everything else is what you'd expect from a Shantae game. The character art is beautiful and animates nicely. The platforming is very fluid and flows really well. There is also an option to turn off items you collect. Don't want Level 3 Fire? You can turn it off and enable Level 1 if you want to use that. It's not a major thing, but I appreciate it's inclusion.

Just keep in mind that this isn't a Metroidvania. It's a Mega Man game. And it's good.

28811891.review:
Pretty faithful continuation of the shantae series.

PROS:

- Solid animation (some of the cleanest i've seen from 2D)
- Tight controls (complete remapping options if you need it)
- Dat soundtrack (probably the best in the series yet)
- Good level design (for the most part)

CONS:

- So short (8 hours to 100%)
- Open world is gone (style changed from metroidvania to megaman)
- Character models cartoony (personal gripe but I liked the pirate's curse art better)
- Too many fetch quests (exploration is more forced than encouraged)
- Excessive level revisits (for all those fetch quests)
- Extremely easy (didnt even know what the death animation was till after I beat the game)
- Magic is useless (except for the invincible bubble, which breaks the game)
- Too many forms (only a few are really useful while the others fill scarce niches)

Wayforward has stated that additional characters will be available later on and hopefully it will help the game retain its value. Its a very fun and upbeat game to play regardless, it just ends too fast to enjoy to the fullest. Wait until more characters come out to buy it.

28809791.review:
Half-Genie Hero is my first venture into the Shantae series, and it is always kinda difficult to review a game in an objective way if said game is part of an established franchise. I went out of my way to look at other people's opinions on the game and reviews of the previous titles in the series, as well as look over the wiki a few times, all just to make sure I knew what exactly what I was talking about. Without further ado, here's my review (oh hey it rhymes !)

Half-Genie Hero is fun, really, really fun. 

The gameplay is just great, with super smooth controls, rapid transformations that open up new paths, magic powers to use and abuse, and despite the level design being on the weaker side, levels are a joy to play over and over again, collecting all the things you can find, and speedrunning is just the icing on the cake. It is a shame the levels are completely disconnected from the main hub, it makes the world feel rather disjointed. A shame for an entry in a series that is usually praised as a good example of Metroidvania (and god knows I'm a sukker for Metroidvanias).

Graphically, the game is gorgeous, pure eye candy (and i'm not saying that for all the lovely Jigglypuffs, IYKWIM). The lovely art direction is only an added bonus on top of some of the smoothest animations I've seen in my life. Every level is a joy to explore thanks to the clever mix of 2D and 3D. It's just a shame that most of them are rather generic, with a port, a jungle with waterfalls, a desert, a volcano...the real standout level was the magic carpet ride, which isn't something you see everyday.

Musically, it's also great, with many catchy tracks that don't feel the need to venture into 8/16 bit territory to be good. Jake Kaufman's the man when it comes to making great music, and I'm happy to say he delivered big time with his work on Half-Genie hero. The mermaid factory theme has to be my personal favorite, along with the boss fight theme. Sound design is also neat, it's very satisfying to fight enemies and hear them burn or get crushed.

The story is pretty weak, however. It's kind of all over the place, with mini-plots that don't go anywhere, and no real big narrative to string it all together. Characters get introduced only to be ignored or forgotten, and it doesn't make a strong impression. For what it's worth, the writing is funny and the interactions between characters are great, and the whole thing can be ignored, but it's a shame that a game like this couldn't give its story more attention. It's all over pretty quickly, as is tradition with games designed with speedrunning in mind. 

Overall, I'd definitely recommend this game, even if you're not a fan of the series like me before playing it. I'm going to give Pirate's Curse a look one of these days, and I'm definitely looking forward to the extra content coming to HGH in the future.

28807741.review:
A stellar game that it's backers should feel proud to have supported.

Shantae: Half Genie Hero excels in just about every category. The level design is superb, the music is fantastic, the visuals are gorgeous, and the characters are likable. Add those with one of the most unique and well-designed protagonists in gaming, and you get one of the finest games of the year. Unlike the previous installments, Shantae travels via map rather than a connected overworld. Keep this in mind if you were expecting more of a Metroidvania style game. Each area of the map counts as a chapter, with each chapter having a seperate plot, making it somewhat akin to Kirby Super Star. Assuming the player is a completionist, the game shold take roughly around 6-8 hours. Some may feel this is too short, but for me personally, I think it's fair for it's price. I do wish, however, that Risky Boot's story was availabe at purchase, and that Hero Mode gave the player access to ALL of Shantae's transformations and transformation attacks. Other than that, I find it hard to find any notable criticisms with the game itself. What I think this game really did well at was achieving it's own identity. For me, it didn't feel like "a Mega Man game" or "a Metroidvania" game. It felt like a SHANTAE game, which is something that Risky's Revenge and The Pirate's Curse, as good as those games are, felt like they were lacking in my opinion.

Buy this game. It's great.

28804927.review:
Somewhat conflicted over this one. Half-Genie Hero is a good game in its own right, but IMO it's a big step down from Pirate's Curse. The transformation dances from the original game and Risky's Revenge are back, but many of them feel shoehorned in and don't serve much purpose outside of getting an item here and there. The level design is much more linear and straightforward compared to the previous entries, and dungeons with maps and keys are completely absent. Even so, there are still plenty of secret items that you can go back and find throughout the levels.

The bosses are a lot of fun but also pushovers, it's true that these games have never been particularly difficult to begin with but I think even by the series standards this game stands out as being the least challenging one yet(Hardcore mode update rectifies this). As far as story goes, it still retains the charm and humor from the previous games but there's not really any continuation from Pirate's Curse, as if all the character development and events that occurred never took place. The game acts more like a soft reboot.

Despite everything, I still think it's a good and very fun game, I definitely recommend it if you're a fan of the series. Music is top notch, controls are tight, the game looks great and DLC is coming in the near future that'll let you play through 4 additional campaigns as other characters, so that may alleviate some of the issues.

Like always, I enjoyed the writing and quirky story behind Shantae series from Wayforward. I played Shantae games for the comedy and how the characters developed around them. (better to play the previous series if you never played Shantae series before)

However on this 1/2 genie sequel, I found that a bit of everything kind of washed out a bit. Still the graphic is excellent (even though I experience diagonal screen tear in my laptop) but it's undeniable that the game is beautiful and the animations are smooth.

But for some reason, I felt that this time, the game ends too early (unlike the the pirate curse) and story even though still full with funny memorable moments but it felt too short and suddenly before you know it the game is already ended. The gameplay is also a bit too easy this time with a very easy puzzle and easy bosses... (especially if you go for 100% completion)

But still overall, even though this is not the best of the Shantae series for me (so far the best is still the Pirate Curse IMHO), the game is still highly enjoyable nonetheless.

Hopefully next time, Wayforward can come out with a better Shantae game series with longer story, challenging puzzle, platformer and bosses but with the same charming aesthetic of 1/2 genie hero. :)

28781450.review:
Just bought and finished the basic game in about 6 and a half hours, Merry Christmas to me. It was the $18 price tag for the release special, but it would be $20 normally. I would recommend trying to find it on sale if you can.

It was pretty good. I had a lot of fun playing it and I'm glad to be adding it to my Shantae collection. It's a little bit expensive for the length, but I think it will be much more worth the price when all of the rest of the Kickstarter-promised features get added in. Like I said, I recommend it on sale and mostly to fans of Shantae.

If you own previous Shantae games, you should probably get it. If you haven't played a Shantae game before, I recommend you get Shantae and the Pirate's Curse much more.

Warning: My review perspective will involve a lot of comparisons to Risky's Revenge (RR) and the Pirate's Curse (TPC) since I played all three this year.

It also has a lot of gripes and may come off as slightly negative.

Gameplay:

The main way it deviates from the previous two Shantae games is that the levels are much more linear. Each level is divided into 2 or 3 separated sections that you have to sift through to get the collectables. It's much closer to TPC's island levels than RR's single connected overworld. No more dungeons, which is a little disappointing because I really like the previous games' dungeon designs. I think it completely loses its status as Metroidvania, even though TPC wasn't very Metroidvania. But that's fine.

I felt that the platforming suffered. Shantae runs slightly too slow and jumps slightly too short to be satisfying. Platforming only felt good in monkey form. And unfortunately, transforming from human to monkey repeatedly was not great. It was much more jarring compared to RR's dance transforms because it requires more complicated inputs and briefly pauses the game. The platforming with Risky's items in Pirate's Curse can't be outdone.

The dance system felt sort of "crowdfundy" with a bunch of transformations thrown in just because they could. However the transformations were generally really fun to use once you got used to it, even if some were a bit too niche. My favorites were the monkey and crab mechanics.

Combat was solid. The character hitboxes and attacking animations were super smooth and fluid. The max attack speed upgrade surpassed my xbox button pressing abilities, which is kind of absurd.  It also added the spellcasting system back from RR which is fun, but pretty much optional for most of the game. Upgrades allow you to become completely overpowered very quickly.

Boss designs were pretty good, all had pretty cool designs and unique mechanics. However, I did not have very much fun with the final boss, or the final level design in general.

The overall difficulty is pretty low. It was the easiest of the three Shantae games I played.

Story:

I think it was almost a soft reboot?

The story was okay. I felt like it was clearly "crowdfundy," meaning it was kind of garbled to fit a desired checklist. I had no idea what my main storyline motivation was for the first 80% of the game and I had to get invested in these little villain-of-the-week episodic stuff. But the episodic stuff was fun and amusing, so I was able to roll with it, even though some of the subplots weren't fleshed out enough. Shantae has never been known for its gripping story line, but I didn't think it was as good as the last two games.

Characters:

As with every Shantae game, the characters are super appealing. They are as endearing, flirty, and ridiculous as I expect out of Wayforward. The dialogue writing is clever and funny. My one big gripe is that all of the Sequin Town NPCs are just there to bombard you with hints for progression, which feels wrong. Also, some of the great characters don't get a long enough exposure because the story is so scattered.

Music:

Virt's work is godtier. No exeptions. I downloaded the OST (free on his Bandcamp!) immediately.

Artstyle:

The art is great overall. The character and world designs are top notch, and together with the music it makes a very pretty package. Sometimes the 2-D/3-D mix is a little jarring.

28771743.review:
I was a backer of this "Daniel David" in the credits (should have been Daniel David Kelly but it seems they acknowledge that some names got messed up), but theres no bias here, the game is good. I'll go into some details on the game however because its not flawless, no game is.

Shantae managed to make a game many times better than Mighty No. 9 on a fraction of the budget, beautiful artstyle with solid gameplay with a feel of a Saturday morning cartoon. This really was a kickstarter done right.

Shantae is not without its problems however, the main thing to point out in these flaws however is they've been persistant throughout all Shantae, so if these are a problem for you its more a problem with Shantae in general instead of this specific game:

1) Game is linear compared to the past..... I guess? The past Shantaes were no Symphonies of the Night as far as exploration goes either, I don't know why it suddenly becomes a huge thing for this game. And in all honesty while they don't have alot of screens, theres still alot of stuff hidden in them for you to find using your powers which kind of ties right into the next major complaint.

2) Alot of backtracking and fetch quests as "content":  I got no counter for this, its absolutely true. Even if the fetching is comical and corny on what they make you find, a spade is a spade. They do make you backtrack alot as playing in Hero mode proves. Most every shantae I've played however used this formula so its more a knock against Shantae than this game specifically.

3) The game is short: my first play through was 6 hours, and has only gotten shorter in replays and hero mode.... once again however this is something Shantae has almost always been known for (I mean hell Risky's revenge you can 100% clear in 2 hours X minutes) Platformers are rarely epic 60 hour games unless they are a castlevania where most of that time is grind.

What should be made important here is the game is put together very well and solid, while its a short experience its one that is great from beginning to end and is colorful and fun. I also sort of liked the format of this one that really felt like playing an old Saturday morning cartoon, as in each "level" feels self contained like an episode out of a show that all contribute a small thing that the last level feels like the conclusion of a season arc, it added to the over experience and made it fun.

If the game is a bit too pricey for you, just wait for a sale, but if you love platformers this ranks up as one of the best ones.

Es bestünde zwar die Möglichkeit, nachträglich einen Kickstarter zu eröffnen, um die Features dazuzukriegen, aber das liegt in der Hand der Entwickler.

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]

Das Spiel geht zurück zu den Anfängen der Reihe, hat eine interessante Story und liebenswerte Charactere. Meiner Meinung nach sehr empfehlenswert.

28754750.review:
Как–то так, мне кажется, и должен выглядеть современный платформер. Красивая, мультяшная плоская графика и качественные 3д задники. Лучшее от двух миров!

Шантая — это девушка–полуджинн, защитница города Скаттл Таун. Она по–прежнему бьет врагов волосами, но теперь в полном HD. Как и в Risky's Revenge, Шантая при помощи различных танцев (более двенадцати в этой игре), может перевоплощаться в разных существ, и обретать за счет этого новые способности. Так, мартышка может карабкаться по стенам, слон — ломать большие камни, и так далее.

В игре не так много уровней, но в каждый из них придется вернуться несколько раз, чтобы с новыми способностями добраться в места ранее недоступные.

Уровни в этот раз более линейные чем обычно, а пестрое население Скатл Тауна щедро выдает квесты и подсказки, так что блуждать без понимания, куда идти, придется гораздо меньше, чем в прошлых играх. 

Игра, за исключением отдельных моментов, легкая. Если скупить все доступные артефакты — очень легкая, а в отдельных моментах можно и схитрить. Проходится быстро. Я одолел ее за девять часов и собрал 100% предметов. Если не заморачиваться с собирательством — наверное, можно управиться за четыре.

Это хорошая игра, яркая и веселая, так что обратите внимание.

I really enjoyed Shantae and the Pirates Curse but this game seems to be a total bore compared to it.

Do not get me wrong, it's well made. But I'ven't seen as much hand holding ina game as this. 

You have a spell that shields you from almost everything, and then you have a spell that heals you completely. 

On top of that, if you go around and collect all the keys to unlock the concept art gallery you'll get an item that gives you unlimited magic! Why so much hand holding? The Final boss is a joke by the way, regardless if the game has 2 endings (I think squid baron was harder) 

I like the art of the game, it's not pixel art it's stylized and it works nicely. The voice acting is pretty much ... the same (wish there was more) 

There are some very tedious sliding levels, while the first one is ok, the second one is ok, I thought the last one was pushing it. Not in terms of skill level but rather how long it was, I ended up basically memorizing it to completion. 

And backtracking is another thing, there's virtually no reward for finding items in this game because you buy an item to make your hair do more damage. You buy a spell to completely heal you. You buy this, you buy that. The items that you find are usually worthless. The spider form is only useful in like 2 areas so why does it even have an attack? 

On top of all of this the game lacks the comedy aspect that was delivered in The pirates curse. It's just so bland I found myself just trying to complete it as fast as possible. 

I'm only recommending because I still liked the game, it's just a slight dissapointment to the shantae franchise.

28731412.review:
Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is Shantae's newest game, Kickstarted by the fans. Updated for the modern age and brought to Steam, the game is in full color (big shock) with a wonderful "indie" feel. Is it any good? Let's find out!

[h1]Story: 7/10(Quirky and fun, but awkward pacing)[/h1]
Shantae's story in this game is fairly straightforward. It's definitely an indie-written story, but it wears that designation on its sleeve. The story itself is like the game: Quirky and fun. However, its pacing is somewhat awkward. It's not bad, but it seems to have some sections that drag on from a lack of direction (Thankfully, "Bathroom Angel" can fix that somewhat) and some that blow by.

There's also some funny references and 4th-wall-breaking. The writing itself is fantastic, giving everyone personality and charm. I just wish the story itself was paced a little better and the initial directions you're given at the start of each quest were clearer, but nothing in the story has made me consult a walkthrough yet.

[h1]Characters: 10/10 (YESYESYESYESYESYESYES)[/h1]
OK, I have to gush about the writing for the characters. There is so much charm and personality to the characters, ESPECIALLY Shantae. Shantae is a mixture of a straight-woman to the weirdness, a generic hero-type (played with), an airhead (without being a motor-mouth), and a bit of thickness. (She's not dense by any means, she seems pretty smart, just naive.) I like all of the characters and their dialogue is all great.

[h1]Gameplay: 8/10 (Well-refined platformer with a bit of side-scrolling brawler)[/h1]
Shantae is evocative of the old-school Nintendo platformers, including some Metroidvania elements. You jump around like a maniac looking for platforms, look for every tiny hint to a secret/easter egg/new power-up, and some Castlevania-like brawling.

Shantae's also bringing some tricks to help make platforming better and uncover more secrets. She can use her Belly Dance (which has an adorable animation) to transform into different Forms, each with their own unique traits, jump height, attacks (or lack thereof), and special abilities. Most Forms have an upgrade to unlock a new attack, which is, unfortunately, not that interesting. (Mermaid Form gets a bubble, Crab Form gets a quick snap that clips through seaweed, Mouse Form gets a spammable-low-damage bite, and so on.)

The platforming itself is highly refined, practically to a science. The controls are tight and intuitive, Shantae's movement and jumping is consistent and controllable (You can adjust and correct your jumps mid-air, thankfully), and it's usually clear what you can and can't jump on. My only real complaint lies with a couple of her Forms, mainly with Harpy Form, where the controls become extremely floaty and nigh-controllable. Sometimes, the hitboxes can be a little iffy, especially with Mermaid Form where I've taken damage while close to (but not touching) an enemy that only damages you by touch because my TAIL got near it.

The brawling is very simple: One button makes Shantae slap a short distance in front of her (your generic Hair-Whip Attack) and another uses your Magic. It's very simple one-button combat (technically, two-button, but w/e) and works well.

I think my current major complaint with the gameplay is just the insane amount of backtracking you have to do. This isn't anything new if you've played a Metroidvania-style platformer in the past 10-15 years, but it really drives the pacing into the ground sometimes as you run from place to place, running the same levels at least 2 extra times each just praying you'll see the one thing different you can do with a new Form or upgrade. Granted, I'm not huge into Metroidvania, so take this with a massive grain of salt.

One more minor complaint I have to get off my chest is the inventory. There's no quick-use keys, so if you want to use something, you have to go into the Inventory screen, select it, and Use it. This is a very minor complaint, considering this actually HELPS, since the Inventory screen pauses the game and can let you get your bearings.

[h1]Music: 9/10 (Amazing Soundtrack)[/h1]
The music in this game is fantastic. It has that indie quirkyness to it without being grating. My only real complaint is that the music can get a LITTLE repetitive due to the Metroidvania nature of the game, forcing you to backtrack a ton and hear each track plenty of times.

[h1]Art Style: 10/10 (Awesome, A Visual Treat)[/h1]
The art style in this game is absolutely awesome. It's 2.5D (meaning, gameplay on a 2D plane, but 3D models) with a very anime-esque style. In fact, this whole game looks like a playable anime. Everything has this cute-quirky style to it and just drips with personality. It's an absolute treat to look at, combining an old-school 2D game with a 3D art style flawlessly.

Any the animations are just...AAAAAAAAAAA I LOVE THEM! Everything has this bouncy energy that brings the game to life. Shantae's idle animations are fun to watch, her Belly Dance is playful, just everything is beautifully animated.

[h1]Conclusion: 9/10 (Fantastic)[/h1]
Simply put, Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is a fantastic game. I'm rarely a fan of platformers, but Shantae has me absolutely entranced. I can't stop smiling at this game. Its fun old-school gameplay, energy-filled art and animations, just everything about the game oozes charm and personality. This was clearly made by developers who love their craft and wanted this game to be fantastic. While I haven't played any of the previous Shantae games (Nothing against them, just wasn't interested), this game seems to fit perfectly with the rest of them, but with some excellent modernization.

It's an absolute STEAL at $20. I can't wait to see how the developers will follow up to this fantastic platformer.

Maybe a Squid Baron standalone with $0.99 Shantae DLC is in order too. ;)

繰り返し繰り返し繰り返し訪れる事になります

マップを極度に制限して小出しに開放していくと言うのは
メトロイドヴァニアの楽しみとは違う気がします

お使いからお使いをリレーして奴隷の様に奔走する様は
さしずめ、わらしべ長者マラソンて感じです。

ダンスで技能を切り替えると言うのはビジュアル的には
最高に素晴らしいアイディアですが

前作ではそれらはコマンドでシームレスに行えたことなので
ゲームとしてはテンポが悪くなっているだけだと思いました。

水の中出入りするだけでもその都度一時停止して変身するので
結構イライラします、最高に可愛いんですけどね。

キックスターターで資金を集めて作った作品なので
じっくり煮詰める時間が無かったのかなぁとか邪推します。

壁に接触した時、キャラクターがそのまま欠けるだけと言う処理が
作り込みの甘さを物語っています。

ファンが出資してファンの声に答て新作が生まれた、
そういうコミュニケーションを楽しむ作品なのかもしれませんね

ビジュアルに惹かれた、シリーズのファン、なら
オススメです。

28726272.review: A wonderful game! A very fun platformer with wonderful characters and humor and levels that I gladly replay again. As someone who hasn't played any of the previous titles I could still very easily follow what this game was about. I really love it!

28725915.review:
Good game. Not the best in the series, but I had fun anyway. 

There were a couple of parts in the story that I felt were resolved too easily (deus ex machina moments) . WayForward could have easily tweaked the game to fix these "convenient" problem resolutions and given the game a lot more depth. I do wish they would have taken a darker turn at certain moments, but I suppose that I should remember that Shantae is a lighthearted series. 

The transformations are fun, but a lot of them are pretty much useless (mouse, spider, crab, pot, tree, fish IMO). I wish WayForward would have either put more effort into making more levels that used the tranformations or just left out the ones I listed and focused on the others.

I had a lot of fun in almost all of the levels. I feel that some had a lot of potential, but were not used to their full potential (hypno baron mansion). My favorite parts were the race up the tower and the carpet race. All in all, it was a good platformer.

I wish that the supporting cast would have had a larger part in the game. In previous games, I felt that you got to see Sky, Bolo, and Rotty Tops a lot more. In 1/2 Genie Hero, Sky is basically just your chófer, Rotty is present in maybe three scenes, and doesn't really do anything, and Bolo I think is in maybe three or four parts. I was hoping that you could play as them or have at least a little more interaction in the game. We'll see if they put out DLC that lets you do that.

The music, as usual, is superb. I bought the soundtrack after my first playthrough.

Overall, it's a good game. I've played every Shantae multiple times, and speed run it a bit, and despite a few flaws in the story and gameplay, it's overall a good game. I recommed you play it (and the others in the series as well).

28701712.review:
It's still a good game but I feel like the kickstarter model didn't do too much good to the game because it's a step back from Pirate's Curse. Personally I'd say Risky's Revenge is even a little bit better.

On the bright side they did progress from pixel art and have what I think is a great engine for the game. So perhaps there's some great potential in the future. The graphics, music and general movements are on point, although there are some minor bugs causing the game to stop for me from time to time. So overall it still plays great like a Shantae game. You get a lot of dances and the typical magic, which is very fun.

Where it gets insufficient and I suspect may be due to the kickstarter forcing them to implement so many elements to the game and thus not having enough time left, is the content and the story. The writing, first of all, seems a bit off. Shantae isn't a story focused game by any means but I thought this game story wise is especially shallow and did not portray the main characters as well as they can. Content wise you have so many powers and forms but there is very little content specifically designed for them, in some cases only one zone or none at all. Also, to inflate the content the devs added a lot of backtracing the the zones and since this game is no longer metroidvania style that's also not as good an experience as in previous games where revisiting zones and doing challenge dungeons can be so much fun. Another issue is boss difficulty tuning-- the later bosses are a joke unless you restrict yourself to not using any magic or item at all.

I think if this game was a bit more polished story wise and had 50% more content (that's not backtracing) it would have been great. As it is I still can't hate it because it's still Shantae but I don't regret not joining the kickstarter either.

28692422.review:
Disclaimer-  I backed Shantae:  Half-Genie Hero all the way back in 2013 (gez it's been that long).

I'm glad to see Shantae's first HD adventure turn out well. Also great to see a good finished product from a Kickstarter game after other disasters which will remain unnamed in this review.

Pros:
* Gorgeous design. Great art in the scenery and character sprits. Well composed music and good dialog. The end product is very polished.
* Solid platforming gameplay. Really reminds me of the SNES/Genesis golden era of platforming.

Cons:
* A bit on the short side. ~7-8 hours to complete. Possibly under 3 hours on replays. This includes two chapters added after hitting Kickstarter goals. I stutter to think what the end product would have looked like if those goals weren't hit.
* Like past Shantae games, it has a lot of backtracking in it, espcailly if you want to get 100%.
* Can't help but feel a tad pervy while playing it.

28689943.review:
[h1]A Solid Platformer[/h1]

I've looked forward to this game for a while and it had not failed to deliver. 

The visuals are a mix of beautifully drawn characters within a colourfully crafted world. The music also doesn't fail to bring you deeper into the world that has a blend of a megaman x/sonic feel to them. Controls are tight and responsive giving you the needed accuracy to navigate some of the hair line dangers. 

Level design is that of a stage select with some backtracking through previous areas. The only problems I have with that is you would get a power that at some point only serves a single purpose instead of being used multiple times and once certain areas have been completed they feel like they have lost their charm in some way (mermaids and tower).

If you are looking for a decent platformer with a decent amount of puzzle solving then this game is for you.

28689888.review:
Beautiful art direction, awesome soundtrack, cute girls and tight platforming, Shantae has it all! 

Fans who have played the other games in the series may notice that this game in particular takes a step back a bit from the backtracking, and instead focuses more on transformation abilities and platforming abilities.

Nevertheless, this game is yet another fantastic entry in the Shantae series, and an even better one to start with if you want to dive into the series.

28688868.review:
This game is in plenty ways amazing and dissapointing in others. It's a very beautiful platformer that feels just as good or better than previous Shantae games and also has some great level design that focuses more on linear megaman-style levels than those games more open Metroidvania or Zelda influences, and then lets that new focus down by adding unnecessary filler. I'm going to be comparing this game to the previous modern Shantae games quite a bit in this assessment, they are games that are pretty dear to me as far as modern-but-classic style platformers. Pirates Curse particularly I hold in very high regard, it's definitely the highest point where the series correctly iterated on the prequel and knocked it out of the park with the new skills. 1/2 Hero doesn't quite hit that mark.

Just to be clear, the core levels are all great and a pleasure to play. The upbeat music (I really don't like the lyrical version of the main theme, but everything else is great) and flow of the game works exceedingly well when you are jumping and hair whipping enemies. That first time you finish a level and a boss feels great...but after you do that there's this middle time when you meander around doing fetch quests for various NPCs. If these quests were optional they would be much easier to stomach, but their quirky weirdness don't make up for the fact that it's clearly game padding. Instead of filling the game with interesting side stuff to collect, most of it is all there to progress the main story. These levels are not really made for exploration either, and there is no map to assist you for finding the hidden stuff. It's mostly just reading NPC dialog to figure out where you need to go out of the levels you've already been, going there to get the necessary plot item. It seems like this game is trying to have it's tight platformer levels and is adding metroid elements to extend it, rather than building them into the game naturally. It doesn't really work too well, the game would only be about 4 hours with just the levels, but I would definitely prefer that to all of the filler.

Tied into the monotony of the between-levels is that most of the transformations just aren't very fun to use. The Monkey might be my favorite, but it is criminally underused because many of the later game transformations make it redundant. A lot of the transformations accomplish *almost* the same thing, Crab lets you sink underwater, Mermaid lets you swim. Sometimes you need to be a crab to fit underneath tight spots but there would be no way to know that by just looking at a body of water. When this happens you would have to jump out of the water, go back to the land area, dance to the right transformation and dive back in. This kind of thing sounds trivial, but it's just one of the many quirks that annoy me about the transformations. The entire idea of pausing the game and dancing just to have access to a traversal element seems unnecessary. The game doesn't even use all of the buttons on a ps4 pad, they could have let you bind transformations to individual buttons. If you compare this to the sleek implementations of Shantae's abilities in Pirate's Curse it definitely falls flat. Add to the fact that the charge, triplejump, saber, pistol, and Hat were all just way more fun to use in that game and integrated into the main game more often instead of being used just for item collection. Some of the transformations in this game are used for literally one item and never again, while some of the powerups you get for Shantae's different forms like the Spider Venom or Mouse bite seem never used at all.

Another issue I have with the game is the plot, or rather the lack of one. The dialog keeps that Shantae charm found in the previous games, Shantae herself remains a good protag with the right amount of snark. It is however tonally all over the place compared to Pirate's Curse. This series has never been about the amazing writing or anything, but at least Pirate's Curse had a solid goal and a tone that remained consistent. 1/2 Genie Hero drops the ball on this, most of the stuff that happens is silly for silliness sake and there is hardly an end goal to speak of. There are times when I really appreciate the weirdness of this game and the character interactions, but it also uses that weirdness to feed into those mandatory fetch quests I was talking about earlier which is unfortunate. None of the chapters really have much to do with each other, they don't build towards anything by the end. I think the desire for this to be THE Shantae game to bring the series on modern hardware, as well as the expectations associated with a kickstarter game encouraged Wayforward to find a way to cram every Shantae villian into this game to its detriment.

So what does work? Why am I recommending it? I would like to emphasis I really enjoyed playing this game a lot especially when I was playing through each of its 6 levels for the first time. As far as Shantae herself goes minus abilities this game might be the best feeling one yet. The levels are all utterly fantastic in that special linear megaman way. Hair whipping feels great and I hum the music obessively in my day to day life. Every level is an incredibly varied and unforgettable platformer experience that mostly makes up for all of those shortcomings I listed. I am able to look past those annoyances and confidently say I love this game and you should definitely play it, just temper your expectations a bit regarding everything else. I honestly can't wait for a more Pirate's Curse style game to come out with this engine they have crafted, it would be truly incredible.

28687383.review:
A decent platformer, but with it has its faults

I was a huge fan of the previous game in the series, and I was very excited to play this, unfortunately some things feel like a step backwards rather than forwards. There, however, are a lot of things to love here: The art is fantastic, and is easily one of the best looking platformers you can play on PC. 

The music, as composed by the great Jake Kaufman (Shovel Knight/Mighty Switch Force)  is generally top notch, although a few tracks (such as the last two parts of the game) I found very underwhelming. 

The levels are extremely fun the first time through, they all have fun gimmicks to them that make them stand out among the others, but you will be doing a ton of backtracking to find items, which can feel like a chore, and make the levels feel very small after a while, I know it was done to lengthen the game, but it spreads too thin, and I'd have preferred a 3-4 hour game that stayed fresh than a 7-8 hour game where you constantly comb through the same areas.

The boss fights are hit and miss, not horrible for a platform game (a genre not generally known for good bosses, outside of megaman and metroid) but not as challenging or charming as they were in Pirate's curse.

The biggest positive of the game by far is the transformations, there are tons of forms Shantae aquires and they all have fun and unique properties that change up the game a lot, and they all look dang cute.

I give this game a soft reccomendation, but hope there will be more that feels in line with Pirate's Curse in the upcoming Risky Boots campaign, as it was left feeling pretty dry at the end.

Still, one of the better platformers on steam, and for 20 dollars it's not a bad way to kill a few hours.

28686849.review:
Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is a game that wastes my time and jerks me around. I have beaten this game to 100% and this is my review:

[b]The positives:[/b]
-Good music, which will get repetitive as you replay levels over and over.
-Pretty good visuals.

[b]The negatives:[/b]
-Poorly thought out level design
-Terrible controls for several different Shantae transformations.
-Monkey Island style wacky nonsensical solutions to puzzles that make no sense.
-Awful check point system that makes you replay entire levels/the worst part of a level over and over.
-Forces you to constantly replay levels over and over as you unlock new powers which, in the end, does not feel satisfying but instead wastes your time.
-Boring boss battles.
-Terrible memeatic writing that is forced sounding and fan service feeling in general
-Has kick starter ‘backer-exclusive’ content that cannot be bought at all by anyone who didn’t get in early on the kick starter. This is anti-consumerism no matter how you try to spin it. This basically says to people who wanted to wait for a finished product and reviews, “your money is worth less to us than those who backed it”.  [b]More on this at the bottom of the review.[/b]
-Very little bang for your buck. I frustratingly played through this game in 8 hours, it is designed to be beaten in 4 hours. This is a 20 dollar game.

Details of this filth:

I have invented a new term just for this game, which upon reflection can be applied to a lot of bad games.
This term is called, “Monkey Island solutions” what is a, Monkey Island solution you ask? It is when a game, not just point-n-click adventure games, ask you to perform a series of complicated tasks to do a simple objective but also in which none of the steps nor end result makes sense and cannot be deduced naturally. Some other people in the video game realm might call this, “rub the fish on everything” syndrome.
Here is an example from this very game: you must get the power, as a mermaid, to shoot bubbles. How do you do this? Well, one of the villagers tells you that only “elder” sea creatures know this power! Well look at that, in town suddenly is the Grandma Blobfish (which earlier you had to find two tickets for her grandkids to go see a magic carpet ride via killing gator enemies with magic you must grind money for to unlock until they drop “gator stakes” to give to too villains for a ticket and that was only HALF of that quest).

Ahem, the example:
"We're gonna need you to get this blobfish a new hat so she can sing you a song and give you the mermaid shooting ability but to do that you must get the hat from a WACKY CHARACTER GUY that tells you to find ANOTHER WACKY CHARACTER GUY but to do that you first need to unlock the Mermaid form (several step subquest), combo into Harpy unlock (several step subquest), and figure out this cryptic clue that actually makes no sense (subquest to get clue)"

Do you see how this is a problem, how it is unfun to deal with and why guides are so popular for games today? This game is entirely like this, the whole game.

Let’s mention some gameplay; there is a point in this game in which you must control Shantae through a SPIKE MAZE using the WORST CONTROLLING form in the game, the Harpy. The harpy controls like a flappy bird clone but you can move forwards and backwards. She does not stop in midair, she always slightly moves forward which is a problem when this is happening:

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=826681326

See these two blocks? They are rotating around each other, and before them there are a series of three columns that block the entire way from ceiling to floor (the floor also kills you) and you must step in between the middle set of these spike walls as it opens to wait for the next to open; all doing this mind you [b]while the harpy cannot hover in midair[/b] so you must constantly tap jump to flap while wiggling back and forth to not die in a space less than an 8th of your screen for a character that takes up 90% of said space you are safe. This section alone is so disgustingly made, so poorly thought out I almost quit the game right then and there; [b]and this is at the very end of the game, right before the big finish.[/b] Oh right, for good measure they take you back to the start of the level if you die so ya know, have fun backtracking through the level to get up to the point you died, only to then die again on the very next trap you have no idea is coming.

The examples I give above are not single instances, but throughout the entire game. This whole game is a huge mess of poorly thought out choices, obscure and often offensive puzzles, poor controls for multiple transformation forms, and a absolutely terrible check point system that will make you want to quit. [b]Do not buy this game.[/b]

[b]Why backer exclusive content is anti-consumerism [/b]

Backer exclusive content is anti-consumerism in pure form.

Well fear not, for I shall explain; you see by offering 'backer-exclusive" content the game devs are tempting you in parting with your money before a finished product is made. They are offering you promises for cash, this is anti-consumer.

Pro-consumer is waiting for a finished, final product. If you are offered a chance to wait for a product, to see if you would like it and to experience reviews then you are in the clear and so are the devs. Backer-exclusives can be grouped in with other scummy practices devs/publishers often use. Here is an example:

"If you buy this game now, you will get access to X thing! No one else will get access to X thing because they bought it AFTER the game was released." Can you name that anti-consumer practice? That's right, preorder bonuses! Buy now, get product later! Secure money now for nothing, offer a game that might be as good we promise ;). Sound familiar? In the above sentence replace "after the game is released" with "after the game is funded". Nice.

A quick question to people that will come shilling in because of the bottom of this review: please riddle me this, how did games get made before kick starter?

How did a game get produced without the backing of a publisher, triple A or otherwise? How did indie games come into this world without the hand holding of kick starter? Through the blood, sweet, and tears of game devs everywhere. Cave story came to exist and became an excellent game as it was done by a man in his spare time.

28679736.review:
Whether it be a reboot, soft reboot, sequel or soft robot rabbit, Shantae is back in town.  Everything is familiar for fans of the series, maybe a little too much so in some respects, and if you're unfamiliar to the series and looking for a light metroidvania-esque platforming game that isn't too hard, you'll enjoy this.

The world is bright and colourful and the 3d background visuals are a pleasant departure from the standard 2d pixel art.  The soundtrack is pretty solid, as usual for the series.  Controls are mostly smooth, some jumps didn't feel quite as responsive as I'd like but good on the whole.  Though, Relic usage for animal transformations could be more seamless in game. On the topic of Relics, there are far too many transformations and not enough puzzles using them.  A few of the transformation upgrades only get used once or not at all.  There may have been plans to use these upgrades that never made it into the game, but it still feels like there's unnecessary clutter and it's disappointing to have useless abilities.  A lot of the magic you can buy from the store also isn't as useful as in past series.

Plotline is disappointing.  Just... disappointing.  It's like the events of the previous game were completely forgotten.  Whilst I do enjoy seeing familiar faces like Sky, Bolo, Rotty and Mimic again, too many of the minor antagonists were reused from previous games in shallow ways and the culmination of the plot just felt very half-baked.  That being said, there is some witty banter and some enjoyable dialogue.  And some nice 'plot' as usual.

The level design is decent and there are some interesting concepts and designs, though the execution isn't entirely there.  Bosses... eh.  I think the game misses not having any dungeons whatsoever, though, and the difficulty curve is pretty nonexistent.  I've no major issue with the backtracking elements to the game, but I do think that the game spoonfeeds a little too much with regards to some of the hidden items.  The hinting system is pretty inelegant as well.  

Overall, enjoyable.  Bit of a step back from Pirate's Curse - WayForward may not be living up to their name - but a nice few hours romping around anyway.

28668096.review:
Coming totally fresh into the series I have to say I enjoyed what I played. It's definitely not an amazing game, by any means, but it's good throughout, despite some issues.
This is a 2-D platformer that succeeds in bringing in some Metroidvania elements, to a certain extent.

Pros:
- Self-aware humor.
- Good level design.
- Colorful graphics and vivid animations.
- Lots of power-ups and transformations to play with.
- Soundtrack is catchy and memorable (for the most part).
- Doesn't overstay its welcome (around 7-7:30 hours, which is perfect for this type of game).

Cons:
- No map to see which places you've already explored in a specific level.
- Way too much backtracking.
- Obscure objectives.
- Some transformations are redundant, serving purpose for only few specific locations.
- Last stage has a rather big difficulty spike with poor checkpoint placement.
- Last boss fight is painfully slow and annoying,

Overall, the game is bigger than the sum of its parts. I did enjoy it and I would recommend it to anyone looking for a good platformer with some solid exploration elements.
It's a shame the last stage and boss weren't so good as it left me with a bitter taste, though.

7/10

28668007.review:
ゲームボーイカラーで発売された『シャンティ』以来、シリーズ4作目になる作品です。
前作、前前作である『Shantae: Risky's Revenge』と『Shantae and the Pirate's Curse』は
（単体でも遊べますが）話が続きになっていたのに対して、本作はどちらかというと
『Shantae: Risky's Revenge』の方のリブート版といった内容です。
シリーズを未プレイで本作からプレイしても大丈夫だと思われます。

内容としては動物や架空の生物に変身するダンスや魔法を駆使しながらマップを進み、
隠されたアイテムなどを探索していく、いわゆるメトロイドヴァニア系2Dアクションです。
新しいダンスや新しい能力を手に入れたら今まで行けなかった場所へ行き、
新たなアイテムを見つける・・・という繰り返しでゲームを進めていきます。

[ローカライズ]
今までの作品は英語のみでしたが、本作ではデフォルトで日本語UIとテキストが付きました。
ただ、正直結構怪しい部分が多く、一部直訳になっていたり前後の会話がつながっていない、
誤字脱字、[]が表示されたりしていますが、概ね話を理解するのには
困らない程度の日本語翻訳がなされています。

[レベルデザイン]
前作までよりも大幅に1マップの横幅が広がっています。シームレス化したのは良いのですが、
それ故に落下死するとかなり前に戻されるという場所がやや増えたようにも思います。
入手した能力を駆使しての探索要素は健在で、見えていても行けなかった場所に
後々戻ってきて行き、アイテムを回収する・・・という流れができるようによく考えられています。
シリーズでは消えるブロックを叩いて隠しマップへ・・・という場所が多かったですが、
本作ではそうした隠し通路はほとんどなくなっています。

[ダンス・魔法]
ダンスは今までの4種類だけではなく、8種類+オプション4種類+おまけという形に増えました。
バリエーションが増えたものの、コウモリとハーピィ、カニと人魚、一箇所でしか使い道のないクモなど
やや下位互換的だったり存在意義の薄いものもあります。
個人的にはラストステージでもうちょっと全要素を使わせてほしかったかも。
オプションの中にワープダンス（次のエリアに進む）があるのは純粋に評価できます。

魔法は今まで通り火・雷・鉄球の3種類に加え、防御魔法とおまけの魔法が増えました。
相変わらずパイクボール（鉄球）系がボス・雑魚問わず強いのに対し、
火の魔法は1度だけアイテム入手に使い、雷の魔法に至っては
1度も使わないで100%クリアできてしまいました・・・。

[操作性・アクション難易度]
グラフィックは変わりましたが相変わらず操作性はかなり良いです。
シャンティシリーズは割りと箱コンを前提に作っている部分があるので、
箱コンがあると快適に遊べるかと思います（キーボードだと結構やりにくい場面あり）
過去作では後ろを向いてバックダッシュを連打すると高速移動できるという
テクがありましたが、バックダッシュは大幅に弱体化されています。

難易度に関しては前作よりもかなり下がったように思います。
特に終盤シビアなアクションを要求される場所があるわけでもなく、
ボス戦もかなり簡単なので全体的な難易度としては前作、前前作と比べると一番簡単かも。

[まとめ]
シャンティシリーズはやったことがないけど興味はある、
オーソドックスな2Dアクションが好きという人にはオススメできます。
現在はシャンティモードのみが存在していますが、将来的にリスキィモードの
追加コンテンツがリリースされるとのこと（メニュー画面より）。

※補足：街の中にあるギャラリーはおまけではなく普通にゲームに絡んできます。
　関連で貰えるアイテムもあります。

28665025.review:
Pretty much the first Shantae game I ever completed and for good reason. This game involves a lot of backtracking, which is the reason I guess fans are disappoint. As a person who usually hates backtracking more than any other video game mechanic, I have to say this is the one of the few games that did it right.

Gameplay:
Pros-
As I tried to imply, I barely know much about Shantae or the gameplay so overall how I can describe this game as the love-child of the Paper Mario series and Donkey Kong Country. As I said, a 'lot' of the game revolves around backtracking, yet it honestly didn't feel at all like a chore. It flows well for this type of game as levels feel brand new or updated once you acquire more power ups and dances. My fear when I purchased this is that the animal dances were going to be used as gimmicks for obstacles and puzzles, but there are several situations where you can get through a level more efficiently than base Shantae.

Cons-
This game goes from delightfully challenging(while annoying on a few parts) to being way too easy. You'll get multiple hearts and food to keep them full forever later in the game, despite the x9 limit for each food. Combining her hair whip with the spike balls/scimitar magic could pretty much smash virtually every enemy away with ease. In fact, magic is immensely unbalanced in this game. You could literally just only purchase the weapon summoning and barrier magic then still beat the game with ease. The difficulty jump and lack of checkpoints can get annoying at times, if you fall off or run into a spike then 2-3 minutes of platforming is basically gone.

Story:
How can I describe it? It basically feels like a Saturday morning cartoon. I don't mean that in a negative or positive way. The dialogue feels witty and the characters keep the liveliness of the game going. Even though I found it funny, I actually felt characters taking catastrophic events to lightly to be rather museless about. The main characters seemed a bit cookie cutter, but they were solid through and through. Even though it was mostly Shantae doing the work, you enjoyed the moral support you was giving from your friends. It's hard to go too deep into it without spoiling. The town NPCs felt like characters in the beginning, but then they reverted into mere hint givers. Overall, I did find it awesome how a simple anti-monster Beacon turned into genie corrupting war machine.

Music:
Overall it was enjoyable to play through the game, but it didn't feel memorable aside from maybe the slide theme. Although, I can't get over Shantae dancing to the town theme.

Overall:
I give it a 7.5/10. Despite a lot of my nit-pickings(and a couple more I didn't mention without spoiling), there was nothing in this game that was game breaking. The platforming by itself is... decent. What saves the game is the versatile abilities and how you can use them to get through puzzles along with faster methods to defeat enemies. It also could've been 'much' longer, yet seeing how this is a Kickstarter game it's understand they had to use the funds they were given in such a little time.

28661108.review:
[u]Les plus :[/u]

- Beaux graphismes, visuellement très différent de ses prédécesseurs en pixel art (qui avaient aussi leur charme)

- (?) Potentiellement un style de jeu à base d'équipements de pirate façon Pirate's Curse en plus du style magique de Risky's Revenge (je développerai plus tard)

- (Tout le monde n'est pas concerné mais j'en parle quand même) Un speedrun Any% glitchless (il est important de préciser "glitchless", donc sans abus de bugs) qui semble intéressant (je précise que je n'ai pas encore regardé de speedrun, seulement débloqué le succès Steam un peu à l'improviste avec ma première partie pour seul routing)

- Une gallerie d'arts, bon honnêtement je me moque un peu des concept arts, mais une partie de la gallerie est dédiée aux fanarts, et ça, c'est plutôt rare de voir un jeu mettre en valeur sa communauté (autrement que par un multi en ligne hein)


[u]Les points neutres :[/u]

- Pas de donjon, c'est possible dans un "Metroidvania" (Metroid et Castlevania étant les précurseurs de ce style mais dans lesquels on se passe totalement de donjons), mais leur présence dans les autres jeux de la série n'étaient pas désagréables.

- L'humour. Pourquoi dans cette section et pas dans "les plus" ? Et bien parce que, comme à l'habitude de la série, c'est assez no-brain / sans logique en fait, et je comprends que tout le monde ne soit pas fan de ce genre, donc je préfère le mettre ici.

- Jeu assez court, personnellement j'ai mis 8h pour ma première partie à 100%, mais les Shantae sont des jeux aussi connus pour leurs speedruns, et c'est souvent plus agréable de faire un speedrun d'un jeu court (moins de 3h pour le 100%, donc beaucoup moins pour un any%) que d'un jeu long (coucou FF9 qui demande moins de 12h pour trouver Excalibur 2)

- Risky en personnage jouable, en neutre oui, car elle n'est pas encore disponible, et je préfère juste ne pas trop m'avancer en disant "ouais c'est trop cool ! un nouveau scénario et un autre style de gameplay !" ou bien "c'est nul ! il faut payer 20€ pour l'avoir !"


[u]Les moins :[/u]

- La version française... Absolument insupportable... C'est censé être un jeu tout public, et vas-y les "tête de con" et les "sale con" qui s'enchaînent sans raison, des personnages qui parlent à la place de leurs interlocuteurs et des fautes de frappe sur ABSOLUMENT TOUTES LES LIGNES DE DIALOGUE !
Et bien sûr, le siffler (et non le "siffleT") étant le premier objet de l'inventaire, les profs de français et autres fanatiques d'orthographe pourront s'arracher les yeux à chaque fois qu'ils ouvriront le menu Pause...
Non, le jeu n'est pas traduit par un étudiant random payé au black, mais ça aurait peut-être été moins choquant que de voir "Dys Translations" dans les crédits, une boîte spécialisée dans la traduction de jeux-vidéo qui recrute apparemment des "Dysléxiques"
*Badum tsss*

- Lorsque je parlais de speedrun plus haut, je disais qu'il était important de noter le "glitchless", je n'en aurai pas parlé sur Risky's Revenge ou Pirate's Curse, puisque je n'ai jamais eu affaire au moindre bug sur ces deux jeux, même en faisant des choses assez absurdes.
Dans 1/2 Genie Hero, danser ( = principale feature du jeu) juste avant de se faire toucher par un ennemi, ou même simplement tomber dans des pics peut déclencher un bug ! L'un peut rendre le personnage invisible jusqu'à faire certaines actions, bon ça éventuellement, si ça peut en faire marrer certains, pourquoi pas, mais la chute dans les pics qui ramène la première fois à l'entrée du niveau au lieu du dernier check point, puis la deuxième fois laisse la caméra dans un coin random du niveau et le personnage complètement ailleurs, ça c'est non... Et pourtant, je ne les ai pas cherché, ces bugs, j'y ai eu droit à ma première partie, en faisant le jeu normalement, sympa non ? ...

- Le farm... Hein ? Moi j'ai dit que c'était un jeu à faire en speedrun ? Ah oui pardon :D
Bref, oui, alors le farm d'argent, dans Shantae, c'est pas nouveau, il y a souvent des objets à acheter, que ce soit pour progresser dans l'aventure ou pour optimiser le speedrun, et dans les deux autres jeux, il y a souvent un personnage pour nous aider en nous offrant des sommes non négligeables (le chien de la cuistot et Bolo dans RR ou Sky dans PC), même si au final il faut toujours prendre quelques minutes à la fin du jeu pour farmer quand on veut faire le jeu à 100%.
Dans ce jeu, aucun personnage ne semble aider finacièrement, et pourtant je crois avoir parlé à tout le monde et à chaque moment du jeu, donc à moins que ça ne soit la "Navi-spoileuse" des bains (qui est le genre de perso avec qui je déteste parler), je ne vois pas. Donc obligé de farmer soi-même en cassant des pots ou en tuant des ennemis... Ah non pardon, les ennemis sont des gros radins, donc la seule solution reste de casser tous les pots qui passeront dans votre champs de vision.
Et bien sûr, le meilleur spot de farm ne vous sera pas accessible avant le fin du jeu, car la plupart des plateformes sont à des endroits où il n'est pas évident d'aller sans la dernière transformation, ce qui m'ammène au dernier point négatif, quand même moins conséquent que ces trois premiers :

- Les utilités des transformation pas vraiment équitables... C'est vrai quoi, c'est un peu le coeur du jeu, les tranformations, et pourtant, parmis les 8 transformations principales, 90% de votre temps de transformation dans une partie normale ça sera la souris et le crabe pour chercher les objets de quête, le singe pour simplifier les phases de plateforme, et éventuellement la harpie si vous faites un new game + pour skiper absolument tous les niveaux et optionnellement démolir les boss à coups de 20 pv par seconde
(Une petite pensée à la transfo' en araignée qui est super kawaii mais qu'on voit littéralement 2 minutes : très lente, level design quasi jamais adapté pour elle sauf rares cas particuliers, attaque à très faible DPS obtenue très tardivement et très grosse hit-box)



Pour traduire ma recommendation positive de ce jeu, je dirai que je ne regrette pas mon achat, mais que j'y réfléchirai à deux fois avant de me précipiter sur le prochain épisode...
