28658961.review:
Gioco platform molto carino, non esente da difetti ma non così drammatici da meritare una valutazione negativa. Un gioco fin troppo facile, che fa capire dalle trasformazioni che quasi saranno inutili nel gioco, perchè in alcuni casi saranno utili solo a prendere un oggetto o il pieno potenziale lo raggiungeranno solo alla fine quando sarà troppo tardi, che le ambizioni c'erano ma non i fondi necessari a portarle a termine. Lasciando un po' un senso di insoddisfazione poichè si vorrebbe di più dai livelli del gioco, dai personaggi secondari, e dalle abilità della genietta protagonista. Ma tutto dà quella sensazione di "ce li abbiamo messi dentro all'ultimo secondo, e meno male che ci siamo riusciti".
Il gioco però resta godibile e divertente, con una gran cura al comparto grafico che vanta animazioni 2D fluide e molto curate, musiche molto oriecchiabili, un umorismo efficace, e il carisma della mezzo genietta protagonista. Posso tranquillamente affermare che non sono affetto da nessun rimorso per questo acquisto. Anzi, piuttosto mi dispiace non aver partecipato alla campagna kickstarter.

Aggiornamento: Adesso è disponibile un nuovo livello di difficoltà. Perlomeno questo rende il gioco un po' più interessante per i giocatori che cercano un minimo di sfida. Per chi si considera un giocatore più o meno esperto è consigliato cominciare direttamente in questa modalità.

28658264.review:
Um exemplar peculiar dentro dessa franquia. 

Para começar o jogo não é um Metroidvania, como os títulos anteriores, mas sim um jogo de plataforma com mundos separados que emprega alguns elementos desse subgênero, como passagens que só podem ser abertas com determinadas habilidades (backtracking). Os visuais também são completamente diferentes do estilo tradicional da franquia, com um estilo completamente 2.5D, que no mínimo, é extremamente bonito. 

Os controles são precisos, com uma boa variedade em termos de habilidades e itens. Já a narrativa não foge muito do humor padrão da franquia, mas é muito melhor apreciada por veteranos, já que o título faz pouco para apresentar o mundo e seus personagens para o jogador, partindo do pressuposto que são velhos conhecidos.

E como todo jogo, este também apresenta a sua dose de problemas. O principal deles é a curta duração do jogo, para termina-lo em 100% (todas as conquistas, New Game+, Speedrun, etc...), são necessárias não mais do que oito horas, tornando-o um dos jogos mais curtos da franquia. A dificuldade também é bastante amena, especialmente após a acquisição de um determinado item, que pode, literalmente, tornar o jogador imune a qualquer tipo de dano não letal (espinhos, buracos e lava ainda te matam). 

Mas como um conjunto, esse é um jogo que vale a pena ser apreciado, especialmente para fãs da franquia.

28657108.review:
とりあえず全実績解除したのでキーボード操作で遊んだ感触を…
 
　今作では変身とダンスが復活し、変身･ダンスの種類は12種にまでボリュームアップした。加えて、ダンスの仕様は2から変更され、振付が変わらないまま最大4種*3パターンのパネルが切り替わり、プレイヤーは表示されている4つのパネルから一つを選んで変身するというものになった。使用頻度の高い変身のうち2つは2つ目のパターンに配置されているため、使いたいときに使いたいフォームが選択できないというストレスが常にかかるようになったほか、パネルの配置をある程度頭に入れておかねば新しい変身を覚えたてのうちは使いたいフォームを選ぶ前にパターンが切り替わることも度々起こり得る。変身アクションの追加に伴い、Shantae3でせっかく解決したプレイヤーが自然と操作に慣れる機会をステージ中に盛り込むということも難しくなった。アクションの難易度を下げることでShantae2ほどの難易度ではなくなったものの、セクションの初めからやり直しとなるトラップの頻度が上がっているため、結果的にストレスの度合いは差し引きゼロとなっている。
　また、システム周りでは攻撃キーと調べるキーはそれぞれ独立してバインドできるが一部互換する。その一方でキャンセルキーを互換するキーはなく、ショップを素早く抜けるにはいちいちバックスペース、メニュー画面を抜けるにはESCを押さなければならない。さらにボタン周りではキャラクターセレクトを完了するまでは互換するはずの攻撃キーではゲームを開始することすら叶わない。他にはマップセレクトやセーブ時に聞かれる『Yes / No』であるが、この順番が状況次第で変わる。マップセレクトへ移行する際は『Yes / No』だが、マップ移動時のセーブは『No / Yes』、任意でセーブするときは『Yes / No』の順となっており、それぞれデフォルトのカーソル位置も異なる。
　思い出による補正も強いと思うものの、Shantae3の出来が良すぎた分だけあってシナリオにもステージにも期待外れだった部分は大きい。特定の変身を使用している間はそれなりに再現性の高いスタック現象があるため、DLC、パッチを待ってからでも購入は遅くないと思われる。

28649141.review:
Everybody's favorite Half-Genie Hero is back and Ret-2-Go! She's dancing her way through the danger with a variety of forms, spells, and items--but does it hold up compared to the former entries?

Mostly, yes. Let's start off with some pros.

PROS: 

*The new art design is absolutely gorgeous, with painstaking attention paid to both the animation fidelity and character design. Sequin Land and its people have never looked so good. 

*Core gameplay is still superb: jump, whip your hair back and forth, and dodge what you can as you make your way through levels and discover hidden secrets with the help of any shapeshifting forms you happen to pick up along the way (and after). If you've played a Shantae game before? You'll feel right at home.

*As always, the soundtrack is a joy to listen to. Nothing more to say on that--the music is great!

*If you're a fan of the usual dialogue found in a Shantae game--wacky, weird, and sometimes a little 4th Wall-Breaking with a veritable drenching of saccharine Feel Good Vibes--then you're in for a treat. It's not gonna make you think on the existential crisis that plagues us all, but hey, it'll warm your heart and probably get you to crack a smile. Just as good, right?

But, no game is perfect. So let's look at some cons.

CONS:

*While the backtracking you'd come to expect from Shantae, or any Metroidvania for that matter, is still present? It feels cut down, streamlined, and less rewarding than before. While you'll amass over a dozen new forms that get your hips shaking, most of them are rarely used for more than bit puzzles--and then they're never really needed again. Mermaid, Monkey, and Harpy eventually become your main forms, and the rest are kind of left hanging.

*While the dialogue remains as endearing as ever, the main storyline itself feels somewhat disconnected from the actual theme it's trying to convey. There are also elements that're introduced, but addressed in a manner that feels lacking--looking at you, Holly.

*While the UI itself is very comfortable, the menu screen suffers from some clutter issues that were a minor irritation. Items you wouldn't think to use again--like the previous ranks of your damage upgrades--are kept in the inventory as toggles, so you can weaken yourself by choice. Still, that's a case of "Your Mileage May Vary." I could see somebody using those toggles as self-inflicted "hard mode" conditions.

*It's not long. I clocked in at around seven hours to complete the main campaign, though there's the additional Hero mode to tackle for fun--you get to start a new game with all of your main forms.

Shante: Half-Genie Hero isn't -better- than the previous games, but despite some minor gripes and irritations, I find it still holds up rather well to former iterations of the series. There's also the point that DLC will be introduced at a later date which may shake up some of my points. If it does? I'll revise my review to accommodate.

Still, if you're looking for a simple "buy it or not" deal? Go ahead and buy it. It's good, simple fun that's worth the price of admission.

28646310.review:
Well, here's to a monkey paw wish. For the record, I was a Kickstarter backer.

Shantae: Half-Genie hero is a big step forward visually from its predecessors... and a smaller step back gameplay-wise. In general, the game looks gorgeous. Though Crybringer's redesigns are jarring compared to the the previous game, they hold up well animated. The animations are fantastic, though there's less variety than there was in Pirate's Curse, perhaps owing the new engine.

In terms of speed and flow, this game feels like it's slightly slower than Pirate's Curse. There are more transformations, but many are just so situational you won't find yourself using them widely - most are just keys to open locks, with only a few serving as general use, and another few literally just existing to generate powerups or the like. Magic has been nicely expanded, with a third level for most of the spells. However, one issue is that it simply overdoes it in terms of upgrades - even early upgrades can trivialize things like health loss, whether it's just reducing damage or being able to generate health and healing items on a whim. One even lets you generate cash, leaving your ability to purchase upgrades down to your patience. Worst of all is the item you get for collecting all the gallery keys, which may as well have "CHEATING MODE ACTIVATED" in big red letters, making a number of the final boss battles trivial. If you want challenge out of Half-Genie Hero, it's only self-enforced - the menu at least lets you switch off most of the upgrades if you like.

Enemies are no longer of the "stop-go" nature from previous reviews, and in general the enemy design is nicely varied, with a number of really great boss fights with varied styles... save for the final boss, which was an annoying slog for me. In general, though, fighting enemies is pleasant and there's more use for the varied spells against them than previous games (which mostly boiled down to "spike ball or nothin'").

Collecting is, of course, a core element, and it teeters between reward and annoyance. I found myself revisiting levels a lot to get this or that geegaw or power, and the game enforces it a bit to pad its relatively short number of levels. While most of these trips aren't too laborious, towards the end I started to resent having to dig for the last few chunks. There's a lot of keys for various locks to open up Metroid-style, and slightly too many in my estimation.

The story is almost episodic, reflecting the varied plots promised in the kickstarter, and a lot of the side stories are much more clever than the main plot. The dialogue is often genuinely funny and sharp, and does make me wish for voices on account of it. The climax, however, is cliched to the point of being painful. I understand they probably wanted to get back to basics... but it features a twist you'll likely see coming from the very start of the game, and a pretty bad one at that.

It should be noted that the extra playable characters aren't finished yet. Presumably they'll be DLC to non-backers in the future, but it's not clear. In general, the game isn't long - it took me about 9 hours to do 100% completion without any guides or tips at all. It doesn't overstay its welcome, and I didn't mind that at all. Presumably when the extra characters / modes are completed, they'll add to the length of the game for better or worse.

Ultimately, despite my criticism, I really enjoyed my time with Half-Genie Hero, though I don't feel much of a need to revisit it. It's a pretty fun ride over all, with a very appealing look, solid controls and innovations... but also is the sort of step back you often see with a new engine like this. As such, go into it expecting some flaws, but it's worth getting into if you've enjoyed the previous games or want a light, colorful platforming adventure. Just bear in mind it's got a few kinks.

Well, literally speaking it has a few kinks. It could just be me, but some things seem coded for certain corner fetish communities (some subtle, some not). It's nothing I wouldn't let a child see (nothing on the level of Pirate's Curse's waterfall scene), but if you detect some weirdness here and there, it's probably not just you.

That's a note to close on, isn't it? I think it is.

28640517.review:
Half genie hero is a great game, in terms of platformers and metroidvania games it is up there as one of the best, but as a Shantae game, it feels more like Shantae 2.5, which is puzzling seeing as we have a true Shantae 3 (pirates curse).

Pirates curse was always going to be a hard act to follow, pirates curse became a 10/10 game by abandoning a lot of what made Shantae and replacing it with a new system that was much better, the dancing transformations are for sure unique, but even as fast as they are here it still unnaturally broke up the gameplay whereas the pirate gear in the previous game flowed in seamlessly.

Compounding the issue is the story, pirates curse was a much grander tail that did a lot to build out the world and its characters, a lot of big elements are introduced in pirates curse such as Shantaes farther, the history of rottytops and her brothers, the humanising of risky, hell buy the end of pirates curse Shantae had seemingly developed feelings for risky, I was sure that would all be built on here but it's not, instead we get a more episodic day in the life of Shantae style story, which works on its own especially for first timers, but as a sequel to pirates curse, the lack of continuity is maddening.

Before I played this game I didn't know if it was a prequel or a sequel, and the fact I still don't know is a bad sign.

But despite that, I had a blast, if you like platformers or metroidvanias this is one of the best, but just don't expect it to be better than pirates curse.

28639089.review:
El juego es muy bueno, presenta paisajes coloridos, controles que responden como deben, personajes carismaticos, el diseño de nivel es realmente bueno, animacion hermosa, pero tiene una filosofia muy clara, "De lo bueno poco" y es ese el problema mas grande que tiene este juego, es muy corto.

Practicamente el juego te lo puedes pasar en una tarde, tampoco es que pida mucho al juego y que me dure 40 horas, pero practicamente pase mas tiempo rejugando niveles encontrando sus secretos, que por cierto son pocos niveles a disponibilidad.

Ahora si hablamos de su historia, personalmente opino que en la Saga Shantae la historia no tiene mucha relevancia mas que contextualizarte a lo siguiente que debes hacer, ya que en si la historia no es lo mas emocionante del mundo, te ponen una problematica, te dicen necesito este objeto, hablas con los NPC para que te den pistas de donde puede estar, vas, lo obtienes y continuas con tu historia, basicamente es asi el juego. Wayfoward pudo haber aprovechado mas la historia y hacerla mas profunda o mas larga, pero es muy basica.

Como mencione anteriormente, el juego tiene personajes muy carismaticos, por ejemplo Squid Baron, es un pulpo rojo que quiere ser un villano majestuoso, y eso lo lleva a enfrentarse  con nuestra heroina, inclusive al final de su batalla rompe la cuarta pared, para decir que el sabe que esta en un videojuego y que ojala este juego tenga un Spin-off con el como personaje principal.

Sus niveles son plataformeros, con un toque de metroidvania, ya que cada nivel tiene sus secreto que algunos no podras obtenerlos cuando estes por primera vez en el nivel, los enemigos son variados, los jefes son originales y un tanto desafiante.

¿Recomiendo este juego?
La respuesta es si, es un muy buen juego de plataformas, y cumple con su objetivo el cual es entretener, te hara pasar un buen rato, quizas te saque unas risas, ademas de que viene en español, aunque su traduccion no es la mejor que digamos ya que tiene algunos problemas de semantica, pero por lo general se entiende y hace amena la experiencia.

28638560.review:
I would say this game is overall very good. It was a tough task to follow up the Pirates Curse, and I didn't expect a masterpiece.

First of all, the music and graphics are simply great. The trailer gives you a pretty good impression of what this was going to be in that regard and I'm really loving it. The gameplay feels smoother overall than previous entries and they improved on the transformations, making the process less time consuming.

That said, the transformations are my first big negative. We get a mix of old and new, but really they  break the flow of the game. That's an issue previous games had already, but it feels a lot more pronounced in this one. If you want to move efficiently through levels you will change forms a lot, and that can be a bit annoying at times. Not terrible, but I would say the older games handled this better, probably because this one has more transformations, and quite a few aren't really that useful.
Similarly the backtracking feels worse in this one, probably because you only have 5 leveles plus Risky's Hideout. Going back to the same level, with minor changes when you enter the 2nd time, over and over just doesn't feel satisfying. Even worse every level basically consists of 2 main screens with secrets dispersed in between them plus a boss battle.
The biggest issue for me is that everything feels so segmented. The stories of the bosses don't really have anything to do with the main plot, the levels, due to the select screen, feel just like that: levels and not a connected world. I just feel like they could have done a lot better by connecting the villains and give us pointless connection roads. Yes they take more time and can be annoying, but they make the gameworld feel connected.

The levels themselves are absolutely great. They just feel well designed and fun to play, if you weren't forced to play them quite as often (if you want to get 100% of course). The bosses are also very creative, and some kind of boss rush at the end would have been really fun.

Overall, I would certainly recommend this game to anyone who likes fun platformers. It's a little too easy for my tastes and could be better, but it's fun and that's what matters the most.

28633646.review:
SPOILERS ALERT
Like almost everyone here, I was eagerly waiting for the release of this game.
I played every Shantae game in the series and and had many expectations for this last one,
I was drooling when reading goals on Kikcstarter achieved one by one and naturally an ideal game picture was
drawn in my head, a picture of a game that at least does not give in to it's previous incarnation, the brilliant 
Shantae and the Pirate's Curse. A game with the budget of almost 800,000 USD. 
I have never been so wrong... 

Graphics
From the very first time I played Shantae, I loved the concept and dreamed it to become an HD.
Partially my wishes became true in RR and PC but that only involved sprites, not the actual universe.
I like the graphics in HGH, it looks refreshing, though somewhat lacking in magic previous games had.
I especially like the the job devs did on some of the Shantae's forms such as Mermaid and Spider, they look adorable. 
Some of my complaints lie in character animations, they are almost noexistent. Whatever happens during a dialogue, 
Sky is smiling happily, Risky dances, Bolo remains pokerface etc. It especially strikes your eye during a scene when Shantae turns dark and they come for help. I don't think it is a very difficult job to change a facial expression since it's HD and it would contribute greatly to a scenes' emotional impact. 

Music 
Music is wonderful. Kaufman knows his job well. 

Plot 
This is what actually disappoints me and what makes me give the game a thumb down.
During the whole course of the game an impression stuck with me that devs had some great ideas which they failed (or didn't want) to implement for some reason. The plot seems rushed, teared and incompleted. No character development at all.
New charactes appear to be tossed away right after their debut. Main Shantae friends could have more impact on the story. I'll give an example.
- In the very first stage - mermaid falls, Bolo catches up to Shantae and complains he is always left out of her adventures.
It was a great reference to the previous game but unfortunately it didn't go anywhere.
There is a couple of funny moments with him in this episode, but after that he doesn't play any significant role at all.
- The same thing with Rotty, I have an impression the devs had no idea how to insert her into the plot and just got away by giving her some nominal role. Abner and Poe are introduced and forgotten.
- An episode with Shantae taken over by dark magic just cried for a fight with her dark self or an extra level "inside her",
don't get me wrong, the thing her friends coming to her rescue is great but still a lot of potential is lost.
- The new "villain" Holly was downright pathetic. Her reasons ridiculous, dialogues far-fetched, character - bad guy cliche. It was a real challenge to beat the boss with a palm on my face. 
- Moreover I was negatively suprised when I discovered it was actually a "bonus chapter" (along with the cape crustacean) inserted in the story because the kickstarter goal was achieved. 
Would would be left of the game without those? Bonus chapter should be BONUS and usually after you BEAT the game or can be completed optionally, but here it is an integral part of the story. I don't oppose this approach, just don't call it BONUS. Call it: "Initially we planned to make the game 4 hours long, but since you funded it we will make it 8".
- The game has two endings and they differ by a couple of lines. If the whole genie realm was destoyed, Shantae will say something like: "Well, that's a bummer." and Mimic like: "Well, maybe it wasn't". 
Yes, I know it is a kind fairy-tale and there is no place for heavy dramatic moments but this very ending should motivate a player to search for a better one, but it doesn't.

Difficulty
Too casual. It does give you some challenge in the beginning, but once you have a bikini and 4+ hearts you dont really care to avoid attacks at all. Some people complained the last boss to be very difficult, but when you have invincibility magic what difficulty are you talking about??? I really like easy games, when I don't have to smash break the gamepad and just enjoy the gameplay, but there must be balance between difficulty and enjoyability, which this game definitely lacks.

Conclusion.
I, as a fan of the series, am very disillusioned because the potential the series had was destroyed by this game.
Maybe the DLCs will brighten things up a bit but we'll have to pay for them which highlights the desire to only earn money, not caring much about their product. 
I'll repeat myself, as I was going through the game it seemed to me the devs had great ideas but right after the beginning they decided to save budget, which I don't understand. They raised twice they pledged + income from release, did they only care to make it "ok" but not "great"?
 
Well, it was just my personal opinion, there are tons of positive reviews, so I probably just dramatized a lot.
Agree or not? Comments are welcome.

28627941.review:
This is a fun little metroidvania-type title. It's not an especially long or difficult game, but the different abilities are cool and add new dimensions to traversing the levels (except Spider. I like the design but I'm not really sure how useful it is outside of one instance where it's necessary). I also like that it's fairly short because it makes backtracking to use those new abilities much less tedious than it could otherwise have been.

It controls well, the art direction is charming, and the songs are all nice. The voice acting is good although there isn't much of it, which is fine; it's not something I need in every game and I would have been fine without it. I also like the fact that you can 'adjust' the difficulty in-game by turning on or off your different power-ups; for example, something you can unlock later is unlimited magic as well as an invicibility spell which can make the last few bosses rather trivial, but if you feel like challenging yourself or 'doing it right' you can just turn off the relic and activate one of the lesser forms of the spell.

In short, I recommend it.

+ More transformations than all the previous games combined; and a well-implemented dance menu.
+ The bath lady gives free hints so that you don't get stuck for too long.
+ The whistle and warp dance make it very easy to either leave a level or skip a certain part so you don't have to do the same platforming over and over each time you revisit a level.
+ Giantess mermaid boss with "plot" to spare! (Did I mention she's chained up too?)


Tossup:
+/- You can purchase invincibility magic and later on get unlimited magic to effectively make it last forever. This makes the game (and especially the final boss) brain-dead easy as long as you are competent at platforming. 

Cons:
- No dungeons: a big departure from the series' norm.
- Too many types of collectibles and not enough worlds to really do all that collecting justice.
- Spider transformation, Spider Venom, and Bat Sonar are barely used at all in this game.
- Story is a bit shallow with no serious conflict and little exposition until the very end. 
- Boss designs could be a lot better

It appears that Shantae and the Pirate's Curse, the game that preceded this one, set the bar juuuust a little too high for WayForward. Half-Genie Hero may have gotten some negative reviews for not living up to it's predecessor, but I'll give it a pass since I enjoyed it anyways.


I rate 7/10 
Definitely worth it if you're a Shantae fan, but not mind-blowing.




All achievements get update *MILD SPOILERS*:

This game is very easy to speed run. The time limit for any% is around 3 hours and 100% is probably around 4 hours. Hero mode makes both of these extremely easy, but I've also seen some more dedicated runners get both achievments in a single playthrough on regular mode. 

The final boss (a total of 3 phases) is pretty lackluster. The first phase is a callback to the first Shantae game where you fight Risky in a one-on-one battle. The next two phases are really boring and are super easy to beat. The "Harpy Gauntlet" heading up to those bosses was a much more satisfying challenge. I can't say I was too impressed with the other boss designs either. In previous games, they forced you to fight them using your newly acquired upgrades/transformations. The bosses in this game basically just force you to tank damage and go all out with lots of magic attacks and health potions... not very smart or creative. 

There is also a really random difficulty spike in platforming in the third level "Tassel Town," which is then followed by one of the easiest bosses. Seriously, I died more to the platforming in this one level than all other things in the game combined!

28614867.review:
Il tanto atteso sequel di Shantae Pirate's Curse è finalmente arrivato dopo una lunghissima attesa! Creare un seguito ad un gioco perfetto come Pirate's curse non è un'impresa facile, ma Wayforward è riuscita a confezionare un ottimo sequel! LA cosa che fin da subito mi ha preoccupato è stato il radicale cambiamento dello stile grafico, scartando la pixel art fantastica dei primi capitoli per passare a uno stile 2.5D molto simile a Ducktales Remastered. Per quanto gli ambienti risentino di un design abbastanza squadrato e poco organico, i fondali sono fantastici e i design dei personaggi sono troppo adorabili! Mi sono innamorato a prima vista di questo stile non appena iniziato a giocare e la colonna sonora di Jake Kaufman è la ciliegina sulla torta per un ottima presentazione. Shantae è ritornata in possesso dei suoi poteri e si ritrova come sempre immersa nella sua routine di proteggere Sequin Land da pirati e cattivi di ogni tipo. La trama è forse la parte del gioco che pare più affrettata, ci sono svariati punti dove sembra che sia stata un pò tagliuzzata per questioni di tempo ed è un vero peccato. PEr quanto un gioco sia sempre un platform con una componente esplorativa, è stata rimossa la componente Metroidvania dei titoli precedenti, per un approccio più lineare e concentrato sul platforming, vi sono comunque molti power up nascosti che spingeranno i più cleptomani ad esplorare ogni punto dello schermo, quindi anche gli appassionati dello stile Metroidvania hanno qualcosina su cui aggrapparsi. Shantae è più ricca che mai di poteri e trasformazioni in questo gioco, alcuni molto sottosviluppati, altri molto utili e alcuni che sono talmente overpower da spezzare il gioco in due! Se volete godervi Half Genie Hero senza renderlo incredibilmente facile, il consiglio migliore che posso darvi è fare una run ignorando totalmente l'esplorazione, oppure evitando di usare potenziamenti overpower. 
Il gioco inoltre offre nuove modalità di gioco con diversi personaggi, i quali saranno in arrivo in futuro come contenuto scaricabile gratuito, ciascuno con il loro stile di gioco che offrirà un incredibile rigiocabilità per coloro che hanno apprezzato questo titolo. C'è da dire, per quanto non lo considero un seguito superiore a Pirate's Curse, Half Genie Hero è comunque un ottimo seguito per la serie di Shantae, nonostante gli evidenti tagli subiti durante la produzione. Se siete nuovi della saga, questo e Pirate's Curse sono i titoli da cui cominciare!

28608632.review:
SUMMARY: A fun, colorful metroidvaina-esque platformer with a lot of personality.  Though heir to a fan favorite series, it stands out pretty well on its own and shows a lot of crafting.  There's a few issues of polish and levels of difficulty, but the overal experience is very enjoyable.

I Kickstarted this game.  Not because I was actually into the series, but as a lot of friends were, and were thrilled to see it returning.  I figured "what the heck" and tossed some money into the pot.

Fast forward to now, and the results of a non-fan of the game?  Pretty damn good.

Shantae is a platform-heavy metroidvania type game.  Start in a town, go to various areas on missions.  Complete missions, find new abilities, return to other areas to find stuff and use abilities, repeat.  Unlock new areas and new treasures.  It's a standard formula we all love.

So let's see how it breaks down.

PRESENTATION: The game is colorful and fun, with great graphics and soundtrack.  Characters have plenty of personality.  The game's look and feel is excellent.

GAMEPLAY: Gameplay is very old-school and there's a heavy emphasis on exploring the environment and platforming timing. If you're not ready for it, it may be a bit of a shock.  When you "get" it then the game really comes together.

CHARACTER GROWTH: Shantae basically A) finds new dances to transform into things, B) Buys spells and some combat upgrades, B) gets increased health.  It's not exactly complicated - the dances are the important part as they give you access to new areas.

PUZZLES: Though the need to re-return to areas can be annoying,the different abilities you unlock make them easier to navigate, and help you access hidden areas.  A few times you'll have an "aha" moment and figure out how to solve something and get a real rush from it.

STORY: The story seems to be more of a "Shantae's greatest hits gets the band back together" so you're not getting Game of Thrones or Dragon's Age here.


If there's a flaw to the game, its some of it feels a tad disjointed, from varied difficulty to a grand adventure suddenly turning into a fetchquest that feels like it should have been optional.  It's a minor concern, but it did stand out for me.

So do you buy it?
1) If you're a fan, judging by the game's quality AND the fans I know you either should or already did, and I'm shocked you read this far.
2) If you like colorful old-school patformers you'll probably enjoy this.
3) It'd make a GREAT gift for a friend who liked old-school platformers.

Who shouldn't buy it?
1) If you don't like platformers, really, don't.  This game will make you angry.
2) If you're not up for a game that involves repeating levels several times and poking around in their corners.

28598286.review:
Transform! Transform~ Trans…form…
---------------------------------------------------------------------
更快的节奏，更流畅的动作，同样逗趣的对话和情节，高清化和3D化的漂亮画面，更多的变身能力，更好听的音乐，出色的平台跳跃和谜题，大大降低的难度下限，Shantae: Half-Genie Hero是一部令人叹为观止的系列新作，同时也是一场欢乐十足的冒险。

60帧，高分辨率，对应的就是游戏节奏的“快”和画面的“细”。诚意十足的场景和人物重制一眼就能看出，去除了像素化的朦胧美之后的动作重制也更加生动。Shantae系列终于从半吊子类银河战士变成了只带少量类银河战士要素的关卡式平台跳跃，而带来的就是游戏节奏的大大加快。肚皮舞变身、魔法切换的操作非常简洁方便，操作的反应我感觉比起前作更加顺畅。游戏中的各种机制比如平台消失更加迅速、沙尘暴的短暂间隔都在鼓励玩家不停的向前跑。直观的说，在HGH中你很难找到一些平台跳跃中“等一个石矶”或者Metroidvania中走回头路的地方，即使需要timing，也是眨眼之间一气呵成。想想第一部Shantae中默认的移动方式甚至还是走路。能把这个特性是慢节奏的肚皮舞的游戏做的这么刺激和流畅，Wayforward的下的工夫和精力可想而知。然后带来的可能就是这个游戏不frustrating了，更加亲不那么硬核的玩家，有利有弊吧。

流程偏短，内容不算很少，关卡设计瑜不掩瑕。这部的流程前期惊艳，后期有点乏力。开始的几个关卡非常棒，新的人声主题曲下的系列传统“Scuttle Town又被袭击了！”是个不错的开头，之后的人鱼工厂荒诞新奇，沙塔逃生挺刺激但是感觉不如哦日的银之树逃生令人印象深刻，飞毯大赛可能是最好的一个关卡，层层递进节奏紧凑，很有想象力也很幽默。之后的关卡就乏力了，短而且内容少，印象不深。最后一关像海盗诅咒中一样仍然是对各种能力掌握的一个检验。但是我个人感觉可能因为能力太多，这个关卡很多地方意义不明，做的并不优秀。说到能力太多，把这么多变身能力塞到相对较短的流程中，不炸已经是万幸了，但还是显得冗余。所以我们会遇到有一个能力升级只用来解一个房间的谜题，开一个箱子。有的能力升级甚至沦为鸡肋，完全用不着。其他的一些招牌变身运用少了很多：Monkey Bullet是我在Risky复仇中非常喜欢的一个能力，在HGH中用上的次数屈指可数。所幸这些要用到能力解谜和收集的地方，做的真是不错，有一些设计非常独创和新颖，可以说是Super fun。

Shantae: HGH是我今年最期待的游戏，我之所以寄予厚望主要应该就是Risky复仇到海盗诅咒的这段进步，系统和游戏机制的进步是一方面（不过Risky复仇作为类银河战士那个地图设计真的太meh了，提升空间本来就有点大），更加让我惊喜的是人物刻画有了一点复杂化的趋势，几乎所有角色在海盗诅咒中都丰满了很多，Sky经过结婚风波后直爽的可靠朋友形象更加深入，Rotty的灵魂和Shantae的对话也表现了傻呵呵的表面下更复杂的感情，次要反派是奠定基本设定，博人一笑。当然坠吸引人的还是七大海女王的人物发展。而在这部HGH中，人物基本又回到了之前的水平。各个反派出来走过场，仍然是败事有余的傻蛋，Risky又干起了没有创意的邪恶勾当，Shantae的朋友们又回退到第二部的状态，所有第三部的人物发展都无迹可寻。这部的剧情包括主线和支线也毫无感染力，整个游戏的剧情更像一部三流卡通连续剧的一集，讲道理的地方没有说服力，煽情的地方比较尴尬，完全没有第三部的那些动人的时刻。所幸逗趣的人物和对白还是一脉相承的风格，一些桥段也足够新奇，但是剧情真的毫无感染力。

Shantae: Half-Genie Hero仍然是个很有诚意很优秀的游戏，也是Wayforward能做好这个系列的能力证明。不用怀疑，这个游戏能带给你相当多的惊喜和很纯粹的乐趣，但是也不能说没有遗憾。我仍然很后悔没早点知道这个系列去众筹当Backer，[strike]这样就有免费的dlc了[/strike]。总之不管续作再怎么改动，我相信有紫发半精灵英雄的游戏还会是一个欢声笑语充满个性的独特作品。

Overall a very fun game with solid controls in which you start out really weak and get exteremly broken by the end of the game...so much so that you feel invinicbile (i dont think i ever died in this game and came the cloest to dying on the first level due to how weak shantae starts out)

unlike most games of this genre, when you beat a boss you get a new transformation then usually you have to backtrack through a level you beaten again to find more upgrades (and this isnt optional the game halts and forces you to do this to continue the story and it happens every time)...this may sound like a negative but since you just got a new transfomation and became even stronger, it wont seem like backtracking through a stage and you might find optional upgrades to make the rest of the game even easier...

and thats the charm of the game, you really feel the progression of the main character who starts out super weak with very traditional moveset you will see in most platformers then slowly start breaking the mold once you start finding upgrades and start going back to levels that gave you headaches in the past and just watch them get broken apart due to your new abilites.

Also you eventually get a warp spells so you can skip unneccary parts of a level to find that 1 upgrade or part you need in a level you already beaten and you can leave the level at anytime you want if you gotten everything you need...

it does become super easy at the end when you can go invinicbile at will, fly over the whole stage, and have so many heart containers that theres no way the enemy can kill you but ya you sorta earned that right? though hard work and upgrading yourself...its not a hard game in the slightest but its so much fun when you are so strong at the end of the game and it feels justified with all the time you spent on making shantate stronger...

Lastly this game is getting dlc to extend the gameplay later on...and its not just skins...its new playable characters with unique gameplay styles and their own storylines so you have something to look forward too...and this game rewards speedruns so if you thought it was so easy by the end...try going for the achivements, some requiring you to speedrun the game...

28592745.review:
While it falls short of previous Shantae-games, it's still quite the fun game and there's currently more to come (I believe there's a Risky Boots addition coming along). The art style alone makes the game worth the money. Game play is responsive and fluid, no major hiccups and as is usual you're able to chose your upgrades freely (magic or pure damage). The game is quite short though, beware.

It's way easier to navigate than earlier games and there's more places to save your game - so if you haven't played any Shantae-games earlier this could be a good place to start. Though you will probably miss out on some of the jokes that's been carried since the very beginning.

The only real negatives about this game is the lack of dungeons. Those were fun in previous titles. But since this whole game is built on instanced content and each level is a form of a dungeon which you'll need to do several times in order to unlock more and more of it - it's my favourite metroidvania-style-type of game series.

Casual playthrough: 7h~ est.
100% playthrough: 8h~est.
100% steam achievements: 11h~ est.

28592384.review:
A very polished Metroidvania platformer.
Art, animation, music, gameplay, everything is solid.

Took me about 7 hours to hit 100% on my first playthrough, so not terribly long, but there is more story content being added down the road and replayability seems pretty good.

Had an absolute blast playing this, (first Shantae title I've fully played through) and I'll definitely be playing older titles because of it. (Note that the story in this game does not depend on prior knowledge from past games.)

Backed on Kickstarter, and WayForward met my expectations. One of those not-so-often scenarios where the crowdfunding campaign actually delivers exactly what you were hoping for.

28588075.review:
원래 정식 출시 이후 리스키 부츠 모드가 나오면 하고 나서 적을려고 했는데 1월에야 나온다고 해서 지금 적습니다.
본 평가는 블로그에 썼던 리뷰를 기반으로 작성되었습니다. [url=http://jm01049.blog.me/220886994989]포스팅 링크[/url]

[h1]그래픽, 음악[/h1]
2013년 펀딩당시 하이파이브 하고 나란히 걷던 백은 2D 기술이 딸린다는 핑계로 조약한 3D그래픽으로 가버렸지만 샨테는 그렇지 않았습니다. 2DLive 스럽지만 자체 제작을 통한 부드럽고 자연스러운 모션, 깔끔하고 스무스한 풍경, 테마별로 어우러지는 음악까지. 당연하겠지만 시리즈 사상 최고의 그래픽과 음악을 선사한다고 볼 수 있습니다. 

[h1]더욱 간결해진 클리어 동선[/h1]
샨테 시리즈는 대대적으로 100% 타임어택을 도전과제화 시킨 시리즈이기도 합니다. 그런 만큼 곧곧에 숨겨진 요소를 넣었고 그 요소를 빠르게 찾기 위해서는 동선의 최적화가 필요했죠. 하지만 이젠 그럴 이유가 별로 없습니다. 편하게 1회차 클리어를 하고 이후 해금되는 히어로 모드를 통해 주요 변신을 가지고 시작하며 이 모드를 통해도 정상적인 도전과제 달성이 가능하게 만들었습니다. 거기에 일일히 던전문을 열기 위해 애쓸 필요없이 지도만 있다면 곧바로 스테이지를 시작하는 배려까지. 게임의 낮은 난이도와 함께 도전과제에 목말라하는 분께 추천하는 바입니다.

[h1]불분명한 스토리관련 떡밥[/h1]
개인적으로는 좀 아쉬운 부분이였습니다. 왜냐하면 지난 작품, 특히 바로 전작에서 샨테의 과거나 리스키와의 관계에 대한 떡밥이 나온바있는데 이번작에서는 이런 요소가 상당수 다루질 않는점에서 아쉽다는 생각이 듭니다. 어쩌면 외전격 스토리인지도 모르겠고요. 아직은 샨테 편만 있는 만큼 차후 등장할 리스키 모드나 볼로, 스카이, 로티탑스를 다루는 히어로 모드에선 전작까지의 스토리에서 뭔가 나아가는게 있다면 좋겠습니다.

[h1]춤의 퇴화?[/h1]
아마 이건 초대작부터 해오거나 본 사람은 처절하게 느낄 부분인데 일단 춤은 역대 최다 등장입니다. 그런데 어찌된건지 마법 춤이 마지막으로 등장한 리스키의 복수편에서 보다 춤동작의 수가 적습니다. 가장 초라했던 초대작에선 커멘드별로 있는 동작과 리듬이 있다는걸 생각해볼때 몇 안되는 비판점이 될 수 있다고 봅니다. 다음 작부터는 다체로운 춤을 추는 샨테를 볼 수 있기를 바랍니다.

[h1]최종 결론[/h1]
요약하자면 한층 발전화 그래픽과 음악, 최적화된 게임성, 아쉬운 슽토리, 춤의 부재를 꼽을 수 있겠습니다. 저는 개인적으로 추천합니다. 이 게임이 좋은 선택이 되길 빕니다.

28585023.review:
Before I begin, I will let you know that I have played both Risky's Revenge and the Pirates Curse (both prequels). And Although I don't recommend this game, YOU SHOULD GO PLAY SHANTAE AND THE PIRATES CURSE! (which is a great game).

First impressions about this game.

The graphics are amazing (much more so than predecessors) and music is fantastic. And as usual, the gameplay is exceedingly smooth and controls respond very well. The dances are pretty cool and the story also leans more on the comical side compared to most games leaving a lighthearted feeling.

Despite my glowing remarks above, I have 3 large issues with the game.

Content: The length of time required to beat the game and get full completion is ridiculously short, ~5-7 hours for the average gamer.

Story/Character Development: This is also related to the content. The story is pretty weak and honestly if you remove playing the actual levels, I could tell the entire story of the game to completion with like 2 sentences. Connected to this is character development. This game in no way makes anyone really care about any of the characters! Not even Shantae! If I hadn't played both the prequels, I would have no idea why Shantae was a half-genie and why she cared about the genie realm, or what her relation to Risky was! And then the supporting characters, rotty-tops/brothers + sky + bolo/grandpa: the game really does a disservice to how these people relate to shantae as from this game alone you could barely even tell that they were friends and not just some random townfolk A, B, C.

Difficulty: This is yet another problem. Going through the levels are like a walk in the park (even so for non gamers) and the bosses while looking cool, are extremely dissapointing. All of the bosses patterns are extremely easy and they are honestly so weak that as long as you decide to use a potion (which you shouldn't really ever need), you can completely face-tank never dodge any of the bosses attacks and still smash them! Also the 4 skills which have always been a shantae staple are pretty much never needed. The fireball->flamethrower and lightning cloud are excessively weak and useless it pretty much every scenario. The pikeball/scimitar aren't really necessary but are usefull for clearing out monsters/bosses faster. And then the bubble is really good enough to make you invicible to some bosses (not counting the 3rd upgrade which is literally invincibility). And the magic power these things use is almost negligible for the time you need to activate it.

Aside from ease in monsters and bosses, getting 100% completion and finding all the "secrets" is so simple that I don't even need to put any thought to find every single item! While it wasn't extremely hard in the Pirates curse at least I had to go revisit some areas just to search every nook and cranny for the special tinkerbells. In Half-genie hero, all the secrets are pretty much just lying in front of you waiting for you to get the right power to unlock it.

Overall, the game is lovely but is waaaay too easy with a laughably simple and short plot that does not make you care for it in any way. I was really looking forward to this game but it really dissapointed me on many levels, even as a Shantae fan. Although I don't regret buying the game because I was a fan of the Shantae series (and this is probably the last game I'm guessing), I can't really recommend this unless this game is under $10. However, if you haven't picked up any Shantae games before I recommend you try out Shantae and the Pirates Curse. That game is way more polished than this one and doesn't really have any of these big issues that I listed for this entry here.

28580278.review:
Full diclosure: I was a Kickstarter backer for this game.  After playing it, I feel like I got my money's worth.

Wayforward has a good track record with 2-D platforming games (the other one I have played is Ducktales Remastered).  Half-Genie Hero is a fun, bright, easy-to-pickup game that I recommend to fans of platforming games.  The development team put a lot of effort into ensuring that this was a well-executed, polished, product. 

Pros: Easy-to-play, fun platforming, interesting special moves/transformations, varied/interesting stages, great soundtrack.  Accessible challenge level that doesn't ever feel unfair - no "cheap deaths." 

Cons:  Sometimes too easy - there is a relic/magic combination that makes the final boss trivial, but you have to do all the legwork to get everything and then realize the combination.  

Other thoughts:  I recommend using a controller (my Logitech F310 worked perfectly).

28580011.review: This game is every bit as fun as it looks!  Also giant mermaid waifus.

28579826.review:
Beautiful animations and gorgeous designs, this is definitely one of the prettiest 2.5D sidescrollers I've seen in a while. Visually, this game, is so vibrant and joyous to watch, it simply leaves you feeling good.

The music is also nice and simple, having a sort of retro feel to it without the exclussive use of 8-bit samples. It feels very Early-Sonic-ish at some points, wich is high praise considering that the early Sonic games had nice, catchy and energetic tunes for each level to give emphasis to the rapid action.

The game controls very much like most 2D platformers, the controls are fast and responsive and after only a few minutes they will feel like second nature. This game also adds a bit of variety with transformations, meaning that as you progress through the game you will gain the ability to transform into a variety of cratures with different abilities, but I won't spoil too much about that. This mechanic adds to the value of each level, as when you return to them with your new transformation abilities, after you played for a while, you will be able to explore more areas that you couldn't before.

Now, the game in total is not all that long, in fact if you are really into it and don't do much of exploring around each level, you could easily get to the end in the same day you downloaded it. As mentioned before, bacause of the transformations, you will have to do a lot of backtracking, which it can get tedious if you are not into this sort of thing, but discovering little secrets in each level can feel so rewarding at times.

Overall, it's a pleasant little game that I highly recomend to people who want a nice platforming expireince, amazing visuals and simple story that doesn't take forever to finish. It just makes me wonder; if the team had a bigger budget (the game was crowd-funded) and maybe more time, what more could have they accomplished.

28577646.review:
Updated for Risky Boots DLC: The ridiculous and creepy fanservice is so severe in the DLC that it has completely turned me off of this game. I no longer reccommend it, and honestly I think the devs should probably just make porn since that seems to be what they want to be doing.


--Original pre-DLC review--
I backed this game on kickstarter and have no regrets. The gameplay is fast-paced and highly enjoyable. The main mechanic, transforming, is very well executed and a pleasure to use. This is definitely one of those games that makes you feel powerful, jumping around and whipping things to death with hair attacks and shifting smoothly between whatever forms you need for the task at hand. I played with an XBox 360 USB controller and had no issues whatsoever. You can even rebind the buttons if you want, something not every game offers.

The game has a cute but fairly light story, which is honestly perfect for it. It is enough to keep you moving without bogging you down or getting in the way of the main feature, which is the excellent gameplay. Pretty much my only issue with the game is one I knew I'd have going in. I do find the female outfits and character designs a bit silly/fanservicey (personal preference here, not an attack). That said, they don't really exploit that in gross ways like some titles do. Something I read on TVTropes seems pretty true, describing the style as 'sexy but not sexualized'. 

The only exception I found was the first playthrough of the second level Mermaid Factory. I found that level seriously squicky in a variety of ways. [spoiler] Seriously, girls tied to some kind of assembly line looking thing, being shoved into cans to be sold (as you find out later) as *food*? That's pretty messed up.[/spoiler] Thankfully all the disturbing elements are gone when you come back later. And to be fair this series has always had some squicky elements to its humor. 

I am generally pretty sensitive to this sort of thing, so if you aren't this may not bother you at all. If you are very sensitve, then, be aware. I still definitely reccommend the game, which I feel has a great deal of heart and is well worth it. I have already beat both normal and hero mode, and am looking forward to the extra content that will eventually be released.

EDIT: Something I forgot to mention was the soundtrack, which I found highly enjoyable and perfectly suited to the rhythm of the gameplay. It's all instrumental with the exception of the theme song, 'Dance Through the Danger', which plays during the first run of the first level as well as during the ending credits. That song... well, let's just say that three days after playing it was still getting stuck in my head. xD

28574993.review:
Disclaimer: I backed the kickstarter (sort of). To be more accurate, I gave a paypal donation that counted towards backing the game well after the campaign had been successfully funded. I'd just finished Pirate's Curse and was excited to see how they'd treat the franchise going forward. Well, you see that red thumb in the corner so I've got some explaining to do.

Let's start things off by saying that my actual feelings towards this game lie somewhere in the middle, however, steam only has a binary "good or bad" system for rating games. Given what I have to say though, I'm sad to say I'm going to have to give this a thumbs down. The game leaves a great first impression but the deeper you get in the more you can see the cracks in its structure.

Let's start off with the positives. The music is fantastic, Jake Kaufman continues to be one of my favorite game music composers and I'm delighted to enjoy the soundtrack to most games he's worked on. The upgrade from pixel art to drawn sprites is absolutely wonderful. The future looks great assuming they stick with this art style, the game looks fantastic. The controls are nice and responsive and the basic gameplay has a good feel to it. While my issues with the genie transformations, that have followed me as I've played through all four games in the series, aren't entirely solved in this game they're much quicker to access, especially with the metronome, which I consider a must have item. There's a couple fun ideas for settings and it's neat to see how the tech of this world is advancing in each installment.

Unfortunately, good music and visuals do not alone for a good game make, now we're in the negatives. The game only has a small handful of levels that feel shorter and shorter the more you have to scour over every inch of them to find more collectables to progress the story. That's the biggest problem with the game, it's spread incredibly thin over a very small and tightly packed space. I loved my first run through each level, the first time through mermaid falls is my personal highlight of this game. The second run through, it was neat to see how little elements had changed. However, by the time I'd finally gotten everything there was to pick up I was pretty much sick of every area. Well, aside from the first and the fifth one which are both, comparatively, tiny levels with little to do.
The linear "level" structure really went against what I've become familiar with in this series. While the map design is nowhere near as bad as Risky's Revenge, (Which, as it stands, is my least favorite entry in this franchise by a wide margin.) it's definitely a huge step back from Pirate's Curse. They went from open maps to screen to screen "levels" packed with things you are required to get but can't until you get more transformations. Aside from that, the biggest problem with them is how they're checkpointed, which is really only an issue because of any of the instant death traps that are in the later environments. The game isn't really all that hard but instant death spikes/lasers isn't how you remedy that. (Side Note: Games don't have to be "hard" to be good.) At best, it's a nuisance, but at worst it's a complete waste of time. Some genie transformations are usefully only for one or two manditory uses to collect an item but outside of that are completely pointless when put up against the other transformations you get (spider). Any points I can get into beyond this get more into the territory of nitpicking so I'll spare you that.

If I were to give you a recommendation it'd be for what is, in my opinion, the best of this series and perhaps the only 5/5 worthy one on the list. I'd highly encourage you to check out Shantae and the Pirate's Curse. It goes above and beyond all 3 of the games it sits alongside. Funnily enough, it's the only game where Shantae doesn't have her genie powers (animal transformations) and I think it plays like a dream because using your abilities flows better with the controls. There's no stopping to turn into a less powerful, less interesting form. Instead you flow smoothly through actions. Be careful though since there might, unfortunately, be some odd issues with the PC port of Pirate's curse based on my browse of the community page. [strike] If Wayforward could "remaster" Pirates Curse with these visuals it'd be a dream come true. [/strike]

Edit: 12/30/2016 This review was made with the base version of the game in mind. In the event that any of the added characters/campaigns be paid DLC I feel my review will not need to be adjusted to reflect content sold separately of the original product. There's no guarantee that I'll think to return to the game by the time additional content is added. Any willing to "take up the mantle" are free to do so in my absence.

Author's note: If you enjoy the game, great, more power to you. I'm honestly happy that you have a thing to be happy with. You don't have to agree with me, in fact, I don't expect you to. I just felt compelled to put this together by the time I'd finished with the game. I don't often share my opinions in writing like this but I felt like I had a case to make even though it was going against the tide. Hope your day treats you well.

28569301.review:
Here it is, mentlegen! The third Shantae game has finally arrived (MY third Shantae game anyway)!

Boy, this one was worth the wait. Both the animations and the gameplay are silky smooth, the music and the jokes are as good as ever and while I feel that the overall gameplay difficulty may have been dumbed down a little, there are also some new ways built into the game which enables all players to customize the stuff (power-ups/abilities) that they want and don't want to use, so they can manually make their game experiences harder for themselves if they find it too easy.

It's so easy that I actually managed to get a 100% right during my first playthrough with some microscopical help.
Easy as it may be, it's just as much fun to play. Backtracking no longer feels like the chore now that the dungeons are removed altogether and thanks to the buttload of new transformations and the majorly increased visual quality added to the once again catchy tunes and wacky gameplay it's ensured that you won't get annoyed about the fact that you have to visit the very same place for the 6th time.

If the difficulty or the P.O.O.P.load of dungeons were the only things holding you back from getting a sip of the Shantae universe, then now is the perfect time to join our forces of relentless belly dancers.
Together we shall dance through the danger! (and we'll never fail!)

A must have for Shantae fans and highly recommended for fans of Raymanish games.

P.S.: WayForward, you have my moniez for any future DLC content.

28569258.review:
I'm somewhat disappointed in this installment, but it was still a solid experience overall.



If you're a newcomer: Shantae is a 2D platforming metroidvania series, and this is the 4th installment. It's got very well executed gameplay and controls. Shantae can transform into various animals to get around the area. There's a bunch of world to explore with their own themes and hidden secrets. It's very linear and easy compared to the previous installments, so I would recommend getting this one first to get a feel of the series, but overall I feel Shantae and the Pirate's Curse was a much better game.




If you're a veteran: This game left a bittersweet feeling in my mouth. Half Genie Hero is still a well done game, but it feels so terribly bare bones compared to Pirate's Curse and Risky's Revenge. It's much shorter at about 5 hours long, way too easy especially with upgrades, no dungeons, very linear compared to the other games, plot that is very boring and goes nowhere, generic and few interesting setpieces, much smaller and linear stages that don't have any emphasis on exploring since most "hidden" objects just require a dance or upgrade you don't have yet. However, with all that said, it's no Shantae on GBC. What the game does, it does well. I just feel it lacks in a lot of areas, but it's by no means bad. Worth picking up on a sale if you loved Pirate's Curse.

28567754.review:
Full disclosure: I backed the game way back in 2013 and may be a little biased.

I was really worried that Shantae: HGH is going to be another Mighty No. 9. I reminded myself that WayForward is a company with a good service list, but to err is human, right? Well, It has been out for 3 days now and I'm glad to say that it's not Mighty No. 9. In fact, HGH kinda blows the Kickstarter failure out of the water. HGH is a neat experience of a great colorful and vivid artstyle, amazing music and comfortable gameplay. The gameplay is your typical metroidvania: scattered over the levels are areas that are reachable only by performing a certain dance that transforms Shantae into a spider, a crab, a mermaid and et cetera. You could seperate the transformations into two groups: group 1 is made for platforming and group 2 is made strictly for puzzles (at least I have never personally found a platforming use for the mouse transformation). You're going to spend most of the game travelling back-and-forth, collecting hidden items with newfound transformations.

This is when you get to the cons of the game. The transformations are, long term, pointless gimmicks. The mouse transformation is used around 5 times all over the game, while some of the other ones (mermaid, for example) come in too late to be a viable alternative to the one you got earlier (crab transformation). There's also no point to use them to combat enemies. In the end, you're going to use transformations to discover the occasional blocked off area, transform back to original Shantae because she's stronger, faster and more versatile, and then go on. By the way, as I've said, that's all you're gonna do for the majority of the game. I didn't really find that too bad because I'd be doing it anyway, but the fact that you're basically forced to repeatedly go through the levels to find hidden stuff makes it easier to 100% the game. And if you 100% the game too early, you get an eight hours long playtime. Now, I think that's quite normal for an indie platformer (for example, Shovel Knight takes about 8 hours to beat it too), but some people may disagree - that's quite alright, though WayForward has new characters for the game in the works. Maybe that will make the game longer?

Basically, as a summary: Shantae: HGH was a very good experience, however it's only two real flaws are the most important ones: the transformation gimmick that dies off as the game progresses and the length.

28566001.review:
Caution: While my end result is that I do recommend the game, I do not heavily recommend it like I would with snap-buy titles.
I've enjoyed Shantae throughout the years. Pirate's Curse is, to me, the best game of the series and sadly, Half-Genie Hero does not surpass that game's level. It has too many flaws for that.
For one, the past games had a sense of exploration. Big worlds which you'd discover all kinds of new things in when going through them later on, metroidvania style. Half-Genie Hero...tries to have that, but the worlds are just so tiny. There's a feeling that there should be more, but there simply isn't.
The end-game also has a very strong "Collect 10 Bear Asses" feel to it. Just padding to make the game last a bit longer for those who want to get the proper ending. While it is a tradition for Shantae games to do something like that, it never felt as obvious as it does here. 
Then there's the various forms you can take. Some just feel a bit tacked on, like the Spider form which you need only for one little thing, and is never needed again except for an achievement. The Crab form also feels redundant with the Mermaid form around, with only a very few small things ensuring you must use it.
Finally, the game is on the short side. 7.5 hours for 100% completion without actually rushing through the game...it's not horribly short, but I had hoped for longer.
Having said that, these aren't huge problems. The gameplay itself is smooth as ever, perhaps even smoother than before. The flow of most of the game is perfect, the enemies are nice and varied, the level design itself, while small, is very well done, so gameplay wise there's nothing really wrong with the game.
The graphics are also top notch. A lot of work has gone into the animation and it shows, the game looks fabulous. The music also helps, the ever-present ear worms keep up a great tone.
Finally, the absurd and hilarious conversations are, as ever, another highlight of the game. It does refer it's predecessors a fair bit which might be annoying if this is your first Shantae, but even for those people there's plenty of good humor to go around.
All in all, I think that this game's biggest problem is the existence of Pirate's Curse. That game set a very high bar that Half-Genie Hero falls just short of. I definitely do not regret the purchase, I had just hoped for a bit more after the kickstarter and the various postponings. The game is technically very well done, it just lacks that bit of punch.
7/10.

That said, if you love gaming in general, and side-scrolling 2.5D platformers in particular, you owe it to yourself to check out this little gem. 

It's adoreable. It's winky and fun, without being precious about it. The controls are smooth, the action is plentiful and occasionally challenging, and every new location, interaction, or character has something to delight the senses.

I know we're not supposed to enjoy things unironically anymore, but I'm having me some fun. You should, too.

28561191.review:
Half Genie Waifu
The best waifu.

But seriously though this is a great game. A charming artstyle with beautiful and bright HD graphics, fun level design, and tight platforming controls make this a must-buy for any fan of the 2D platforming genre. The mechanics of your genie powers, the great music, and Shantae's cheery personality itself makes this an amazing game in my opinion. If you like the idea of playing a head-strong, spunky girl who transforms into animals as she saves the day, then this is the game for you.


This is more of a Megaman style of platforming than a Metroidvania, this means the levels are going to feel alot more linear at first. The real exploration comes from after you get your animal abilities, where the extra means of movement allow you to explore the untouched nooks and crannies  of the levels you previously cleared.

The cons I can think of are:
backtracking to find every item in every stage may get repetitive. However this is entirely optional unless you either want to do the little bit of extra work to get the good ending or just 100% complete the game.

This game is also probably the easiest game in the Shantae series. Shop items might as well be given to you with how cheap they are, barely any real threats in terms of enemies, and thinking creatively will sometimes let you use your animal transformations to completely bypass entire sections of the game.  

Edit:
The new introduction of hardcore ups the difficulty on a grand scale. More enemies, different enemy placement, more damage, and new boss attacks make for a much more exhilerating experience.


However.
Even with its faults, I stil llove the game. It is an excellent edition to the series and a pretty good step forward.

Personally I loved the story, but heads up, its episodic like a Saturday morning cartoon. *SPOILERS* There is no Big Evil threatening to destroy the entire planet that requires an epic adventure. Instead Shantae has to deal with a bunch of smaller threats and go on smaller adventures one at a time. It's less of "This is one of the most important days in this character's life" and more of a "This the stuff this young lady has to deal with sometimes."

Using internet guides at the late part of the game, I was able to 100% the main default story within a total of about 7 hours. Its a short game, but it was fun enough that I'm going to be revisiting this story plenty more times.

 I also need to mention that there is going to be alot of DLC coming out in the future of writing this review. Costume swaps for Shantae, and extra story modes where you play as some of the side characters are all underway. As a fan of the series, I am very excited to see some of the other characters get some time in the spotlight.

28551452.review:
Shantae: Half Genie Hero is the 4th installment of  developer WayForward's Shantae series and the first to be funded by the fans via Kickstarter. Despite being overlooked and criminally under funded when compared to the likes of the now long forgotten Mighty No 9, Wayforward has once again have shown their true talents as a game developer.

HGH is the first Shantae game that's in full HD.  It's also a more linear adventure, although there are secrets and hidden areas to find and discover. There are a total of 6 levels. Each broken into 3 to 4 stages each with a boss waiting at the end of each level. In this new adventure Shantae has more transformations at her disposal that totals up to 12 forms she can use. The animations and the overall look of HGH is possibly the best visualls WayForward has brought to the table with the series. The soundtrack has once again hit another home run thanks to series composer Jake Kaufman and also credit to Shantae's voice actress Christina Vee for lending her talented voice in main theme. 

Pros:
-Beautiful visuals that match with the equally vibrating soundtrack
-Shantae's arsinal and transformations is the most varied in the series yet
-Each of the 6 levels do well to make use and compliment the way the transfomations are used in certain situations
-Gameplay is simple, but does offer some complexity
-The 6 levels are varied and offer plenty of action platforming that doesnt get dull

Con:
-Short playthough that could be completed around 6+ hours on a blind run
-4 of the transformations are forgeteble and are hardly used
-Certain pickup items can make Shantae go extremely OP
-Difficulty is easiest entry out of the entire series


Verdict: Despite the game's shortcommings, this is still one of the better Shantae titles released being behind The Pirate's Curse. It doesn't change the formula too much, but rather it gives it a bigger, HD paint-job. This is an easy buy, but may want to wait for a sale and/or DLC to come out for additional content.

Shantae:  Half-Genie Hero is a very fun platformer, I highly recommend this game to those that are looking to get into the genre or for those that enjoy these type of games.

The world map is very straight forward, you going from stage to stage with each one containing a boss.  You may choose to do this, but the game encourages you to replay the levels again to find secrets and upgrades.

Combat is fairly straight forward.  What makes this game special are the various unique transformations you can turn into to complete stages and also find secret areas withen them.  Throughout the game you can find secret npc's that upgrade your transformations that lets you do special moves/attacks.

There are also a variety of spells that you can choose from and each one is upgradeable to a certain point.  

The only issue I have is the small amount of content, I would love to see more stages because they are very well done.  

The progression system is just right which keeps you constantly engaged, which makes this game very enjoyable and you'll definitely get your money's worth.

28547300.review:
This game is very cute and has a lot of love poured into it, but suffers immensely from a very bumpy difficulty curve. The developers seem to be either unable or unwilling to create levels that are anywhere between easy and hard.

Most of the easy levels feature platforming and enemies, but with little or no consequence for failing the platforming - and enemies can be easily dispatched, ignored, or avoided most of the time. I never once died to any of the enemies, including the bosses, and I imagine most other players will be able to say the same thing.

However, some of the levels are completely different, and feature very few enemies, and often difficult or finicky platforming, with the consequence of missing a jump being an instakill, which sends you back to the last checkpoint. Unfortunately, there are very few of these, so falling into a pit can send you back quite a distance.

The final zone is where this all culminates into one huge mess. The levels leading up to the final boss consist mostly of screens that are almost literally Flappy Bird, with instant kills lining every wall. Getting through those screens took me significantly longer than beating the final boss itself, and after that I was dropped in an auto-run level that was even more difficult, and took me even longer to complete. I didn't feel a sense of accomplishment by the time I was done; just frustration.

Bottom line: Watch a playthrough instead. The difficulty of the levels spikes too much for me to call this a good game, which sucks, because there's a lot of great work put into just about everything else.

28544257.review:
This is a great addition to the series.
Gameplay, music, visuals, all top-notch. The game consists of bright colors and the cute, cheery half-genie hero Shantae as you play through several different environments, be it a mermaid factory surrounded by water or a hot desert with strong winds. The transformations are really interesting. Some are chibi looking animals while others are cute monster-girls with every one having their own unique abilities that can be built upon if you find the hidden upgrades throughout each level. Shantae herself can be upgraded from the item shop by buying new spells and hair products and accessories.

The game is a reasonable length of about 6-7 hours for your frist run (hard for me to judge because I left the game on in the background so my own time is not arcuate), although there's speedrunning challanges that time you for under 2 hours. I'll like to add I completed my run with 100% item collection and I think you should look for all the art gallery keys, the mayor's reward is worth it. 

There seems to be more content in the works, probable DLC for us none kick-starter folk, but I think as it stands the game is worth the asking price.

I do recommend a controller for this game though, the default keyboard settings, at the time of this review, don't make much sense and it just feels way more responsive with a controller in hand. 

Overall, a great game and I highly recommend you pick it up!

28541457.review:
O quarto jogo da série Shantae possui um roteiro simples e leve mas que prova como sendo mais que o suficiente para permitir o fluxo do jogo.
  A jogabilidade é sólida e, seguindo a tendência que o terceiro jogo propôs, é dividido completamente por fases separadas em geral em 3 partes razoavelmente  grandes, permitindo um certo grau de exploração e um chefe no final da fase. A mecânica de transformações presente nos 2 primeiros jogos da série voltou e agora existem várias formas que o jogador pode destravar ao longo do jogo, dado a ele um toque sutil de metroidvania no titulo.
  A trilha sonora é boazinha. Consegue dar um certo clima pro jogo mas não é nada excepcional.
  A arte é a parte onde houveram as maiores mudanças no geral. Tendo feita a transição do gráfico pixelado pro gráfico desenhado em alta resolução, na minha opinião, fez muito bem ao título. Permitindo belos cenários e personagens detalhados além de ser bem animado.
  Os aspectos dele que podem ser considerados negativos são a quantidade de coletáveis presentes nele, que apesar de não ser o número absurdo que se vê em certos títulos AAA mas não são poucos e pode acabar ficando um pouco chato no final, o fatos de alguns inimigos possuirem muita vida em relação ao dano máximo que a protagonista pode infligir a eles e a duração total do jogo, por volta de umas 6-7 horas, que pode afastar as pessoas que procuram jogos mais extensos, apesar de eu achar que o jogo consegue terminar antes dele ficar extenso demais.
  Concluindo, apesar de possuir alguns defeitos, ele pode fazer parte da lista dos bons jogos produzidos graças ao kickstarter e da lista de jogos com boas protagonistas femininas, uma personagem que, apesar de ter os seus conflitos e defeitos, consegue ser alegre, forte e capaz de resolver os seus problemas por si mesma, sem perder a humildade.
Nota: 8/10

28541336.review:
*NOTE: I WAS A BACKER FOR THIS GAME'S KICKSTARTER*

I'm not gonna go too deep into this game because it's pretty obvious as to what it is by looking at it but I can say it is an excellent platformer from WayForward that has some metroidvania elements. The game is hud based, and you can revisit previous levels in order to collect items needed to progress. So, what you are looking at is a game that's part traditional run left to right platformer, and part collectathon. You will get various powers and upgrades as you progress through the game not unlike a Metroid or Castlevania title. You'll have a scene with characters in a hub town, go to a level and make it through, then likely have to find something you couldnt get before to progress to the next level by revisiting previous levels. The good news is that you won't be playing the exact same things over again as levels do have some changes as you go through them again but it's mostly the same. If I have any major negatives it may be the nature of having to revist old levels over again though it didn't bother me too much, and that it's fairly short, taking about 7 hours for me on my first run to collect everything and beat the game.

28540398.review:
Shantae is one of my favorite game series of all time. While other reviews will talk about the great level design, the (occasionally) amusing writing, the phenomenal music (thanks to Jake Kaufman). I'd like to talk about the thing I truly love about the shantae series (excluding the original).

The game engine in these games is flawless. The greatest crime I feel a platformer can commit in my opinion is have a poor engine. If I ever feel like missing a jump is the game's fault, or some BS pixel perfect jump requirements, then it is a bad platformer. 

This is never the case in Shantae. Shantae always lands from every jump exactly the way I expect based on the buttons I pressed. If I miss a jump, it is clear and obvious what I did wrong. I timed it wrong for the moving platform, I misjudged the arc, an enemy attack threw me off. I never fight the controls, and I never yell at the screen "OH THATS BULL, I MADE THAT JUMP". Hard sections feel challenging, not frustrating.

That right there, the silky smooth controls and rock solid engine, are the best part of this game and its predecessors (except the original, lets not talk about the original....)

UPDATE:
Now that I'm less starry eyed from just finishing the game. I'll give my honest opinion to long time fans of Shantae. The biggest difference in this game is the style of level design. Its less metroidvania, more mega man. This isn't a bad thing, its just different. Levels are less about being labyrinths, and more about combining enemy placement and platforming to create a challenge. To those that prefer the labyrinth style designs, Shantae and the Pirate's Curse remains your best bet. To those that prefer stuff like Mega Man X, this game is perfect. To those that like both, like me, both games are awesome.

28535746.review:
[h1]Half-Genie Hero is Ret-2-Go[/h1]

Half-Genie hero is the fourth installment in the Shantae series, and each entry manages to impress in new ways. Half-Genie Hero's visuals are its most impressive feature, from the artwork to the animation, its all very good. I liked this game a lot, but I think it does have a few minor shortcomings.

[u]Pros [/u]
+++ Visuals, they're great. The character portraits are nice, the models and sprites fit the style well, and the animations accentuate character personalities
+++ Soundtrack, it's very good, each area has a unique track that sets the mood well
++ Level Design, the levels are nicely designed, each new ability that is unlocked makes them easier to traverse in some way, as well as unlocking new areas in previous levels, new enemies appear in previous levels after clearing them as well
+ Gameplay, transformations add a fresh take on the playstyle of Pirate's Curse, but transforming back and forth between them can sometimes feel tedious

[u]Cons[/u]
- Length, as a metroidvania game, short lengths are to be expected and replay value is where play time comes from. However, in comparison to Pirate's Curse I found this game to be shorter without much justification gameplay-wise
-- Difficulty, Half-Genie Hero is an easy game. The ability to toggle upgrades helps to add an artifical challenge should it be desired, but for a casual player the base game is hardly challenging, especially compared to Pirate's Curse

Overall, Half-Genie hero is an excellent game. I never felt frustrated with it, and that made it a fun experience. Even though it was an easy game, the effort WayForward put into creating and polishing this title was evident. With more content coming next year and a 10% discount on the game, I wholly recommend giving Shantae: Half-Genie Hero your consideration.
