28533385.review:
After 3 years in development, the fourth installment of the Shantae franchise has finally been released. Is Half-Genie Hero worth the weight? Well, let's find out.

Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is the fourth game in the sassy and charming Shantae series and now in high-definition. The visuals in this game are fantastic to say the least. The game mixes colorful and nicely textured 3D assets with high-quality 2D sprites. The animations on characters are also excellent and gives the game some life. Game also ran very well at least for me it did. No crashes either.

Unlike Pirate's Curse, Half-Genie Hero brings back the transformations from the first two games; however, they made some more changes to the system in this one. The way transformations work now is that you go into dance mode and the game goes through a menu of transformations automatically and you use the d-pad (if you played it on a controller which I did) to select your transformation. Additionally, there is now a grand-total of 14 transformations (2 of them can be swapped) with some being more useful than others. The transformations are fun to use but they are not as good as the Pirate Gear from the previous game due to having to pause and wait to select the transformation you want to use which can ruin the flow of the gameplay. There is an upgrade that increases Shantae's dancing animation speed which helps somewhat.

Now for the most important part, the gameplay. Is it any good? Absolutely. It controls nearly as well as Pirate's Curse and using the transformations is still fun despite not flowing as well as the Pirate Gear. The game is more linear than its predecessors but the metroidvania elements are still there as you will be doing a lot of backtracking in earlier levels to go into areas you wouldn't have access to before. The levels are fun to explore but the lack of dungeons is really disappointing. The Shantae games always had really fun dungeons to explore and the lack of them in this game is a crime. I don't know why they removed them but hopefully they will bring them back in the next game. Also, there is no map in this game which is odd considering that Risky's Revenge and Pirate's Curse had maps. The game seems to be quite shorter than the other entries but there will be new character modes that will be coming up later on which should increase the length of the game.

The music is composed by Jake Kaufman once again and I must say, some of the tracks in this game are the best in the whole series. The soundtrack of this game consists of high-quality remixes of songs from previous games and new tracks. There is one track from the previous games that gets reused but is only used for one section. Overall, the soundtrack does not disappoint and Jake Kaufman has done an amazing job once again.

Now for the story, I know the story isn't really the main focus in these games but Pirate's Curse did a pretty good job on that aspect and this game seems to ignore some of the character development from that game. Risky just goes back to her "LOL IM EVIL" self without any explaination and a few characters from the last two games don't make an appearence in this game. Speaking of Risky, there is a lack of Risky in this game as she only appears in the beginning and the end of the game. The story feels pretty unfocused throughout the majority of the game as each level in the game feels more like an episode of "Shantae beats the bad guy from doing bad things". The rival Half-Genie that appears early on in the game would have made for an interesting story but they just conclude her story shortly afterwards. Despite the story being unfocused, the dialogue is still very funny and charming.

Overall, Half-Genie Hero is a very polished and well made game that will not disappoint any fan in the series. It may not be as good as Pirate's Curse but it's still a great entry to the franchise. Due to its pretty short length, I would recommend to pick this one up on a sale and/or when the new character modes come out.

28533235.review:
Let me just say it first: yes! The game is pretty good.

However, when you played Pirates Curse before, then may not expect a direct sequel to that. I mean, yeah, Storywise it is the continuation of the Shantae francise, but when it comes to gameplay, it's kinda more like Riskys Revenge and the first game on the GBC.
And even then it is quite frankly less of a Metroidvania then before. There are no Dungeons anymore for example. Instead you got regular levels who seems more linear at the first sight, and play suprisingly more like the old Mega Man games, with focus of challenging levels with plenty of obstacles to avoid instead of the open nature with a lot of exploration what Shantae used to be (yeah, the old Games had also a lot of tricky platforming, but in this game there are way more bottomless pits and instant death Spikes like in Mega Man as I already mentioned).
However, when you unlock more and more transformations (and there are a lot of them, much more then in the old titles) and revisit old areas, which the game forces you on a repeatedly routine, then you realise that there are more and more open areas hidden inside of these levels where you can find new Items and upgrades and such. And because you can buy a move which can warp you through revisited levels and later even unlock a transformation with that you can fly and skip hard platforming, backtracking isn't even that much of a problem anymore. However, there is no more Map that help you to orient, but too be honest, it isn't needed, since the levels are still quite linear.

So yeah, the gameplay rocks, but sadly, the Story doesn't. Instead of a fully fletched Story, we got more like a Saturday Morning Cartoon approach with small stories that surround every level and a tiny, tiny main plot that got it's focus at the end of the game, and is pretty predictable to be honest. It's not bad, but kinda dissapointing since Pirates Curse felt more massive beause it was one big story (and the Story in that game was really good!). 


But that aside: It is really a good game, the second best in the series too be honest. and while I had my problems with the Story,  the gameplay, the really excellent humor and awesome Soundtrack made me forgive this one particular flaw. If you are a Shantae fan: buy this game! If this is you are a newcomer to the francise, hmmm, try Pirates curse first, or even Riskys Revenge so you can tell if you like this Gameplaystyle. But at the end it is indeed a good game!

28530303.review:
Your typical platforming experience, with gorgeous graphics and full of charm. You jump around to get through levels while whipping some fools using your hair as a weapon. The usual.

The most notable aspect of the game is that Shantae, the protagonist, transforms into different animals, each with their own abilities that'll be necessary at specific moments to reach all sorts of secrets or progress-related key items. There are also a lot of upgrades to these transformations that increase their capabilities to deal with both enemies and the terrain.

Every level has a very distinct theme and gameplay focus. Each of them feels original and engaging.

The only possible problem with this title is how much backtracking it puts the player through. I personally didn't have a problem with it, but I'd wager some people did. It's probably done to extend the durability of the game, since it's quite short. The silliness involved in the many NPC interactions that occur during these backtrack experiences made them totally worth it to me.

Overall, it gets a hearty recommendation. It's fun, it's charming, it's funny, excessive backtracking being the one thing to be aware of before you get this title.

[h1][u]But wait! There's more![/u][/h1]

[b]So this is the fourth game in the series, crowd-funded, and pure HD.[/b]
[u]There's something i have to say first, and it's that the game isn't yet fully finished. We're getting some DLC.[/u]

I sorta find it a bit weird and expensive, but it'll probably get more value as the DLCs release.

If you want reference for how good or bad the series is as a whole, it's good, read my other reviews of the previous 2 games:
[b]http://steamcommunity.com/id/garketmardener/recommended/277890/
ːshantae_relaxːShantae: Risky's Revenge
http://steamcommunity.com/id/garketmardener/recommended/345820/
ːshantae_relaxːShantae & the Pirate's Curse [/b]
This time around, they went for a more visually stunning but shorter game, to be expanded with lots of replay value thanks to the upcoming DLCs.
So right now it has the same problem as Switch Force: It's cool, and fun, it's pretty in graphics, but once you've done the 2 modes you're basically done with it. Wait for DLCs.

As it is, and considering how the game's supposed to be expanded, it's good, it's really great. Most importantly, the graphics are really well done and don't even get close to straying off of the style the game usually goes for: Toonish, charming, colorful, vivid, and with noticeable details and tweaks. I believe it's the first time WayForwad does 3d models on one of their IPs, and they did it great for a first time. Characters are still well-put sprites in a 3d-2d parallax world. Really comes together as a modernized classic way of doing things.
60FPS engine, but animations aren't all 60fps. It still looks consistant and doesn't really bother. Also, yes, it comes with chest jigglies. As it's obvious. I mean, WayForward? Fanservice? Isn't that the same thing? /joke

This however doesn't stop the game from being fun and really great. As always, the prime 3 aspects i like about this company are on point: Decent difficulty (questionable here but whatever) and fun gameplay, great artstyle and personality, absolutely rocking synth muslc from Jake Kaufman AKA Virt. [b]Album is out on bandcamp now btw[/b]

game's a bit short, you can get 100% in the base game mode in 5-6 hours approx, considering how the other games took up to 8 hours for that (all of those are player-dependant times, might take longer if you're not familiar with the games or genre).

The game's very iconic and takes everything positive from the other games, such as returning gags, levels, enemies, bosses, transforms and abilities, while still refreshing everything really well.

On the minus side, because of how short the game is, some features fell under the "situationally helpful" cape of negligence, but at least they get used once. There are a few annoying mechanics that were uncalled for, overall for the very stupidly placed pauses inbetween the action (Why is the level start Ready! screen a thing, and why can't you move while it's playing?), but for the most part it still is a great game.

Buyer's advice: Play the other games before. Some of the content might go unappreciated if you haven't played the other games, or just watched a full gameplay. Any works. But still, playing is much more fun than watching, at least for me.

[i][b]Overall, i give it a [8.5-->10]/10 depending on how well executed the DLCs and extra modes come along.[/b][/i]

28525761.review:
While this game is visually superior to previous games in the series, in other areas it appears to have taken one or two steps backwards.

Gameplay is as good as it's ever been, though perhaps a bit stale given how little has changed. Same spells, same upgrades. Even the transformations are largely recycled from previous games. In fact there are probably too many transformations. It sometimes felt contrived how the level layout required certain transformations to progress.

This game can't seem to decide whether it's aiming to bring in new fans, or pander to old fans. The game is more simple and linear compared to previous games, but spends next to no time on character introductions, expecting you to already know who everyone is. And while the old transformations do look great in HD, they lack personality. In particular, I really miss the monkey's idle animation from Risky's Revenge.

The pacing is also kind of messy. As with previous games, to progress you need to find the relevant collectibles in levels you've already cleared. This creates a sort of slow, leisurely "scavenger hunt" type of game, during which you jump around and fight enemies set to an exciting soundtrack. This structure was also in previous games, and is not a problem.
What I'm talking about is the "in-between" segments, when you talk to NPCs to get hints and hand in quest items. There's very little dialogue before you're onto your next task. So you might spend half an hour finding the item you need, and then you get less than a minute of plot before you're onto the next level. The game felt really short, too.

While we're at it, boss battles. This game's bosses are pitiful. I'm not talking about difficulty, I'm talking about buildup. Risky's Revenge had actual dungeons in which the bosses resided, and you would know their name before meeting them.
Pirate's Curse was longer, so didn't do this for each boss. Those it did build up, though, were well done.
Then we get to Half Genie Hero, and there's practically no build up for any of them, least of all the final boss, which is only introduced when the battle begins.

The final bosses are the most irritating example of this. RR had the boss take something the player themselves had come to cherish, and turn it against them. PC had a deliberate repeat of this, but getting the right collectibles adds a twist to the ending which turns everything upside down. HGH has the boss show up and fight you. And... that's pretty much it. If more effort had gone into developing the plot or characters, the stakes might have felt higher, but as it was, it was just a moderately more difficult boss battle.

If you've read this far, you might be wondering when I get to the reason this is in the positive reviews section. And that reason is that despite all its flaws, this is a good game that I enjoyed playing, and I think it is well worth the $20 USD pricetag.

The other games are better though.

28524633.review: Another great addition to the Shantae series! The graphics are really good and so is the music, definerly worth the money considering how much time Wayforward put into it.

Classic platformer and great fun. The humor is self-depreciating and tolerably corny. Controls and movement very crisp. Difficulty is a bit less than earlier titles in the series, but as of this point I've only played through the initial campaign. A few things that are lacking in the game are an easy to access guide to animal form abilities when you first obtain them. From the concept art, it also seems that there was a lot more planned for the graphics that was cut later in development. It was kind of a downer that this title has the least amount of dancing of any of the Shantae series despite showing at least initial plans to draw it out.

Still, I'm glad this Kickstarter project came together so wonderfully. I'm happy that I contributed my own humble amount to its completion and will spend many more hours enjoying this game.

28523721.review:
Got this game as a gift right before I attempted to get it for myself.

This game is cute as hell with wonderful animation (already a huge motivator for any animator or artist to get it. I might be a bit biased because of this, lol.)

The gameplay is fairly straightforward as a platformer, but even if it's a little more on the simple side it's very polished. Most of the game involves platformer puzzles and exploration, greatly expanded by how the transformations affect your ability to move through levels.

Some forms unfortunately only see use for one or two puzzles and don't have any practical use outside of that, which is a little disappointing, but far from a dealbreaker.

The soundtrack is absolutely killer, and just to stress again the visuals are great. I haven't seen a non-pixel 2D game look this good in a very long time.

The only other gripe I have would maybe be some of the fights are underwhelming or overly simplistic: wait for enemy to use X attack, then attack back a few times. Rinse and repeat many many times until dead. The AI for the fights is more based on patterns rather than reaction--enemies won't do anything different depending on what you're doing, they'll just go through their own motions and soak up what damage you output. There also doesn't feel like there's a lot of randomness in the fights--when a boss uses a move, it operates the same way every time.

It's a little short and a bit easy--leisurely playing will take maybe 5-6 hours to beat, but the game also is only $20, so it's hard to complain about length considering its cost. Plus it's a game that has a decent bit of replay value with speedrun achievements and alternate modes (including a few upcoming and DLC ones). It's also worthwhile going for a full clear.

Overall though it's also a game with a focus on its art, soundtrack, characters, and writing, all of which are good or better, without being held back by elements such as length, difficulty, and mechanics which are 'adequate'.

[spoiler]Also Tuki was woefully underimplemented :([/spoiler]

28520506.review: WayForward once again delivers on the Mega Man X formula that made Shantae and the Pirate's Curse a success with Half-Genie Hero. A not-quite reboot of sorts, this entry ties together the classic tropes of Shantae's transformations and collectable abilities from the original Gameboy Color entry with the streamlined world design of its immediate predecessor. The game rewards exploring previously visited areas with newly gained abilities, and all but the most impatient of players should find it quite clearable without a strategy guide. Though not a difficult game, there are some puzzle platforming sequences and potentially Klonoa-inspired boss battles to keep things fresh. Although not every bit is a slam dunk (a certain escape sequence comes to mind), Half-Genie Hero makes for a breezy, fun weekend's worth of adventure platforming, and I look forward to tackling it again with the unlockable characters.

28520182.review:
The amazing 4th installment of the Shantae series.
PROS:
The controls respond exactly how they should.
There's so much thought put into the art and animation.
The transformation count in this one certainly does not disappoint!
Boss fights are fantastic, not too difficult, but require you to pay attention.
You make use of all your transformations near the end of the game, which in itself is a massive plus.
The ability to turn off gear and abilities from the shop and the ability to use older versions of magic powers.
Hero mode and plenty of achievements to hunt for.

CONS:
It's a bit easier than other shantae games (As well as some transformations making certain segments way too easy to platform through)... but you can switch certain items off to give yourself more of a challenge.
It's quite a bit shorter than other shantae games, but there's more content on the way.


If you like Metroidvania games and platformers, this is right up your alley.
A ton of fun and very hard to put down, and one of my favorite games of this year.

It gets a 8.5/10 from me because Squid Baron isn't last boss yet. (Totally a valid reason, right?)

28520089.review:
クリアまでのプレイ時間は大体5～10時間くらいですかね。
2dアクションゲーム好きならプレイして損ないのではないでしょうか。
空中制動などはロックマンゼロに近いかな。ダッシュボタンはないけれど。
マリオなどのように慣性が働くタイプのジャンプではないです。

進行に関わるアイテムは宝箱に隠されているか、ステージをクリアすると入手出来るので、
出来ることが増えるタイミングが分かり易いです。
防御力、攻撃能力、魔法攻撃などはお店で買います。

ステージを注意深くみて、「あ、ここはなにかありそうだな」
と思いながら進行していくのが楽しいゲームですね。
新しい能力を獲得した後に、再度ステージを訪れて探索するかんじです。
折を見てステージをまた訪れることになるので、
ワープダンスは絶対買いましょう。ホイッスルの存在も忘れないように。





今回のシャンティのいいところ
・HD化したグラフィックがぷにっとして可愛い（好みの差もある）
・各国の言語に初めから対応している
・HD化してもキーレスポンスが従来のまま
・PS4コントローラに対応している
・ゲーム内にアートギャラリーがあって、資料やファンアートが見れる（たのしい）
・ヒント屋さんがいるので目的を見失いづらい
・どのマップにあとどの位アイテムがあるかがワールドマップから解るようになっている
・変身能力によって先にすすめるようになる仕組みがわかりやすい


今回のシャンティの気になったところ
・ファイアボール系が弱い、バックダッシュの距離がちょと短い
・私の環境では○ボタンに変身を設定しておくと、
　変身と同時に魔法を撃ってしまい、MPが使えない
・変身があるとはいえ、人間形態のアクションバリエーションは前作より控えめ
・ダンスモーションが少なかったり、全体的にグラフィック種は控えめ
・背景と足場の区別がつきづらい場合がある
　（特に序盤ステージの火事場、遺跡ステージの渡石）
・能力を獲得した後に、再度ステージを周回するタイプのゲーム
　（ワープダンスで移動の面倒さは緩和される）
・全体的に日本語テキストは女性口調に翻訳されてます　でも楽しむに問題はないです
　（おじさん、守衛などの男キャラも女性口調だったりする）
・2面のつかまるリングを渡っていくところがやや難しい。
・6面は迷子になりやすい。ここだけは全体マップが欲しくなります。
　（楽しむためのギミックで、難点でもないですけどね）



詰まらないためのヒント
・すり抜け床、一部の天井は下＋ジャンプボタンですり抜けられる（必須）
・捕まることが出来るリングはジャンプで触れるだけでオッケー（上キー入力はいらない）
・青白い花の位置を覚えておくと後でらくちん

28517582.review: Mit Shantae: Half Genie Hero dürfen wir nun den 4.Titel dieser Reihe begrüßen. Ich muss erst einmal positiv anmerken, dass nun endlich die deutsche Sprache für ein Shantae Spiel zur Verfügung gestellt wurde, auch wenn kleine Übersetzungsfehler enthalten sind. Nun zum Spiel selbst. Die Story knüpft logischerweise an das Ende von Shantae and the Pirate's Curse an, also wäre es empfehlenswert diesen vorher gespielt zu haben. Es ist jedoch nicht zwingend notwendig. Das Spiel hat eine optische Anpassung erfahren, die sich wirklich sehen lässt. Die Welten sind schön gestaltet und die musikalische Untermalung verpasst dem ganzen noch die richtige Atmosphäre. Ich hatte wirklich ein wenig Gänsehaut, als „Dance Through the Danger“ im ersten Abschnitt der ersten Welt gespielt hat. Die Steuerung ist sehr flüssig und fühlt sich auch dementsprechend an. Mir war zwar bereits beim Kauf bewusst wie lang das Spiel ungefähr sein wird, da ich bereits mit den Shantae-Teilen und deren Spieldauer vertraut bin, dennoch fühlte es sich etwas kurz an. Ich habe viel Zeit in dem Spiel damit verbracht besuchte Welten erneut zu erkunden, um vielleicht neue Wege oder Geheimnisse zu entdecken. Das Spiel war nach ungefähr 6-7 Stunden bei mir beendet, jedoch nicht zu 100%. Mir hat das Spiel wirklich viel Spaß gemacht und ich werde es höchstwahrscheinlich noch eine Weile spielen, ich wollte das jedoch mal ansprechen für die Leute, die gerade noch am überlegen sind, ob der Preis für dieses Spiel wirklich gerechtfertigt ist. Für Fans der Shantae-Reihe ist das Spiel ohnehin ein Muss, aber für Neueinsteiger und solche die sich erst einmal mit dem Genre vertraut machen wollen würde ich erst einmal Shantae: Risky's Revenge als günstigere Alternative empfehlen.

28515036.review:
[h1]Great game altough a little way too easy[/h1]

Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is that OTHER kickstarted game that was during the days of Migthy no.9 and oh boy, this one delivered unlike that other one. Altough quite short and simplistic on some aspects, Shantae delivers in what it promised. Shantae has:[list]
[*]Lovely visuals and character-design
[*]Interesting level design that encourages exploration and revisits
[*]Likeable characters and a easy-going plot
[*]Power-ups
[*]Awesome music[/list]

However, the game falls kind of short on some areas. For starters, it is incredibly easy... so much in all my playtime I didnt even died once nor had a hard time figuring where to go or do next.  Thats not inherently a bad thing but way sooner than later your character gets so strong it becomes laughable how you breeze through the stages. Magic spells are incredibly strong and in general, power-up items are really easy to get, you can pretty much start breezing through the game after the first hour of playing. Bosses are incredibly easy (with the exception of one or two, but not by much tho) and stages are pretty to see, but easy to traverse once you start getting one or two items and power-ups.

Outside of the game being way-too-easy for its own good in general what it offers is great. The levels are pretty and intersting, the music is insanely good and, even if it easy, it will provide you with a handful of hours of great fun.

Again, its only sin(?) is just that its way too easy for its own good but that might be a plus to some, not so much for the more hardcore of players tho. 

Totally recomended

28512505.review:
As a longtime fan of the series I eagerly anticipated this game (and in fact I backed it on Kickstarter).  Well now that I've finished a playthrough I'd like to give it a good, honest review.

For those of you unfamiliar with the series, Shantae is a half-genie who protects a tiny little town called Scuttle Town that sits along the coast of a place called Sequin Land.  She defeats enemies by whipping them with her hair, and can eventually transform herself into multiple different forms that are useful for accessing hidden parts of the map (Some of these you'll unlock as the game progresses. Others you'll have to find on your own).  If you've played any other Metroidvania-style platformer, you'll have an idea what you're meant to do. Jump on often shaky platforms, defeat enemies, find lots of hidden items.  The platforming works well--the controls are quick and responsive and everything feels really good.  The game's story is pretty light fare, written cleverly.  It's not laugh-out-loud funny but there are a few good lines scattered about.

Graphically, the game is a treat.  It has a very cartoony art style, full of vibrant colors--it's a welcome relief from all the brown, gritty reality of most of today's games.  The game's audio is well done too. Voice acting is limited (only a few characters have any lines at all, and most of their lines aren't voiced).  This is easy to overlook, however.  The soundtrack is provided by Jake Kaufman (you may know him as virt) and the music in the game is up to his typical standards--it's mostly a combination of dance-pop and 70s funk with a light Middle Eastern vibe that fits the game really well.  Most of the music in the game is either new, or arranged versions of tracks from previous games. I don't think any of the music is carried over from previous titles, but there are a few that will sound familiar to anyone who's played older games.

If you are looking for a hardcore platformer, this isn't your game.  The difficulty curve in Half-Genie Hero is pretty mild, and even a novice player should be able to complete their first playthrough in about 6 hours or so. The challenge to this game comes in finding all the collectibles scattered throughout the world, or in attempting speed runs.  Some collectibles are hidden in plain sight and it's just a matter of unlocking the right power to get to them. Others are hidden deep in barely-accessible parts of a level and require some serious searching to locate.

So would I recommend this game?  Overall, yes.  It's not too expensive, and there's a lot of fun to be had playing it even if it's not incredibly hard.

28511307.review:
Fun game to play through, controls are tight, attacking feels good. Cast of characters are cute some more memorable than others, overall a joy to play through. The enviroments are quite detailed some of the plot is interesting (and disturbing if you think too much into it). Some puzzles can be fun to solve while others are merely wait until you get X powerup then backtrack, which honestly didn't really fit that well in an arcade style game like this.

But this game has a few issues with challenge, there are a couple of parts which are challenging BUT because of 1 hit kill hazards, so it is more of a change the angle of your jump or timing challenge.

Spells feel quite useless, only ever needing to use one just because I had to for a quest. Some forms just outright break some of the platforming stages allowing you to just skip entire segments by simply going off screen (Much like with Super Mario World and the Cape).

The main meat of the game, the gameplay itself the generic enemies are rather forgetable outside 1 - 2 enemy designs and many enemy types you can easily just ignore and run through if you feel like it. The main offender for this happening is how easy and quick it is to obtain powerups in this game that basically breaks your character. You will find that you are practically invincible after the first stage, once you obtained 2 health powerups and the armor that reduces all damage taken by half.


So to put thing short, the game is fun to play but if you are after something that can challenge you this may not be the game for you.

28507569.review:
Just what I expected. A cheerful and near flawless platformer, where you are, again, in perfect control of your character. 

The puzzles and boss fights are  challenging, especially if you're new to the series, which is a good thing! If you played the previous titles, you won't notice a large difference, but won't get bored aswell.

The zones' enemies now update, once you revisit them, reflecting that you've beaten the boss of that level.

Lots and lots of transformations. WayForward was like: you asked for more transformations? THERE U GO!

The playstyle is a mix between the original and Risky's Revenge, regarding the power-ups and weapons, making Pirate's Curse a unique experience. 

MOST IMPORTANTLY: The items (relics) you buy can make the game a walk in the park, but they can be disabled and you can define your own difficulty. 

There are some minor tech flaws, which I hope they get patched soon, other than that, I really recommend it. If you're a fan of the series, want a good platformer or another metroidvenia done right, then this is for you.

28507077.review:
Due to character limit, this is a brief review compared to my more detailed one on my website. See it [url=www.omaralikaj.com/reviews/games/shantae-half-genie-hero]HERE[/url]. Here here a lot things I liked about the game, and a few I didn't:


[b]PROS:[/b]
Interesting plot, and sub-plots and missions, plus funny and what-on-earth moments.

Transformations, acquired from the messenger, item shop, or snake merchant make a fun gameplay. Unlike Mario, they're essential in clearing certain areas.

I like that this game is not too cryptic, but some ways of collecting items were harder than others to figure out.

Great soundtracks. Having played the mobile version of "Lit", WayForward did it again.

Cool audio and sound effects, but some like Shantae ducking, or the centipede making grunt sounds, felt out of place.

The graphics feel like an interactive cartoon show. The stages are pretty, and surprisingly interactive.

Boss fights are fun and challenging, but, getting heart holders, power-ups, items, and acquiring new forms along the way, I felt like the later ones were easy.


[b]CONS:[/b]
Shantae's story at least is really short. Thankfully, the other stories/DLCs were funded via Kickstarter.
 
The game triggers purchased certain power-ups upon controlling my laptop's volume, as opposed to just pressing "C".
 
I avoid blowing up enemies with my flame attack when there are many of them on the screen, so the game won't crash. This happened 3x.

No clarification that store-bought items are essential for 100% completion.
 
You get "Hero Mode" after beating the game, but it feels unneeded, and only ideal for speedrun or clearing early stages and side missions quicker.

The brat the Mayor replaced Shantae with, even when she was genuinely worried, WayForward still showed the same image of her being a snub in the dialogues.

And finally, some stages or missions take a long time to get back to, especially the "Great Escape", where you can't get hit by a gear during [u]first try only[/u]. Thankfully, I got this achievement during my first speedrun.

28505224.review:
I feel so glad i finally had a chance to play this. I can definitely recommend it.

For those that ask, is it like Pirates Curse? Yes and no.
While 1/2 Genie Hero keeps the goofy Characters (friends and foes alike).

- I think the major difference to the prequels is: 
No more "Zelda like" Dungeons where you have to go back and forth collecting keys to unlock doors.
Instead each world has stories when you visit them. The developers made it a nice touch that almost every world is a bit different when you visit them a second time and the mainstory bypassed them.

- The Graphic is a pure collection of ART XD
- The Music is good too
- The Gameplay is good. Controlls are easy, but in my opionion the game should also have had a hard mode. Its way easier to beat than the former games. 
Ironically the game seems harder to me in the beginning when you only start with 2 heart containers... later you easily upgrade to half demage and collect like 10 more Heartcountainers. Only in Bossfights you can run into trouble of losing all energy then.

- That aside there are lots of items to search for. Stying true to a metroidvania like game you can only reach certain upgrades and items after you got something else at other places.


The Main story (including collecting all sidequests items) can be done in around 6 hours of a first playthrough.

2D横スクロール探索ゲーとしてお馴染みシャンティ新作がついに登場です！
今作はグラフィックがドット絵からアニメーションへ変わりましたが
ドット絵時代と同じく待機モーション、細かい表情、背景の動きと変わらずガンガン動きます。
キャラの動きがいちいちかわいいのも相変わらずです。ヌルヌル動いてます。人外娘多いです。
今作は過去作と違いsteam版に最初から日本語対応していますが翻訳は少し気になる部分が多いのが残念かもしれません。

今作はカメラワークも少し変わっており2Dながら横に進むと円状に動く場所が多くなり
（星のカービィ64みたいなカメラワーク）
以前に比べダイナミックな背景描写が増えております。
ゲーム内容も相変わらずメトロイドヴァニアらしく
「特殊なアイテムやテクニックを入手」
「以前のエリアへ戻り行けなかった場所をアイテムを使いさらに特殊なアイテムを手に入れ他のエリアへ・・・」
と言った形でただステージを攻略するだけではなく探索好きなゲーマー向けです。
操作もとても分かりやすいですがステージにギミックが多いためアクションゲームが苦手な人には不向きかもしれません。

2Dで可愛いキャラがぐりぐり動いてしかもがっつり探索したい！と言う方にオススメ出来る作品だと感じます。

28502358.review:
TL;DR: It's an excellent game. It has its shortcomings, but its strengths far outweigh its weaknesses. 9/10

From the studio that brought Booty Genie, Booty Genie 2, and Booty Genie 3: Booty Pirate, comes a new installment in the Booty Genie franchise, this time with full animated HD jigglies.

Now for my serious review.

-----------

GAMEPLAY: 8/10
It's a platformer, and a very good one at that. The jumping feels exactly as you'd expect, and Shantae's movement speed is at a very comfortable pace.
I very much enjoyed the amount of transformations available in the game, but at some point there were simply too many, and as a result, there were some transformations that ended up not being used at all. For example, I think there were 2 areas total where bat form was required, whereas every other area could have been covered by harpy form much more quickly and easily. If not for the fact that you don't get harpy form until later, I don't think I would have used bat form at all.
Shantae: Half-Genie Hero follows the same formula as the games before it, in which you collect items for people in different areas to unlock the next. Every now and then, you have to return to a previous level with new powers in order to access areas you were previously unable to. Now, this works extremely well in Pirate's Curse, where you only really have to go back maybe 3 or 4 times. In this game, however, I ended up going back to Main Street maybe 6 times, and because of how linear the levels feel this time around, it seems a lot more tedious than it really is. Gone are the exploratory corridors and branching pathways in this game. Seriously, where are the dungeons?
While it may seem tedious, the overall game feel, I think, makes up for the tediousness of the game. These were minor inconveniences at worst. The game still plays exactly as it should, and it feels amazing.

-----------

DESIGN: 10/10
Wayforward strikes out of the park once again with this game. The art design fits the style of the characters and the tone of the game so well. It uses a mix of 2D graphics on 3D environments, and still manages to fit the series as well as the old pixel art style, almost better even. Backgrounds were memorable, and really popped out, to the point where you could tell what level you were in just by the lighting. The new 2.5D approach to this one got a little bit dizzying in Scuttle Town Square, but it was something that I got used to very quickly.
The music, as usual, is a major high point to the game. The retro vibe mixed extremely well with the Middle Eastern tones, especially in Main Street. Virt, applause to you.

-----------

OVERALL: 9/10
Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is most definitely a Shantae game. It's got great controls, great gameplay, great art design, and amazing music, and I am excited for the upcoming DLC. Can I recommend it at $20.00? You'd probably wait for a sale or something, unless you plan on replaying this game a lot. It's no Pirate's Curse, but it's definitely one of the best in the series.

28501815.review:
This game blows me away. The art style is new and absolutely beautiful (just look at the trailer), the mechanics are the same as the previous games but tweaked and improved so it just feels better overall, and the soundtrack has got me unreasonably hyped the entire time. Level design seems to have much more thought put into it, beating Risky's Revenge and of course Pirate's Curse. I really wish I backed this on Kickstarter, but it was already funded by the time I got into the series. Absolutely, 100% worth it. The art and visuals left me extremely impressed, especially.

Also, the technical difficulties of the first two games seem to be absent here. (No framerate or resolution problems. Running at 1440p 144hz, settings were autodetected correctly.) It seems to be capped at 60fps, but that's only noticeable when the camera is panning, for the character sprites and UI don't really need it.

Make sure not to play this if you haven't first played Risky's Revenge and then Pirate's Curse. They both go for really low prices on sale.

+ Art and visuals are amazing
+ Same witty humor, which I personally really enjoy
+ Mechanics control so well, noticeable improvement over previous games
+ THAT SOUNDTRACK.
+ Level and boss/fight design is very thought out. This is a very welcome improvement over the previous games, especially Pirate's Curse. I'm impressed, I must say.
~ A little fast paced. At times I would like to stop and admire the scenery a bit more.
- Can't think of any constructive criticism. I will update if anything jumps out at me.

[h1]I waited to long for this...way to long...[/h1]
Shantae HGH was original backed back in 2013 and promissed to be finish in October 2014 - so the original Kickstarter project told. Now we have it Christmas 2016 and its finally there, after 3 years of waiting. Is the game good? Was it worth the wait? That all will i try to explain here in my review.

[h1]Shantae and the long story short[/h1]
Shantae began her journey back on the GBC but got more fame on the Nindendo DSi systems with her 2nd game "Risky's Revenge. Both titles were more like [b]Action adventures[/b] with (more or less) open worlds, metroidvania-like and a lot room to explore. Since Game nr. 3, "The Pirates Curse", The series changed more into a "stage-like-RPG" game. Still, the "stages" were pretty big and you really had a lot room ("still") to explore. Half-Genie Hero actually made more a step backward and gave the player only [spoiler]7 pretty short stages[/spoiler] to explore, one of them is the main town. Elephant Dance? Check. GAME. OF. THE. YEAR.

28496832.review:
[b][i]TLDR; if you like collecting stuff and revisiting levels to collect more stuff, you'll like this. Sort of like a Metroidvania with the level-to-level gameplay of Mega Man.[/i][/b]

Gameplay is fun. There's lots of items to collect if you want to get the 100% clear rating! Revisiting the stages with power-ups you've collected since is rewarding, occasionally expanding into areas you didn't expect. The upgrade shop is a nice idea, but could do with a bit more stuff in it. The difficulty curve starts a bit higher than average - it might be a bit difficult for a beginner player - but it peters out towards the end as it doesn't scale well to match all of the upgrades you've amassed. The bosses are okay, but some of them are quite boring, especially [spoiler]the two phases of the final boss[/spoiler]. Controls are nice and responsive (as they should be!), but I'd recommend using a gamepad.

The visuals are great! Shantae definitely benefits from not being on a tiny handheld screen! They've built upon the techniques they learnt while making [i]Ducktales: Remastered[/i] - bright 3D environments with 2D animated characters. The characters are really well animated, and share a nice, consistent style.

Music is on point as well! It's been done by the wonderful Jake Kaufman (who also appeared on previous WayForward titles). Definitely some very catchy songs in there, my favourite being the [spoiler]haunted castle[/spoiler] stage.

Luckily the story isn't the focus of the game, because it's an afterthought at best. I'm not familiar with the series, but it seems clear that they tried to squeeze every single earlier-established character into the game. They also introduce a new character... only to have [spoiler]that character be killed off five minutes later[/spoiler]. Overall, it doesn't really make much sense.

The writing is terrible - it definitely tries way too hard to be funny. It seems like it was written by a four-year-old; I remember one of the worst offenders being "[spoiler]hey, guess what? Monkey butts[/spoiler]". Unfortunately, you need to read some of the text to know what to do next; if you don't want to read it, try skipping through the main text, then talk to the NPC characters afterwards to get them to repeat the important details.

Overall, it's a good platforming experience! It suffers from being a bit short - it took me 7 hours to 100% it at a rather leisurely pace - but I'm aware that there's more content coming in the future.

28495691.review:
A very enjoyable little Metroidvania platformer. The art and music are excellent, the character designs are cute and fun, and the gameplay is solid.

For those who have never played a Shantae title, the premise is fairly unique: You play a half-genie bellydancing heroine who fights enemies using her magical prehensile hair and magical dances that allow her to transform into a dozen-odd different animals.

The game, unlike most previous Shantae titles, is split into distinct levels, which vary between being fairly linear to fairly open-ended, though both sorts allow for a fair amount of exploration and discovery. This division does make getting 100% much easier, as the level select lets you know what's left to find in a given level, so rather than having to hunt through the entire overworld you just have to explore on level, which is rather nice.

It's not flawless, the story is largely an afterthought, the jokes can fall flat, and some of the transformations see essentially no use, but the game is definitely fun and very much worth a look.

It took me about 7 hours to 100% the Shantae campaign (an additional campaign where you play as her arch-nemesis, Risky Boots, is being worked on), so this isn't going to occupy you for months, but that does make it comparable to Super Metroid for the amount of content, which is fine by me.

I am proud to have backed Shantae: 1/2 Genie Hero, and along with games like Shovel Knight stands as evidence to the usefulness of Kickstarter in delivering the game developers wanted to make to the players who wanted to play it. From the onset to the credits, its a delightfully colorful and vibrant platformer, that happens to be well written and funny on top of its mechanical excellence. I consider it a treat for returning fans and I'm sure, for newcomers as well.

As the first title in the series built for home consoles and PC, the graphical improvements are immediately apparent. We have come a long way from Game Boy Color, with vastly more fluid sprite animations over pleasing 3D backgrounds. It has notably lost none of the magic of its predecessors, as well as its reputation for charmingly attractive character designs that have just enough appeal to not be tacky. The controls are spot on, and should be familiar to anyone to has played SNES or Genesis era titles with a keyboard. 

I must give special consideration to the soundtrack, which I coughed up extra for during the Kickstarter. If you're at all familiar with Jake "Virt" Kaufman and his work on the previous Shantae games, Shovel Knight, Contra 4, Scurge: Hive and many other projects, you'll know what to expect. He's really outdone himself this time.

The transformation dances that are a hallmark of the series return, including at least once dance that hasn't been seen since the very first game. This one has by far the most dances and other upgrades, enough that collecting all of them makes you virtually indestructible, in particular making the final boss fight rather trivial. This would require you to actually FIND everything, but it's not the hardest Metroidvania to explore. In fact, it's structured more like the Megaman X games. It also has some harder platforming segments then Pirate's Curse.

The few negative reviews of the game all talk about the difficulty, or rather, the lack of it, and the afforementioned backtracking. At no point in the game did I find either of these things aggrivating. Having recently completed a solo playthrough of Bloodborne, I can tell you that there are hard games out there. And there are cheap ones, overhyped ones, and ones that value leaderboard scores over anything resembling fun. Shantae: 1/2 Genie Hero is none of those things, and that is fine. What it is, is a diamond in the rough, a game that made me feel good just to be alive to play it. I think it will do the same for you, and in the end, that's what gaming is really about.

28495386.review:
A game with beautiful, energetic aesthetics and unadventurous design.

+ Aesthetics in general are sharp, cartoony and juicy. The animations with Wrench are particularly fun.
+ Factory stage has a nice narrative progression.
+ Stage progression is more arcade-style than metroidvania-style, which is a fun change for the series.
+ New-form-containing genie rooms remind me of Rayman (PS1), and make understanding the basic utility of new forms very easy.
+ The writing is fun and self-deprecating. Most of the dialogue has great gameplay utility as well, guiding the player with hints (though the bolded text takes some of the fun out of parsing dialogue for the important bits).
+ VO is sprinkled throughout the game and contributes to the personality of the characters and dialogue. It seems like a clever (and budget friendly) way to equip our imaginations with a little more material.

- The megaman-style disappearing blocks are played out, and a little overused in some of the level designs.
- The dance selection screen is colorful, but has an odd timing-element that automates the cycling of menus. More than once I mis-selected as the menu switched at just the wrong time.
- Stages tend to introduce a new mechanic, but they don't seem particularly novel so far. This level features something you can climb / hang from (Donkey Kong Country). This level features wind that pushes you (Megaman). This level features...enemy spawners? Levels don't feel surprising after the novelty of new visuals wear off.
- The monkey form feels weirdly sticky when climbing on walls. It can feel awkward when I try to climb up over the side of a wall, or transform back into human form. The time lost performing attempting these acts often leads to cheap damage in combat situations.
- projectile-wielding enemies tend to shoot from off-screen, which can lead to cheap damage when playing an area for the first time. 
- The Wilbur worm escape features level design that essentially dooms the player if they proceed up the wrong path. The choice is arbitrary the first time a player sees it, so these deaths are very frustrating.
- Game over screen should have more character in a game as colorful as this. Players may see it several times, so why not try some arkham-asylum-style flavor dialogue?
- The hitbox of Shantae's human form seems a bit large. Shrinking it a bit within the actual sprite raises the odds for a daring, exciting dodge. Players who get used to the smaller hitbox can use it to make combat faster, more risky, and more showy
- Characters often animate during cutscenes and dialog, but without any zoom, this easily goes unnoticed (some dramatic zoom wouldn't seem out of place in a story this goofy).
- Monkey form seems to have far more general utility than the crab form.
- I wish there was an overarching villain to give the story a visible destination. As it stands, the magnet contraption ties things together a bit, but the player isn't even told how many pieces remain, or what the final design looks like (unless I'm missing something-- perhaps there was a way to look at the blueprints before handing them to uncle).
- The liberal use of VO really gives the characters...character, but we don't need Shantae revealing the high-level strategy to each boss phase. It takes away the fun a bit, and most are simple enough to simply not need it.
- There seems to be little difference between a fall-death and a game over. The latter should be a more impactful fate than the former, yet the latter typically places the player at the exact same location as the former, but with full health! Often, it is the better option, as being forced to restart an area without having health replenished sometimes sets the player up for quick, highly-probable (and frustrating) failure.
- Bosses don't seem to emphasize new abilities much, in the way a Legend-of-Zelda boss would. While LoZ bosses may go overboard with the way they require stage-specific abilities, the bosses here feel a little rote-- all they seem to require is a bit of hair-whipping and jumping, for the most part. Mechanics never really come together, or combine in interesting ways during these fights, and they never really feel exciting as a result.

Thank you for your effort on this game, and best of luck moving forward!

28495322.review: Adorable, and hilarious. I expected nothing less.

28494854.review:
This Shantae’s first HD adventure along with her returning genie powers, and it is excellent.

Story/Graphics/Music:
Like the previous entries, this is a very light-hearted story, not as great as Pirate’s Curse, but still fun. The cute style and great humor is all there, but in HD. You can probably tell from the screenshots, but this game looks beautiful and set a very high standard for future Shantae games to come. I also don’t know how Jake Kaufman did it, but the soundtrack is even catchier than the last. I’d also like to note that I really like how many older animations were carried over such as the butt wiggle as well as both the bouncy Shantae and Rottytops idle animation, because it wouldn’t feel right without them.

Gameplay:
We’re back to regular movement with genie transformations. I thought I'd miss the Pirate items, but transforming is quick and each one serves a good purpose. Levels are pretty big and while there is a decent amount of backtracking, it really feels like you’re exploring the map a lot more than previous titles. So while it is technically backtracking, it doesn’t feel like you’re going back to levels just for the sake of padding. Most of the time you’re looking for more items, if not you’re at least compelled to because finding secrets in this game is fun. Some of the secrets don’t blatantly stick out either so you’ll have to use a bit of brain power to find everything, which I perfectly welcome. Much of the annoyances some people had are also gone, such as being able to leave a level at any time and skipping any parts that you’ve already clear for free (once you receive the ability to). This means more playing and less waiting.

The combat is quick and satisfying like an old school Castlevania game. You get access to spells and upgrades that generally help you do more damage and take less damage. One of the great things about every one of these upgrades is that they can be toggled off. This is great because after fully completing the game I started a playthrough with minimal upgrades as a challenge. Bosses are generally fun, with a few that are the “wait for your turn” variety.

Some gripes:
I really only have two issues with the game, the first one being the missing dungeons. If you’ve played the previous Shantae games, you would consider these dungeons a staple in the series. You could say they’ve made up for it with bigger, more explorable levels, but fans have shown that they are missed.

My second gripe is the difficulty, way too easy this time around. I actually died being careless once or twice on the second level, but once you clear this and you get access to some money, you can reduce your damage by half. On top of that, you start to gain access to a lot more health upgrades so you’ll have tons health. Another issue is that most enemies will not knock you back when getting hit like you would a lot of the time in Pirate’s Curse. Because of this, I normally just ran through levels taking damage for the sake of speed. Most bosses can also be brute forced before you need to use items, however I will admit I had to use healing items for the last boss. If you really wanted to, you could also fully nullify damage by end game which is a very questionable balance decision. I mentioned earlier I'm on a limited upgrade playthrough thanks to being able to toggle off upgrades. Again, I'm glad this is something you can do.

Final thoughts:
This marks the beginning of some great Shantae games. They have the engine and everything they need to make a great game now. I see this game as a little reboot to the series so I’m hoping for many more to come. Some people might call this game too short. My first 100% playthrough was about 5 ½ hours, about 1 hour shorter than my first Pirate’s Curse run. I would say the amount of content is just a little under the last game because you save so much time with the new features I’ve mentioned before, such as skipping beaten sections. Another thing that saves time is that the town NPCs actually give you hints on where to go so you more or less always know what you have to do. Regardless of the short time, I loved every minute of it and I’m still re-playing the game even with all the achievements. I can’t wait for Risky’s campaign and any more content to come. If you’re into these types of games, there’s absolutely no reason you shouldn’t own Pirate’s Curse and Half Genie Hero.

Edit: And now the added content/DLC (received free for being a kickstarter backer)

Hard mode: It's actually pretty hard. There is smaller limit to useable items and enemies not only do more damage, but are faster too. Definitely harder to brute force your way through.

Pirate Queen's Quest: Fun alternate story where you play as Risky. Has altered levels tailored to the returning pirate items you receive throughout the story. It rewards you for looking for the extra collectables by using them make your abilities stronger.

Friends to the End: Tag-team control Shantae's 3 friends each with their attacks and abilities. A decent challenge too since there is shared health and very limited healing. Similar to Pirate Queen's Quest, the levels are tailored to the abilities, which are all available from the get-go. There's also an interesting mechanic where your characters do more damage the more gems you collect, but you drop some upon taking damage.

The extra content altogether can easily extend the game for another 4-10 hours depending on how much of a completionist you are. If you want really want extend your stay in Sequin Land, I'd say pick them up, but maybe wait for a sale as it is a little pricy.

28493306.review:
It's good. It's not the pinnacle of outstanding platforming like, I dunno, Mario, but it's still a very solid game with good jokes interwoven with it, much like the rest of the series. Ultimately the whole adventure is maybe six to eight hours long.

There are some downsides, though; it's plainly obvious some content was abandoned during development. A lot of various abilities to pick up over the game or even series staples like the destructible blocks only serve to, straight up, get one thing before becoming useless again. This one thing could actually be plot demanded or just a health upgrade. It's very strange in that regard; time was spent on giving Shantae a spider form, yet it's used for A Puzzle and then never so much as useful again.

28493156.review:
Half-Genie Hero is a triumphant return of the Shantae series. The art style and animation is so fluid and detailed, there are times when I'm honestly not sure if what I'm looking at is a sprite or 3D model. I've NEVER had a game make me question this, and it's a testement to artists and animators who brought Shantae to life.

The game is equally a blast to play. Controls are fluid and responsive, even the seconds needed to cycle between Shantae's animal forms don't take too long to break flow. Combat with Shantae's equally detailed and expressive foes is challenging, without being too frusterating. The platforming never gets so pixel-perfect as to want to break your controller, especially with Shantae having multiple ways to progress through challenges. I am also happy to say I never needed to go Googling for the answer to any puzzles or platforming challenges.

The game is relatively short, I finished in about 3 days, spending 2-3 hours each run. Despite being metroid-vania in structure, the game is spread over different stages you chose to travel to, akin to Shantae and the Pirate's Curse. However, every stage is PACKED with secrets, and I found myself going through each stage again whenever I gained a new ability. The stages themselves visually change after the boss is defeated, making return trips feel fresh. Plus, there's new characters that will be added to the game for free with their own campaigns in the future, and I am eager to play them!

The boss fights themselves are amazing. Many even zoom out to make room for the massive boss on screen. Each one is intense and satisfiying to fight, though none proved to be so difficult that I could not defeat on the first try.

Like most of the Shantae games, the plot is fairly standard, and you can probably see all the twists a mile away. Though, like most of the Stantae games, the story is more defined by the characters and their dialogue, all of which is cleaverly written. Shantae and her friends are utterly hilarious and witty, and it's worth playing the game just to see them bounce quips off one another.

My only serious complaint is the relatively weak finale, especially compared to the previous games. The final battle is disapointing, as is the conclusion, at least compared to the last 2 games. For less serious complaints, the story overall, especially in terms of character development, isn't quite as good as Pirate's Curse, though still good. There's also an issue of balance, as most of Shantae's animal forms are pointless to use in combat. You even wind up finding upgrades that enable them to attack too late in the game for them to be of any use. Shanate my actually have too many attacks, spells and abilities, most of which can't match her standard hair attack. And by the end of the game, I was stuffed with so many healing items and restorative abilities, I could brute-force my way through anything.

None of these issues make me regret Kickstarting this game. The greatest testement to its quality, is the longing I felt to play more games like it, and seeing nothing in my steam library that match it.

If you enjoy platformers, quality indie titles, metroid-vania, or just want a enjoyable tale about a beautiful and witty Half-Genie, Buy This Game!

*Note: Was a backer on the Shantae: Half-Genie Hero Kickstarter.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GAr_68TOh0U

+Gameplay is smooth and fluid
+Graphics are super slick
+Music is catchy as all hell
+Great level design reminescent of 8/16-bit Capcom titles
+Interesting enemies with slightly more complex patterns than typical of the series
+Amazing set pieces and boss encounters

-Bikini Armor, Magic Tiara and the ridiculous number of heart containers break the difficulty utterly. Don't go into this game expecting a challenge past the first couple of levels if you aren't willing to handicap yourself on purpose.

-I honestly can't remember a single puzzle
-I can't put enough quotation marks around the word "dungeon" so I won't even try
-At least for me, the frame rate stutters when I go through a level as fast as I possibly can

This is the least Metroidvania Shantae game that I've played, so keep that in mind. If you play these games for things like Risky's Revenge's Hypno Tower or Pirate's Curse's Cackle Tower, you should be warned that this game is more like Mega Man X than Super Metroid. That said, it excels at that sort of level design and I welcome the change... at least for now.

But yeah, as many issues as I had with the game, it was a load of fun and I'd wholeheartedly recommend it.

28492099.review:
Disclaimer: I'm a kicstarter backer and I was able to play this game early. I completed my first playthrough on December 19th. There are no spoilers in this review.

I have been a long time fan of the Shantae series, the unique charm of the protagonist combined with the world the stories are set in made it for a fun and unique experience every time. The series falls into what qualifies as a Metroidvania. All games encourage backtracking and exploration as you gain more powers and mobility, the rewards being more story and of course, a higher completion. To my knowledge the latest two games even have multiple endings determined by your completion rate.


Some history:
---------------
The first game in the series called "Shantae" came out late in the Game Boy Color's life (2002) and was a superbly animated game for the time. In my opinion it is also the most difficult game in the series so far as the first hour or two before you gain more abilities can be brutal. In this game, Shantae was set out to stop her ever present rival, the pirate called Risky Boots and her horde of Tinkerbats. The physical version of this game is quite rare nowadays. Thankfully, if you own a (New) 2/3DS/XL you can play this game via Virtual Console.

The second game "Risky's Revenge" came out much later (2010) for the DS/DSi and was a worthy follow up that saw Shantae once again facing off against Risky Boots as the pirate lady sought revenge for the events in the first game. This game is still available for the DS series of portables and a PC version has been released as well, available right here on Steam.

The third game came out in 2014 and is called "Pirate's Curse". This is the first game in the series to provide some voice acting, but also features a plot where Risky Boots seeks Shantae's help in defeating a foe more dangerous than her. Nevertheless I think this is the best game in the series so far. This game came out on a lot of platforms, including PC. The 3DS version has some nice depth effects as well.
----------------

Does it mean that Half-Genie Hero is an inferior game? Not at all! From a personal perspective I think Pirate's Curse has a better story and higher stakes (although even that could be argued as there is a lot at stake in HGH too, plot wise). But the gameplay, graphics and music are superb as expected from the experienced team at WayForward as well as the designs of Matt and Erin Bozon (who created Shantae) and the music of my favourite games musician, Jake "Virt" Kaufman.

That said, in HGH, Shantae is once again out to face off against Risky Boots who seeks to abuse the knowledge she gained during "Pirate's Curse".  The controls are good and the storytelling is funny in the right places. Transformation magic returns once more (it was absent in "Pirate's Curse") but has been simplified to speed up game play.

If you wonder if you should play all games in chronological order...that depends on you! While each game can be played on its own without knowing the earlier stories, there are some small nods here and there to events from previous games. Even so, HGH makes sure you are introduced to each character and immediately know what they are like.

There were some problems in the version I played and I expect they will get ironed out after the game is released tomorrow. While not breaking, some powers can be exploited to make sections of the game extremely trivial. If you happen to find such a way, consider challenging yourself!

All in all, it took me the listed time as of this review (11.7) hours to finish the game first time through. I had to peruse some youtube videos to find some items I missed, but the game does clue you in . I recommend talking to everyone after each plot event!

-----------------

TL;DR: Great game, as polished as expected from the creators. Personally I think the story in the previous game was better, but that's my opinion and doesn't detract from the gameplay enjoyment.

Быстро я прошел Shantae: Half-Genie Hero, 7 часов, если сравнивать с Shantae and the Pirate's Curse, на которую у меня ушло 17 часов, это довольно немного. Какие плюсы хочется выделить, это все так же хороший платформер, с приятным управлением и игровым процессом. Перевод картинки в HD, мне честно говоря не очень понравился, больше на flash анимацию похож, pixel art был лучше. Изменился и стиль артов во время диалогов, вместо больших и округлых артов, стали мелкие угловатые, причем зачем-то сверху экрана, пример прикреплю. Самый большой минус игры — это ее сложность, точнее ее отсутствие. Игра не дает какого-либо испытания игроку, даже достать все предметы не сложно. Босы из-за обилия здоровья убиваются одной кнопкой. Кристаллы фармятся стоя на одном месте. Заходим в баню, превращаемся в кувшин и жмем одну кнопку 10 минут, все, у вас все предметы, которые можно купить в магазине. А собрав все сердца, коих тут аж 14, можно даже не думать о лечении, так как повреждение отнимает всего четверть одного сердца. Но если и этого мало, собираем все ключи от галереи, что сделать не сложно и получаем тиару с бесконечной манной, все, вы неуязвимый терминатор. 
Трансформаций в игре 12, если в прошлых частях, что бы убить боссов надо было использовать найденные предметы, то тут максимум для чего вам потребуется трансформация, так это достать один - два предмета. А в конце вы используете только одну Гарпию. Есть еще трансформация в дерево, с которого падают апельсины, так вот, в этой форме Shantae, не получает урона совсем, вовремя битвы с босом можно просто переждать любую атаку. В итоге, я ожидал большего, а именно не хуже предыдущих частей, а получил казуальный платформер на один день. Shantae: Half-Genie Hero, неплохая игра, но в отличии от Shantae and the Pirate's Curse, играть в нее снова не тянет.

28491512.review: After 100% finish I can say that the game is definitly worth every penny. Half Genie Hero is a really good entry in Shantae series with amazing 2.5D artstyle graphics and smooth controls. There are 2 things I didn't liked: game was way too easy, and felt too "small" in comparison to other Shantae games. On the other hand soundtrack was spot on, and everything from animations, to boss fights were fun to play and watch.

28491372.review:
Shantae: 1/2 Genie Hero is exactly what it was initially intended to be: a shined and polished Shantae title that offers a fourth helping of exactly what made the previous titles so well-loved. While it still has a lot of growing to do to live up to everything WayForward has promised (in the form of DLC and other bonuses), the core game is ret-2-go, and for the most part, it's pretty wonderful.

As with previous installments, Shantae: 1/2 Genie Hero follows a policy of "if it ain't broke, don't fix it," retaining the same core gameplay mechanics it's always had while further refining the way extras like items and transformations work.

As always, Shantae runs, jumps, and attacks enemies with her hair, exploring (and occasionally backtracking through) five main worlds, each chock full of secrets and surprises, and as with the first two titles, earns (or discovers) new transformations that enable her to navigate her world in different ways.

While the immediate predecessor (The Pirate's Curse) temporarily did away with transformations in favor of new abilities that blended seamlessly with Shantae's standard controls, reverting to the transformation mechanic is handled tastefully. Shantae can now choose from a palette of up to 12 "dances," which are accessed via a single button press and subsequent single directional command, enabling Shantae to transform in and out of forms hastily to suit the occasion. Many of these dances are optional, hidden, or available for purchase, and a few are actually mutually exclusive- players must decide if they'd rather hold onto, say, a convenient teleportation dance, or a form that spits out free money. Players are free to change their mind on these choices, but only via trade with the merchant who sells said optional dances.

While a few of these forms are combat-capable (or can be made so via hidden upgrades), few if any are ever more viable for combat than Shantae's base form. Though Shantae can no longer pick up hand-to-hand secret techniques or upgrade her arsenal with pirate weaponry, her trusty battle-ponytail can be upgraded as in previous titles do deal quite a bit of damage. If this seems duller than integrating projectiles and blades into your fighting style, fear not. Series mainstay items like the Pike Ball and Storm Puff have been given a very welcome upgrade- rather than consumables to be purchased and used at the player's discretion, these magic items now manifest as permanent upgradeable skills in Shantae's arsenal, swapped out as sub-weapons and usable for as long as Shantae has the magic power to deploy them (think Mega Man). Thus, players can now hurl flames and thunderbolts at will, or protect themselves with barriers and damaging satellites. While not quite as seamless as the previous title's pirate powers, this is a fun system that puts the series' classic quirky weapons on full glorious display. 

This is largely a welcome change, but I couldn't help but notice that sometimes the extra powers made things *too* easy. The fully upgraded bubble shield, for example, makes Shantae completely invincible for as long as she has magic remaining. This synergizes very well with items that expand Shantae's mana pool, to the point that by the game's final challenge, I found I was able to remain invincible indefinitely. I'm not sure if this was an oversight or simply poor judgment, but I hope to see it fixed in the near future- I'm not opposed to letting players enjoy some casual godmoding, but I feel like offering it to players just before the last boss is in poor taste.

Indeed, the difficulty of the game is perhaps its weakest attribute. While the game has a few sections that new players are very likely to need to repeat again and again (an aspect soothed tremendously by the introduction of frequent autosaves), I often found myself sufficiently geared and upgraded to pass most challenges on my first try, not from skill, but from simply having so many health items and defensive upgrades at my disposal. The game does offer players the choice to turn off any specific upgrade at will (which is, honestly, a fantastic option to provide), but offers no real incentive to do so- after facing the odd gauntlet of instant death two or three times, I falsely presumed the rest of the game would match that challenge and prepared accordingly, only to watch the rest of the game crumble before my seemingly-bottomles well of force fields and monster steaks, and before I knew it, it was over.

After three years in development, I'm a little surprised. True, the worlds are enormous and the powers vast, but five main worlds? Just five? I confess I'm a bit disappointed by the shortness. I completed this game with 100% progress in exactly the same amount of time as I took to complete the previous title. DLC promises new levels and modes, such as the ability to play as the other main characters in their own separate stories, and as much as I did truly and consistently enjoy my first playthrough as Shantae, I do welcome the chance to do it all again differently. Still, until those new modes arrive, I must say, the game feels a little scant for all the work that's clearly gone into it.

And to speak of that work- my goodness is this game ever gorgeous. The characters are presented as hand-drawn faithful recreations of their old sprites, and if one recalls just how fluidly-animated those sprites were, one can correctly assume the degree to which this title absolutely gushes charm. The visual style of lively 2D characters against lovingly-rendered 3D backdrops works marvelously here, and unlike other 2.5D titles there's no question of where obstacles begin and end.  Shantae: Half Genie Hero is without a doubt the tightest 2.5D game I've yet experienced.

As for the story, it's a bit less compelling than its immediate predecessor, but every bit as hilarious. Shantae has really found its essence in humor and awkard charm- I caught myself laughing out loud once or twice, and my heart lept to see certain characters reappear. Still, while I was never bored by the dialogue or story, I don't feel that this game has yet managed to outdo itself in terms of weaving a truly epic narrative. Pirate's Curse opened the characters up to a measure of depth not previously seen- we saw a powerless Shantae, a vulnerable Risky, a lost Rottytops, a successful Bolo and a terminally misfortunate Sky. None of this is present in Shantae's latest adventure, and while it does tell a pleasantly lighthearted story, we've seen WayForward do better.

After so much time in development, Shantae: 1/2 Genie Hero feels solid, if surprisingly sparse, and is over long before it has a chance to wear out its welcome. With the promise of expansive DLC on the horizon, I feel hopeful that WayForward will gradually flesh this game out into the epic adventure we imagined it becoming. Perhaps future stories will introduce us to new sides of beloved characters, offer us the chance to approach the world from a new perspective, or simply expand upon an already successful formula. For now, though, it's another short yet fantastic romp through Sequin Land, and well worth the price of admission.

28491291.review:
Взял игру сразу же при появлении возможности купить. На данный момент уже завершил прохождение. Так что же - быстренько пробежимся по сюжету:

Шантэ снится сон о том, что измерение джиннов в опасности. Затем она проснулась. Потом на город опять нападает Риски Бутс со своей командой, хотя Шантэ отбивает атаку. После всего этого дядюшке Мимику приходит идея собрать так называемый Dynamo - машину, которая защищала бы Скаттл Таун от внешних угроз. Вот так большинство игры Шантэ будет искать компоненты для сбора этой машины. Чем это всё обернётся, спойлерить не буду.

Поговорим о геймплее. Насколько помнится, магию мы восстановили в хорошей концовке прошлой игры (Shantae and the Pirate's Curse). Это значит, что вернулись в наше распоряжение полоска магии, магические способности и танцевальные трансформации. Трансформаций на данный момент можно собрать аж 12 (в Risky's Revenge было всего 3), также упрощен их вызов - жмем Y, ждем нужного набора и отклоняем левый стик в нужную сторону. Есть некоторые приветы и к Pirate's Curse - отображение нанесенного урона. Что насчет нашего здоровья - начинаем опять с двумя сердечками, но прокачиваются они старыми добрыми Heart Holder'ами (на этот раз до 14 штук). Существующие в игре области больше похожи на уровни для какого-нибудь платформера. Каждый уровень содержит хотя бы две разные части и босса в конце, после прохождения получаем транформацию. Транспортировщиком на уровни является Скай, управляющая... только не упадите... гигантским Рэнчем (который, как бы, все время был ручной птицей Скай). На уровни можно возвращаться даже после прохождения, чтобы собирать всякие дополнительные ништяки. Так что, все-таки игра осталась метроидванией. Магия мне понравилась. Есть магические способности в следующем порядке:
• Фаербол, тройной фаербол, огнемет (классика);
• Шипастый шар и его тройной аналог (классика 2);
• Щит-пузырь, отражающий щит и щит неуязвимости (прекрасно, но уже имба);
• Куча ятаганов, крутящихся вокруг Шантэ (крутейшее дополнение).
Для лечения, опять же, используются зелья и несколько типов еды.
С геймплеем все более, чем в порядке.

Графика. Игра даже не вышла на 3DS, так что теперь вся графика прорисована более качественно, в HD. По пикселям, я все же, буду скучать. Но выглядит Half-Genie Hero просто потрясающе.

Музыка. Я человек простой - раз Джейк Кауфман взялся за саундтрек, то и получится музыка на ура. Half-Genie Hero не стала исключением. Саундтрек здесь все такой же прекрасный и слушать его приятно.

Ну ладно - итог. Как бы так сказать: новая Half-Genie Hero где-то однозначно превзошла Pirate's Curse, но также и проиграла в кое-каких аспектах (игра слишком уж простая и чувствуется немного недоделанной, а также пришлось долго привыкать к системе уровней).
Если начистоту - получилось хуже, чем Pirate's Curse, но все еще лучше, чем Risky's Revenge. Я ждал большего, однако игра хорошая и достойна внимания. Оценка [b]9/10[/b] подойдет лучше всего. Я остался, в целом, доволен. Если вы любите платформеры и метроидвании, то рекомендую раскошелиться на данную игрулю.

28491170.review: Le jeu est correct, mais il est aussi mignon que bancal dans son level design et son game design.
