28490969.review:
Cute characters and light-hearted humor elevate this tiny indie gem of a game.

True to the series roots, Shantae combines a liberal amount of classic Megaman-esque run and jump platforming with a bit of exploration and backtracking ala Castlevania/Metroid. As you beat bosses and explore the mostly linear levels, you will earn upgrades to open up new pathways through levels and discover secrets in previously completed areas. 

While relatively small in scale, it matches the length of the previous installments in the franchise (about 6 hours for my first time to 100%) and certainly lives up to the legacy of its lavishly illustrated predecessors, trading in it's former pixel art for hand animated characters and brightly painted textures. Level design is clean and concise, making up for a lack of quantity with a density of quality content for the price. This game maintains the series focus on light-hearted humor and cute characters, with a strong soundtrack to tie the experience together.

Some upgrades curiously seem superficial and under utilized in the level design (i.e. the Bat Sonar ability is only use-able in one side room and the room can still be navigated using visual cues from other light sources), but most content in the game is well utilized throughout the game.

The storyline feels much more segmented than previous titles, probably due to the fact that each level was a different "stretch goal" when the game was being kickstarted. This makes the plotline and characters feel much more episodic and less developed than previous entries (especially comparing it to Pirate's Curse), but overall tone maintains a sort of "Saturday morning cartoon" feel that remains consistent across the entire game.

While the current release only includes Shantae as a playable character, [i]future updates have promised an expanded roster of playable characters[/i], but they are [b]not[/b] in the game as of this review. Wayforward generally doesn't do many post-release updates (they have a good track record of releasing games that very feature complete), but this is also their first crowdfunded game so time will tell just how well these promised expansions end up being.

28490955.review:
Backed the game, loved it. Personal GOTY 2016. It's a bit on the short side but new game modes, characters and costumes are still to come. I hope later they would also add in the chapters that didn't get funded in the Kickstarter. It could fit the sort of episodic story structure of this game. Because really I just wish there were more of it. It's got solid gameplay, great music, funny writing, good art direction, alright replay value, all the kinds of things I'm looking for in a game.

(I'm not paid by Wayforward to write this)

28490879.review:
As someone who backed this game way back when, I gotta say what we got on hand (so far) definitely made the 3 year wait worth it ~

Much like Pirate's Curse it controls like a dream, and the soundtrack is top notch Kaufman as always. The addition of fully-drawn graphics especially help this game shine, especially during Boss Fights and occasional set-piece like sliding through the Mermaid Falls or escaping certain death in Tassel Town's Tower.

Transforming into certain animals has been retooled from the first two games, and this time for the better. It's great to be able to switch between forms on the fly rather than having to perform a brief dancing mini-game or waiting for Shantae to make a specific dance. Only downside is that I felt some transformations are better than others (the Spider Form is borderline useless. ;;), though thankfully there's more good ones than lame ones.

The overall playthrough did feel pretty short, with only 6 levels (some of which you need to do some backtracking for the sake of plot), but it's not that much shorter than say the entirety of Pirate's Curse. On top of that this is only taking Shantae's Campaign into account, so the matter of game length is currently negligible at best. Really looking forward to when they bring about the Risky Boots and the other Campaigns starring Shantae's friends.

Overall this is a very tightly made package, and is worth the investment! Check it out if you get the chance (preferably once there's more DLC available ~). :)

28490792.review:
DISCLAIMER: I am a backer of this title and paid $55.

A project started 4 years ago has come to fruition and I'll be honest, it easily makes my personal game of the year. Playing similar to previous titles like Ducktales Remastered, A Boy and his Blob, and various other titles by the company it shows that Wayforward has not lost it's touch with making platformers. Bright, cheerful and a difficulty that ranges from easy to difficult without being a cackewalk or mind-numbingly difficult. Often compared to Mighty No. 9, Wayforward delivered on something that Comcept failed to do so: a relatively smooth game that has very intuitive gameplay mechanics and stages that put the mind to work as much as the fingers. The bosses, while really large (HUGE in some cases) all have a very capable strategy to beat. To add, while there are cases of a large number of enemies, I never felt at any point where I was forced to take a hit, making untouchable runs a fun challenge. To add, as with most Wayforward titles there is a game clock so speedrunners are going to have fun optimizing this game. The music and voices are superb as always with variations of Jake Kaufman (Wayforwards cheif Maestro) and Cristina Vee's (the voice actor for Shantae amongst others and the lead singer) "Dance Through the Danger" interspecced throughout amid an incredible selection of other music.

As good as the game is, it is not perfect however. There are two nagging issues. The dances are not as dynamic as the tools from Pirate's curse though the mechanic has been improved from previous iterations, utilizing a radial menu system instead of button presses or timing cues. However there are three panels of four icons that cycle automatically, slowing down the gameplay. This can be sped up with a store purchase but that also has the drawback of accidentally picking the wrong dance. Second, like Ducktales Remastered the game is laid out in a stage format as opposed to a single world format like the original game or Risky's Revenge and each stage has a LOt of stuff to collect, often requiring special hidden dances and abilities. This necessitates a LOT of backtracking in the stages, in some cases being required to progress. Personally, not a huge issue but it can frustrate players. Both of these issues are relatively minor and only impact the game in marginal ways. 

Overall, another fantastic game from an incredible team who have the support of their fans. People on the fence waiting to know whether it will be any good or not can rest easy knowing that Wayforward can still deliver a fun game with a mix of fast paced gameplay, humorous characters and story, and a bright, colorful world.

28490690.review:
Gotta get that right off the bat: I'm one of 18.500+ backers that made this game possible and I'm happy how it turned out.

You play as Shantae, a half-genie and sole protector of Scuttle Town, ready to defend it against any threat. She uses her long, purple hair as a weapon, alongside few offensive and defensive spells. Her magical heritage allow her to perform a variety of belly dances that transform her into various forms, each with different uses. For example, she can turn into a crab and a mermaid, but only her crustacean form can snap through tangled vines, while as a water nymph she can swim properly and attack with bubbles.

Even though it is a part of a series, you absolutely don't need to play any other Shantae game. All characters from previous installments (plus few new faces) make a return and are properly reintroduced. Plot is once again silly with tongue-in-cheek, self-aware humor sprinkled all over. There are six levels in total, but as you unlock new abilities you can replay them to find numerous hidden collectibles and secrets. 

This time WayForward went for HD graphics instead of pixel art I dare say it turned out pretty well. All character models are hand drawn, big, colorful and wonderfully animated. They mesh really well with lush, detailed backgrounds.

Not everything is shiny though. Sometimes a tool tip or two would be helpful. For example, it took me half of my play through to realize that you can jump directly down through some platforms. There are also few frustrating sections that simply require player to memorize sequences of obstacles by trial and error. That wouldn't be much of a problem if it weren't for inconsistent checkpoints. Thankfully you can obtain a special dance to skip sections of a previously completed levels. Levels that try their hardest to hide that they are way too short and  you will be revisiting them many times even if you don't want to get 100% of items. Story is also noticeably weaker compared to previous Pirate's Curse, where Shantae, Risky and each side-character had a story arc.

Finishing the game took me around 7 hours and unlocked new game plus mode. There is at least one planned free DLC (for backers) with (supposedly) brand new story. There might be more content coming along the way based on stretch goals, which may or may not turn it into best Shantae game to date.

A solid entry in the series, slightly below Pirate's Curse. Recommended.

28490687.review: Great game, its just I-MUST-HAVE for every platform/arcade game fan!

28490659.review:
(Note: Shantae Half-Genie Hero was a Kickstarter-funded game, and this reviewer backed it at the $12 level.)

Shantae Half-Genie Hero is an exploratory platformer made by developer Wayforward Technologies, and it's absolutely fantastic. As the titular half-genie, Shantae, you run all around the world of Sequin Land, alternating between finding machine parts for your uncle and solving various crises that might pop up. Instead of an interconnected sidescrolling world map with towns and dungeons like previous games in the series, Half-Genie Hero opts to give you a handful of large stages, each divided into sub-areas and each filled with hidden permanent upgrades and/or new mobility options. On your first visits to these stages, you'll only be able to grab a few items. As you unlock new powers, however, you gain the ability to explore new parts of the levels and gain even more abilities and powerups to help you through the game.

Shantae's main attack is whipping her hair, but you also have the ability to transform into different animals. These vary in usage, and they'll be often used to get to the aforementioned new areas. From a wall-climbing monkey to a sea-swimming mermaid to a high-flying harpy, the powers are welcome and interesting to use... although some are situational. You can also purchase magic spells for more offensive/defensive capability, and these are helpful items to grab as well. The game looks and sounds amazing, with HD art assets for all the characters and 3D rendered platforms to jump and climb over. Its soundtrack by Jake Kaufman is especially catchy, and you'll have the hooks of more than a few stage tracks in your head. Helpful, since you'll be revisiting them a lot.

There are only one or two flaws with the game, and one is far less a transgression than the other. Some of the upgrades hardly change anything, and feel like filler. Attacks for forms you'll hardly use unless you're messing around, or powers used exactly once in a single area to gain another hidden item. In addition, things peak before the climax; the final two stages offer almost no hidden treasures to be found whatsoever. It's as if the game runs out of momentum before the end, and speaking of that we must discuss the penultimate boss. The fights before and after it are relatively engaging and straightforward, but in this middle fight you can only deal damage when the boss uses one of three attacks. The problem is that it spams the other two over and over again, turning what should be a three-minute fight into an agonizingly slow-paced slog where you're just waiting around, dodging the same two easily-dodged attacks over and over again and waiting for the game to decide to give you a chance to deal damage. It's unfortunate and really deflates the climax of an otherwise great game.

At $16 USD you're looking at a five to six-hour experience, if you go for 100% item completion. That would be a bit short for the price, but there's an unlocked "Hero Mode" that lets you play the game over with most of your endgame transformations, and fly through it for kicks in half the time. Other playable modes are forthcoming, so I feel confident in saying the asking price is a worthy investment and giving this the thumbs-up. If you're a fan of the "retro" style of platformers, or love exploratory games like Demon's Crest or Odallus The Dark Call, this will absolutely be your jam.

28490526.review:
Спустя три года ожиданий после кикстартера Shantae: Half-Genie Hero, наконец, вышла. Так как теперь в приоритете не слабенькие нинтендовские портативки, то спрайты в игре нарисованы в честном HD, а не гигантскими пикселями. Всё выглядит и анимировано очень красиво. Игровой процесс тоже поменялся. Прошлые игры Shantae были метроидваниями с одной большой картой, здесь же набор отдельных уровней, а карты, на которую можно было бы посмотреть, нет вовсе. Сами уровни состоят из нескольких частей, обычно это длинная полоса слева направо, потом большая локация в стиле предыдущих частей, потом что-нибудь ещё, а затем босс. Несмотря на поменявшийся подход к уровням, суть игры осталась прежней, как и в метроидваниях — играешь, получаешь новые способности, возвращаешься на пройденные места, там забираешься туда, куда раньше не мог, берёшь там квестовые предметы, тебе за них дадут ещё какую-нибудь способность, и ты можешь попасть куда-то ещё, и так далее. Способности тут, как и раньше — это трансформации в животных, и их тут аж 12 штук, хоть и не все полезны.

Когда получаешь новую транформацию, сразу замечаешь, что в уровнях это учтено, и с ней можно сократить прохождение уровня. Например, можно слоном подтолкнуть большой блок к стене, с него обезьяной запрыгнуть на стену и добраться до прохода дальше. Или залезть на противоположную стену и пролететь в нужное место летучей мышью, которая умеет летать по горизонтали, обойдясь без слона. Или превратиться в гарпию и вообще сразу долететь докуда надо. Видно, что над уровнями старались. Очень много всяких секретов разной степени хитрости. В них попадаются необязательные улучшения способностей, предметы для получения другой концовки или увеличение количества здоровья.

Что может подпортить впечатление — низкая сложность. Игра намного легче прошлых частей, проиграть сложно. В концу игры можно прокачать здоровье до 14 сердец, за один удар от которых отнимается всего четвертинка, да ещё и восполнить здоровье можно кучей способов. Я не представляю, как вообще можно проиграть, когда накапливается хотя бы 5-6 сердец. Игровая валюта — драгоценные камни, на покупку магии и улучшений их нужно потратить много, но можно превратиться в кувшин с камнями, откуда они будут вылетать, пока мана не кончится. А если учесть, что в игре есть бассейн, в котором магия и здоровье восполняются, то сразу понятно, как этим можно воспользоваться. Итого после нескольких минут стояния в одном месте можно всё вкачать по максимуму и потом пробегать уровни, врубив кинжалы, которые крутятся вокруг Шантэ и рубят всё на своём пути или вообще неуязвимость. У боссов есть затяжные атаки, по их можно переждать, превратившись в дерево, которое не получает урона совсем и тратит ману только на выращивание на себе апельсинов, которые можно и не выращивать. А если собрать все 10 запрятанных ключей от галереи с рисунками (но всё же для этого придётся напрячься), то мэр города за это даёт тиару, с которой мана становится бесконечной и остатки сложности улетучиваются напрочь. Получается, игрок должен сам себя ограничивать, отключая слишком мощные умения и улучшения. Мне такое не нравится, предпочитаю, когда игра ставит свои условия, а игрок к ним приспосабливается. После прохождения игры открывается героический режим, и думаете, в нём сложность повышена? Нет, там всё то же самое, только половина трансформаций доступна с самого старта!

В общем, если вы сумеете совладать с искушением нафармить камней (я не смог), то получите лучшие впечатления от игры. Но в любом случае, я её рекомендую всем любителям 2D-платформеров и метроидваний. Думаю, она всем понравится.

28490506.review:

For anyone complain with the shortness of the game, it because they  dont reach extra stage mileage during KS. I hope this game can expand after initial release.

28490487.review:
Great level design, very tight controls, and wonderful music are the best ways to describe this game.  Every level feels fresh and unique, and the game very heavily (almost to a fault) promotes revisiting old areas with new abilities to discover secrets and items.  There are a few bugs here and there, but nothing that harmed the experience.  My only gripes with the game is that there aren't enough areas to explore (5 in total), and the lack of overall challenge in the game.  I said that the areas are fun to explore, but they are considerably less fun the umpteenth time an npc sends you out looking for an item.  Many items can be achieved prior to an npc asking for them however, and those looking for the shortest completion time will be challenged to find the quickest way to collect everything.  Enemies do very little damage and falling down pits does even less.  Additionally, the game hands you upgrades in the form of "Relics", which grant secondary abilities to your transformations, magic attacks that draw power from a mana bar, or passive abilities.  One such relic, obtained by gathering 10 keys hidden throughout the game that unlock concept art in the town hall, gives you an endless mana pool to draw on.  This is very easily abusable with the magic powers you acquire over the course of the game, including a shield that makes you invisible.  By collecting this one relic, you essentially activate god mode and can't be damaged at all.  You are able to turn the upgrades on and off at any time, which I found very welcome trying to give myself a bit more of a challenge, but even without them you'll very rarely see the game over screen.  The game also relies on manual saves where an autosave system would serve so much better.  For instance, going to the map screen mid-level calls a save screen, and upon selecting any other area on the map calls ANOTHER save screen.  The game is also rather short (I achieved 100% completion in about 7 hours according to the in-game timer), so I would mostly recommend this game to completionists or those looking to speed run.  Overall, this is a fantastic game marred by just a few disappointments.  As of the writing of this review, I have only finished the standard game mode with 100% completion with an early copy provided by backing the kickstarter campaign, so the bugs I mentioned earlier will probably be ironed out by the time the game fully launches.

PROS:
-Great sound design/OST
-Fun and diverse levels
-Incredibly tight controls
-Great for speedrunning

CONS:
-A little too much backtracking
-Lacking in overall number of areas
-Some minor oversights (such as the save system)

I give Shantae: Half Genie Hero a 9/10.

28490484.review: So far it's the platformer game i have had the most fun in!

28490454.review:
[h1]A worthy successor to the Shantae franchise[/h1]
 
Once again imbued with her magic powers, Shantae has access to a record-breaking twelve transformations. Each form bears a unique function that allows you to further unravel a level on subsequent playthroughs.
 
There's plenty of fresh, risque content to pique your interest. Several new, cute enemies are bound to catch your eye. It's refreshing to see fantasy mainstays like ghosts and slimes portrayed as cute, sultry ladies. Newcomers and familiar faces both are given a fresh look as the entire game is now beautifully rendered and animated in cel-shaded art, an upgrade from those classic pixels.
 
The storyline remains as lighthearted and humorous as ever. Progressing the story once again hinges upon catering to fetch quests and revisiting old levels with new powers. Levels are now incredibly linear, complete with a level select screen ala Megaman.  A tremendous amount of effort has been put into developing the bosses, these are by far the most developed in the series.
 
Unfortunately I must temper my praise for this game by pointing out a few fundamental, glaring flaws.
 
Several transformations and their upgrades go nearly or entirely unused. Most forms can't attack by default, and those that can be upgraded to strike are not viable compared to Shantae's regular form. This game should have focused on four main transformations, consolidating their abilities (Mermaid and crab have too much overlap) and giving them decent attacks. Majora's Mask did it better. In Pirate's Curse you had access to every upgrade at the press of a single button. The final gauntlet was complex, requiring all of your abilities in conjunction with one another. In here you have sections of gameplay sharply divided between each transformation with no interplay.
 
I love going back to a level with new powers to find new items. Here I ended up repeating the same levels four or more times, well beyond being able to enjoy my revisits. You can 100% the game in under 3 hours, but your first time without a guide may take you up to six. Since the levels are entirely linear, the game world feels less interconnected and more sterile. Unlocking new transformations no longer fills me with any sense of wonder partially since there are so many and also since they're not punctuated by deeply buried, ancient shrines. There are no dungeons, and the penultimate level is painfully brief.
 
Amazing art direction coupled with Jake Kaufman's musical prowess make for a winning combination. Half Genie Hero is another wonderful installment, but doesn't hit the same high notes as Pirate's Curse.

28490409.review:
Disclosure:
I backed this game during it's crowdfunding campaign. Upon launching the game offers a 64bit DX11 version, this is the one I played.


Shantae returns to once again do battle with her arch nemisis Risky boots and save Scuttle Town from certain doom. 

Graphics:
This time out the pixel styled graphics from the previous games make way for new hand drawn sprites and 3D rendered environments (think Duck Takes Remastered). The game looks beautiful with high quality assests used throughout also teamed with the high quality animations the series has had in the past. The game also runs at a locked 60fps. However the graphics options are lacking, offering only resolution changes and AA options of off, on or dynamic.

Controls:
Controls are nice and responsive, press a button and the action is immidiate I was unable to detect any input lag or delay during my playthrough. The game supports both keyboard and mouse and controller configurations. However the game is best played on a controller and also gives out Xbox One button prompts. The default keyboard controls are a little odd with movement on the arrow keys, but are fully rebindable in the optins menu. The options menu is fully mouse driver as is the inventory screen, but the level select and save promps are not which is a little odd.

Gameplay:
The game plays out in the same way as the other Shantae games. Scuttle Town acts as the main hub world for the game offering a shop, access to the games art gallery (with unlockable concept and fan art), a save point and a selection of npc's to talk to who offer game hints or side quests to undertake. Heading into Sky's Hatchery allows Shantae to access the world map where the games levels are represented as desitnations that are unlocked using maps Shantae uncovers along her journey.

The levels themselves consist of two platforming areas followed by a boss battle, however subsiquent visits to a level once completed does not have the boss battle and there is no way I have found yet to replaying bosses without starting a new game. The game does offer three save slots so new games can be played without fear of data loss.

As with previous games in the series, Shantae unlocks transformations and abilities which allow her to further explore each of the levels and uncover more secrets each time through. It is the upgrades that are bring up the first negative of the game which is difficulty. The game is more on the easier side than previous installments if you go for all of the upgrades, especially health. Max health gives Shantae 14 hits before she is defeated and the game is quite generous regarding healing items as well. But these health items are optional and the game can be played through to the end with the starting 2 hit points if desired.

Sound/Music:
The sound in this game is great. Nice high quality sound effects are used throughout and some dialogue is even voice acted at times, although this is limited to Shantae and Risky Boots. Shantae even has voice lines for her magic spells.
The music is also fantastic in this game, with personal notable tracks for me being the music for Mermaid Falls, the boss theme and of course the rocking main theme of the game Dance Through the Danger.

Overall:
I would thoroughly recommend this game as a purchase for those who are into platforming games or those who want a fun (all be it quite short, but replayable) experience. My first playthrough took me 7 1/2 hours to complete, with a 98% completion rating. There are unlockables such as gallery art and a Hero mode which opens up after completing the story once. Not sure what Hero mode is at the time of writing.

28490400.review:
[b]Full Disclosure:[/b] I'm a Kickstarter backer and am a big fan of the Shantae series.



There's three things Wayforward excells at in each Shantae game. Animation, Music, and Writing.



[b]Animation:[/b] It's literally the best i've seen throughout the games yet, i'm not only gushing over the transition into 2.5D but am also liking the cartoonish character portraits.  The small image bobs gives a sense of liveliness and brings across the way each character is feeling quite adequately.  It's her first HD adventure and and HGH (Half-Genie Hero) fully captures the visual look of a Shantae game.



[b]Music:[/b] Jake Kaufman (who has composed each Shantae soundtrack) is the "Audio guy" yet again and has done yet another great job.  You can listen to remixes of older Shantae music and fully original tracks as well, my favorites being the title screen music and Neo Burning Town.



[b]Writing:[/b] Wayforward yet again gives you their classic tongue-and-cheek style of writing so you can enjoy both the plot and all of the silly jokes that go along with it with one of my favorite quotes being: "Blast it All. That airship cost billions of crowd-funded dollars!"



[b]Gripes[/b]The major gripe I have with the game currently is the content, it's somewhat of a short game and you'll find yourself finishing it with 100% in about 6-9 hours, Risky's Revenge is a shorter game but the story for HGH leaves more to be desired with the only other option available being the speedrun achievements).  Also two of the transformations only really have one-time uses and are under-powered in comparison to the others.  Granted the other transformations are very useful and gives shantae both tools for tackling a stage and a different means of attacking various enemies.



However, they plan on adding THREE seperate playable costumes for Shantae (similar to the Dancer costume in Risky's Revenge) and plan on adding FOUR additional campaigns for Risky Boots, Rottytops, Bolo, and Sky which should solve the game's launch-date content issue.



If you want to get a full-enjoyment out of HGH, I recommend you play through Risky's Revenge and Pirates Curse beforehand since it'll increase your enjoyment for HGH.  Regardless, this is a good starting point if you're thinking about getting into the series since it does a good job capturing the feel and gameplay of a Shantae game.



I hope you enjoy!  I sure did!!

28490394.review:
Worth it. Sure it took 3 years for this kickstarter game to come out, but I can say I got my money's worth for backing this game...and the game only just has the FIRST of FIVE playable characters so far with the rest coming up soon!

Wayforward's best traits are simple yet enteraining gameplay & amazing animation, and both are on full display in Shantae: Half-Genie Hero. They really took what they learned from Ducktales Remastered and refined it into some of the best use of 2D Sprite and Vector animation in a videogame to date. All the characters are drawn by hand this way, no cop-out use 3D-Model characters like in Rayman Legends and many other similar 2.5D games. 3D is only used for the colorful levels and backgrounds, but even you can hardly tell half the time by how well painted and textured they are that the characters feel right at home in the game.

The game itself is probably the easiest to get into of the Shantae series; keeping the mainstay of the series' gameplay, but reducing the amount of backtracking of its metroidvania roots for a wider audience, though a little bit does remain, especially  when trying to get the optional upgrades and 100% completion. I would say that Pirate's Curse is a bigger and more epic adventure entry in the series then this game. However throughout the development of this game I felt like Wayforward were trying to make a more accessable game for the Shantae series, as the first three games are all tied together in their overarching story, making playing only one of the games a bit confusing if you didn't know the plot of the previous ones. Half Genie Hero is its own self contained story so there is no need to play the other games, which can be troublesome for many people as the first game for the Gameboy Advance is a bit arcadic; Risky's Revenge though still enjoyable is a tad flawed with bits of its gameplay, and Pirate's Curse relies on the player knowing the story up until that point in the series.

Currently as of the day before release, none of the DLC has been implemented yet, but once everything is set in it should be avaliable. The only DLC that may take a while is the other playable characters as Wayforward plans to release them one at a time as the three stretchgoal characters Bolo, Sky, and Rottytops aren't quite ready if I remember one of their previous development logs. But the backer level DLC and Risky Boots character story should be coming in soon hopefully.

That said, there are a couple minor shortcomings I am a bit disappointed about. Nothing that impacts my enjoyment of the game, but just a couple nitpicks I have:

1) Once you beat the boss of some levels, if you return to a place you have beaten before, the background is fill with a glooming fog, obscuring the wonderful and charming backgrounds of the levels. It's a shame that such nice looking levels become muddied up by the choice to put up a fog in some of these levels once they are beaten.

2) This one bugs be more then the other: Shantae only has one dancing animation for all her transformations and magic dances. Reguardless of which transformation you choose, she currently only has the hip-shaking dance and the finishing pose for all 14 of her dances. In previous games she had various dancing moves for each one; most notable was the first game where each dance was unique to the transformation or magic; then in Risky's Revenge she only had three dances, but each one was different for the animal she transformed into though the final pose was the same one for all three. FInally is Pirate's Curse, which granted do to plot didn't have transformation dances, but using the lamp item did give two different animations, one of which was a all new belly dancing animation. It wasn't necessary for the gameplay or plot, but it was a nice little touch to her character. However here in this game there are 14 dances, but they all use the same one.

It could easily be fixed by tweaking the animations a bit. Here's how the dancing works to get an idea. You press the "Dance" button to bring up the dancing menu. Soft music and a steady beat starts playing and Shantae dances to it in rhythm. The menu shows the first 4 dance slots for 2 beats then for the next 2 beats it switches to the second set of 4 dances, then 2 beats for the third set, then it cycles back to the first four, making 12 slots for dances total. Risky's Revenge had a similar concept with the dances where holding down the dance button would cycle through the three dances in that game and releasing it activated the transformation she was performing. 

The issue of Shantae having only one dance and one finishing pose could be fixed of each of the 2 beats she did a different dance move for each set of dances, then finally once the dance is selected she does a finishing pose that represents the transformation she turns into.




However, regardless of the minor shortcomings that may get fixed, Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is a success in my book. Sure this kickstarter isn't the groundbreaker or epic adventure Shovel Knight is; but it is FAR from the disaster Mighty No. 9 was. This game isn't meant to be grand, but rather a fun, charming adventure with likeable and often funnily-bizzard characters you know from Wayforward. So if you enjoyed Wayforward's previous games or want to start getting into their games; Half-Genie Hero is a full time winner, and will get even better as the stretchgoal content is released.

28490383.review:
As a Kickstarter I got the game 2 weeks early for being a Backer.

I personally enjoy this game, so much that I'm going to also be speedrunning it quite often.
But this is a review so I'll give my review.

Pros:
Beauitfully done animation
Jake Kauffman comes through again with one of his best soundtracks yet
Fan Service, Fan Service, Fan Service!
Enjoyable Story
All the enjoyable Shantae gameplay is still there
DLC will have Risky Mode, more costumes and hero modes when released.
As a Kickstarter, the DLC will be free for me

Cons:
Short, first time playthrough averages 5-6 hours
Until DLC comes out, not much replayability aside from Speedrunning/Hero mode
Having compeated with Mighty No. 9 during the kickstarter - It didn't get as much backing, so content is considerably lacking due to it even with the upcoming DLC.
More linear, lost quite a bit of the Metroidvania feel and less exploration.

Neutrals:
It's easier, which can be a con to some. But after the terror that was Shantae and the Pirates Curse platforming, it was welcoming.
Animations are beautiful, but feels like they are missing something.

Overall:

I hope the sales of the game will help them get more funding to add more content to the game at a later time. :)

I'll still be running it as a Speedrunner, as mentioned above, very very ofter as I enjoyed the game quite a bit.

28490376.review:
Shantae: Half-Genie Hero surprised me. Good and original platformers are getting more and more rare. The gameplay is fun and responsive, I got used to the transformations, they add a variety of different ways to play the game. But the pacing does suffer, especially later on, when you get a lot of transformations and have to shuffle through them all. The story is very basic but it is very charming, it gives the game a fun and light feel. The hub world can get annoying because it isn't always clear what you have to do, to move on to the next level, and you have to return to the same levels allot and search for that one thing you need to move on to the next level. It sometimes felt like I played the same level 10 times. I feel like they didn't put in everything they wanted to in the game, either because they didn't have time or some other reason. So they make you play the same thing again and again. And the boss levels are I’m sad to say too easy and repetitive. 

Overall though I really enjoyed the level design in Shantae: Half-Genie Hero, even though I got sick of playing the same levels, it has some game design ideas I haven't seen before. And I really like the graphics, it is one of my favorite games this year. But it was a bad year for me, so that doesn't say much. It is still just barely an above average game. Games like, Shovel Knight, Ori and the blind forest and Super meat boy are much better.

6 out of 10. 

It makes me wonder why it took so long to release the game, development issues maybe?

28490369.review:
The first game that I've ever backed on kickstarter, and done so on a whim, so I wasn't expecting much out of it...
...it's actually pretty good.

It has great animations, the gameplay is quite the decent metroidvania, and quite good set-pieces. It also runs pretty good, even on this toaster of a laptop I had to play on.
It is, as of this writing, quite short, though. Only 5 chapters fill this game right now, with a bit too much backtracking. A normal run should take you between 7~10 hours.

28490365.review:
Après avoir fini la partie principale du jeu, difficile de trouver à redire (mais on va y arriver, vous allez voir).

[h1]Première impression[/h1]
Le plus important: le jeu est très bien fait; c'est joli, l'histoire (enfin, les dialogues) sont assez léger pour laisser la place au jeu, et l'ambiance est soignée (aussi bien sonore que visuelle). Les contrôles (testé avec un Pad 360) réagissent parfaitement, et sur environ 7h de jeu pour finir la campagne principale (je suis un fan de la série :D), aucun soucis de type bug/plantage/blocage. C'est triste à dire mais de nos jours, ça n'est plus une évidence.

[h1]Contenu[/h1]
Les niveaux sont tous différents, et mettent en avant des gimmicks bien distinct; peu de répétition pour le joueur, donc peut d'ennui, et ça c'est bien, le jeu s'adressant aussi bien aux joueurs confirmés avec son exploration et ses collectibles, qu'aux joueurs occasionnels avec les parties "principales" plutôt accessibles. Y'en a pour tous les goûts, quoi.

Pour la jouabilité donc, on est à la fois sur de la plate-forme classique et sur quelque chose d'un peu plus sympa. Entre les magies et les transformations (il faudra acheter l'un, et trouver l'autre), le joueur pourra vraiment modeler sa progression comme il le souhaite, et pourra (enfin, devra!) explorer à nouveaux certaines zones après avoir débloqués de nouveaux moyens de progresser. Le jeu présente d'ailleurs l'essentiel des objets à collecter sur la carte, histoire de ne pas perdre son temps sur une zone "terminée".

[h1]Oui mais...[/h1]
Petits points noirs: la traduction française qui, au moins la veille de la sortie, est pleine de typo et d'erreurs (des grosses typo, hein). Ça sent fortement la traduction google pas digérée par moment (et pas toujours, ce qui est très étrange). Peut-être que ça sera corrigé rapidement avec la sortie officielle :)

[h1]Alors, quoi ?[/h1]
WayForward sait faire des jeux qui vont au bout de leur concept. On n'a vraiment l'impression d'être devant un jeu aboutit, pas forcément le plus prétentieux au monde, mais qui réussit vraiment ce qu'il veut faire: proposer une bonne expérience de plate-forme avec un humour qui détend. C'est bien réalisé aussi bien sur le fond que sur la forme, et il y a une rejouabilité raisonnable (un mode NG+, un mode alternatif), ce qu'on peut attendre pour ce type de jeu.

Les acharnées passeront environ 7h sur la partie principale (la première fois). Pour les autres, ben, avancez à votre rythme et profitez.

28490357.review:
Full disclosure: I am a Kickstarter backer of this game.

The Shantae series has been a consistent provider of well-crafted platform adventures since the original was released on the Game Boy Color, with each game adding new refinements to a proven formula. This latest release continues the trend with updated abilities and a combination of hand-drawn and 3D graphics.

As mentioned, this game doesn't deviate much from previous Shantae games - though this isn't a bad thing. Bad guys are up to bad things in Sequin Land, and it's Shantae's job to collect what she needs to stop them. Fans of the series will be on familiar territory, and metroidvania fans will find a lot to like. The characters are endearing and memorable, and the plot would fit nicely in a well-written Saturday morning cartoon.

Of course, an important element in any game of this type is the quality of the puzzles and secrets. This game has well-crafted ones just difficult enough to make you want to finish them, without being overly frustrating. I was able to clear 96% of the game without a guide, and the items I had to really work for can be passed over if you just want to play through without finding every little secret. The boss fights are mostly of the "action puzzle" variety as well. At times, the method for beating them wasn't immediately clear, but it didn't require much work to figure it out, and the fights themselves were still challenging.

As for the shift in art style, I am in favor of it. As much as I appreciate well-done sprite graphics (and I do), the hand-drawn characters really suit this series, and it goes well with the cartoony atmosphere. Speaking of, I enjoyed the dialogue as well, with well-written humor that managed to be sharp without resorting to being too crude.

All in all, I think adventure fans will enjoy this game if they've never tried the series before, and returning Shantae fans will be well satisfied. Shantae is securing her position among gaming greats.
